Sustainable investing, also known as socially responsible investing, is the process of incorporating environmental ğŸŒ, social and governance (ESG) factors into investment decisions. Individuals who invest sustainably choose to invest in companies, organizations and funds with the purpose of generating measurable social and environmental impact alongside a financial return ğŸ’°. Impacts are spread across various sectors, from renewable energy and climate change, to health ğŸ¥, safety and community development.

Sustainable investing ğŸ“ˆ enables individuals to select investments based on values and personal priorities. Initially, sustainable investing negatively ğŸ‘ğŸ¼ screened companies and industries, which often led investors to sacrifice returns for value-aligned investment choices. In recent years, however, investors have used positive screening of ESG risk factors to create a modern “best-in-class” investment ğŸ’¸ approach that generates performance that is in line with—and often exceeds—market benchmarks.

This shift toward market outperformance in several sustainable investing products ğŸŒ¿ has contributed to the increase in demand ğŸš€ for these products as fiduciaries look to serve their clients by not only generating returns, but also assessing impact. 

Providing sustainable investing opportunities enables firms ğŸ‘” to not only capture financial returns for clients ğŸ¤ , but also to realize intrinsic returns not replicated elsewhere. These intrinsic returns lead to deeper connections between the clients and their investing habits, creating long-term customer appetite.

Diversification may seem daunting and complicated, but it can be made very simple. Still, the real power of this tool is often far overlooked by individual investors. Today we are going to help you take a grasp of the complete image of diversification. ğŸ§‘‍ğŸ’»

You may have heard the old saying, “Don’t put all of your eggs into one basket.” Many people think this is what diversification means. 

~ To hold more than a handful of stocks to protect your returns. ~

While this is accurate, there is far more to diversification than meets the eye. So much so that the largest hedge fund in the world calls it the “Holy Grail of Investing.” So what is diversification? ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸

It really is the idea of buying the whole store, seriously. ğŸ—ğŸ¥¦ğŸ¥”ğŸ¥’ğŸ¥“ğŸ«

A great way to describe diversification is to use the traditional grocery store example ğŸ˜. When you are shopping you aren’t going to just buy one item ğŸ’ª. You want to enjoy a full and balanced diet. You will need proteins, grains, veggies, fruits, and maybe even a couple of beers ğŸ‘€. No matter how much you enjoy it, your body can’t run off of only one food group. Your investment portfolio is the same. Even if you are having an awesome time only buying tech stocks, eventually it will catch up to you. ğŸ˜¿ğŸ˜¾

So that’s what you then set up to do. Buy great stocks in the other “food groups” or industries. Buy some stock in your favorite stores around town ğŸ¤. Buy some stock in airline companies with strong long-term potential ğŸ›«. Even buy some stock in your favorite food companies. Ok, awesome we have done it, Diversification achieved!

Actually, no. ğŸ™‡ğŸ»‍â™‚ï¸

While you have built a strong base of diversified common stocks, you can still achieve even more diversification ğŸ¤”. First, let's check out some international stocks in a stable foreign market. Adding foreign stock to your portfolio can help protect against large scale market downturns in your home country ğŸ’‚‍â™€ï¸. Plus, you get to say you're an ~international investor~ (Pretty Cool) ğŸ˜. 

Wait but what about some bonds? Why not add in some government treasury bonds or corporate bonds to lock in some returns for your portfolio? Yeah, not a bad idea ğŸ˜. But what if you could then diversify these bonds? Like maybe some foreign bonds? Now you're cooking. ğŸ˜²ğŸ¤

As you can imagine this trend continues by moving throughout all of the assets offered to individual investors. Everything from foreign currencies to even collectibles like vintage cars and paintings. ğŸ’ By dividing your money throughout a collection of different uncorrelated things that will gain value, you set yourself up for long-term gains with limited risk. ğŸš€

The Holy Grail of Investing? ğŸ¤«

While this strategy is not going to bring you millions tomorrow, it is a pretty solid way to lock in millions in say 30 years. That’s still pretty nice if you ask me. ğŸ˜¬

The Bottomline ğŸ“–

There is so much of a focus on diversification because holding a group of stocks, bonds, and other assets that move in different ways, helps you maintain long-term compounding returns ğŸ§®. Using diversification can decrease one’s risk and help lock in long-term growth that is not seen by buying stocks in only one or two industries ğŸ­. Overall, by knowing the true power of diversification, you are setting yourself up to obtain serious long-term gains ğŸ¤‘.

So you want to be an investment pro? 

There is a lot more than meets the eye when it comes to being the Wolf of Wall Street. ğŸº

Big surprise, no one is perfect ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸. Once entering the jungle of investing, we can get easily sidetracked into endless distractions, emotions, and false information that can lead us to end up losing money ğŸ¤¦‍â™‚ï¸. 

Yeah this doesn’t sound too fun, but you are already here reading this, so at least you have that step up over your peers ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ“. By identifying these barriers to positive investment, you can help yourself become a better investor in the long run ğŸš€.

Emotions ğŸ¤©ğŸ¥µğŸ˜°

Playing the markets can quickly become emotional. Depending on the stocks you are investing in, you can suddenly see large swings in your account balance that can lead to all sorts of emotions ğŸ”¥. 

Because investing is tied entirely to money, our emotions can be polarized ğŸ§². One second you are an investment genius, the next second you are a gambling degenerate. People naturally like to call the stocks that make them money “smart investments” while the stocks that lose them money are “uneducated bets.” For the investors that are able to get past their pride and recognize their strong stocks, their honest mistakes, and their own luck, these investors will be better set up to bring in long-run gains ğŸ’¸.

Account Size ğŸ’°

Most people start off with modest account sizes but like everyone else, they have hopes of high gains ğŸ“ˆ. Everyone wants to be sitting on their yacht in the Meditteranean answering questions on how their ingenious landed them there ğŸ. Because of these natural goals of wanting financial freedom, people will be interested in putting all of their accounts into one or two relatively cheap stocks. Rarely does this work â˜¹ï¸.

Combining market fluctuations and human emotions, the account value can suddenly dive and you will quickly be angered ğŸ¤¬. Those new to the market may move out of that one stock and move to another stock they feel is better set up for financial gains. Following this cycle of buying high and selling low, their accounts slowly drift to zero ğŸ˜³. 

It is important to realize the strengths and weaknesses of one’s own account size ğŸ§®. Getting into investing is great no matter what amount you can contribute to your account. Just make sure you are diversifying your account with great companies that will give you long-term growth instead of only one or two stocks that you believe will give you massive short-term gains ğŸ¤”. 

The Knowledge Gap ğŸ“š

The markets are a jungle ğŸ¯. Each day there are millions of different events, mindsets, voices, and beliefs that are shifting separate sections of the market âš–ï¸. As smaller investors, we are caught in the middle of all of this ğŸ¥µ. 

We love to believe that we are smarter than the rest and can outperform the market ğŸ•º. Furthermore, we love to tell each other our investment ideas that may have little to no merit ğŸ—£. A constant flow of amateur investment media, online investment gurus, and heavy wall street jargon has only complicated the investment process. Most new investors do not have the time or the interest to be analyzing macroeconomics and business fundamentals, so how do we deal with this ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸? 

Our Investing Tips! ğŸ¤“

  1. Be Honest. Know your investing strengths and weaknesses. ğŸ™„

  1. Think long-term. “Compounding interest is the 8th wonder of the world.” - Albert Einstein ğŸ¤

  1. Be patient. Chasing massive gains will lead to massive losses. ğŸ¤¬

  1. Know your objectives. Investing is not to generate income. It is to establish wealth. ğŸ©

  1. Don’t believe everything you hear. Always take the time to do your own research before investing. ğŸ•µï¸

If the idea of saving the planet feels like an impossible superhero-sized mission to you, it shouldn’t! ğŸ¦¸‍â™€ Collectively, we have the power to hinder climate change ğŸŒ³ But which actions make a real difference? Which goes further than just contributing to greenwashing campaigns? Let’s find out together!

Reducing our carbon footprint for a sustainable future

In our daily routines, we often contribute to our carbon footprint. From our food intake to our energy consumption, much of what requires energy to produce or use goes hand-in-hand with carbon emissions. So what would be a more sustainable carbon emissions strategy? ğŸ¤”

  1. AVOID âŒ
    Naturally, avoiding carbon-emitting activities in the first place is the best way to improve our carbon footprint. Tough, but optimal!
     

  2. REDUCE, REUSE & RECYCLE â™»ï¸
    When avoiding is not an option, reducing one’s emissions where possible by recycling products and reusing them instead of purchasing replacements also contributes to the decrease in carbon emissions and, ultimately, a more sustainable future ğŸŒ±
     

  3. OFFSET â¬‡ï¸  
    As a last resort, offsetting one’s emission is another option. In offsetting, a third party is paid to compensate for the greenhouse gases emitted.

What specific actions can we take?

At Home: The energy used in our homes comprises, on average, 26% of our total footprint. Wherever you live, here are some steps you can take to reduce your energy use: 

  1. Switch to a green energy supplier ğŸ’š
    By substituting fossil-fueled energy providers with renewable energy, we make sure that less unsustainably produced energy is produced and decrease our carbon emissions â˜€ï¸

  2. Stop heating an empty home ğŸ¡ Heating and cooling can account for up to 44% of energy use. Try to keep the temperatures down when you are at work or on vacation – it cuts down your energy bill as well! ğŸ’°

  3. Turn appliances off at the power source ğŸ“º Flipping the switch on the wall makes a huge difference. Devices in stand-by continue to use energy, something referred to as phantom load ğŸ‘» You can also avoid using stand-by energy by installing smart plugs that allow you to remotely to turn off all power at a given socket or schedule its hours of operation. 

Travel: Your carbon footprint depends a lot on how you get from A to B. If you decide to leave the car in favour of walking or cycling ğŸš´‍â™‚ï¸, you can save up to 2.4 tonnes of CO2e per year. Moreover, airplanes emit thousands tonnes of carbon gases  – reducing air travel and focusing on greener airlines helps reduce our footprint to save the planet. âœˆï¸ğŸŒ±

Diet: Carbon emissions are generated in both the production and transportation of food products. In a perfect world, the entire globe would go vegan right now ğŸ¥¦ Cutting out all meat and dairy products would slash out eight of the top ten foods contributing to greenhouse gas emissions completely ğŸ¥©ğŸ§€ But if this sounds like too much of a stretch, we can also do the following to reduce our footprint: 

  1. Reduce meat consumption: Make educated choices about your consumption. For example, lamb ğŸ‘ is considered the worst for your carbon footprint, followed by beef ğŸ®

  2. Buy fresh and local ğŸ¤˜Food miles have an enormous impact on your carbon footprint. Buying seasonal items also goes hand-in-hand with avoiding distant transport ğŸš›Fresh food also reduces your footprint in comparison to frozen food, which requires much energy to produce and freeze â„ï¸

Shopping: Clothes are overconsumed in our fast-fashion industry ğŸ‘–British charity Barnardo’s estimates that fast fashion items are worn, on average, seven times before being chucked away ğŸ—‘ The environmental impact of this trend is huge: one cotton t-shirt manufactured in China has a footprint of 8.77 kg C02e. Here is what you can do to counter this trend: 

  1. Buy used instead of new items: Many resale websites have sprung up in recent years offering many varieties of quality second-hand clothing ğŸ™Œ

  2. Take extra good care of your clothes: Be more gentle with your clothes to increase their expected lifetime ğŸ§º If your clothes do become unwearable, consider fixing them yourself or contact your local tailor ğŸ§¶

Work: During COVID-19, many started working from home. However, our laptop is not impact-free either ğŸ’» Every time we search, stream or download, there is an electricity-hungry data centre somewhere making it happen. Therefore, reducing our internet consumption time goes hand-in-hand with lowering our carbon footprint ğŸŒ±

Invest for impact

These actions help tackle climate change in our own lives and are very important for a more sustainable future. Together, we can strengthen the movement and create the change we want ğŸ’ª

Is this all we can do? Not quite yet. 

Another big piece of the climate change puzzle is changing the behaviour of corporations. Between 1965 and 2017, 480 billion tonnes of CO2e have been released into the atmosphere – and that can all be tracked to just twenty companies ğŸ‘ The best way to change their behaviour is through impact investing ğŸ“ˆ: buying stocks, bonds, and other assets of companies which support the values you stand for. Via impact investing, we can provide the great companies out there with the necessary funding to drive the green transformation we need ğŸ’š

In this article, we will talk about Prosperity and what factors have caused the lack of prosperity in many regions ğŸ’° We also provide you with three suggestions of companies that strive in this area ğŸ” So that YOU can start putting your money where your heart is ğŸ’›

Prosperity

Prosperity consists of SDG 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy), SDG 8 (Decent and Economic Growth), SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure), SDG 10 (Reduced Inequalities), and SDG 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities).

Prosperity and growth in societies need an environment that allows it to flourish ğŸŒ» In the developed part of the world, having constant electricity, internet, housing, and social equality is something that most of us take for granted. Sadly enough, for many people around the world, these standards are far from being achieved âŒ

Despite the growth of the global economy, extreme poverty is still an issue and is often concentrated in urban areas ğŸŒƒ Many are moving from rural areas to the city creating a shortage in housing opportunities. The lack of job opportunities for a growing labor force is causing income inequality to rise to create a wider gap between rich and poor. Inadequate transportation systems make it difficult for those who do not have a car to get to their jobs ğŸš Many still do not have access to the internet or electricity. All these issues make it impossible for those affected to keep up with the constant development and growth in the world ğŸ“ˆ To prosper, there has to be the opportunity to do so. 

So, what can be done?

Infrastructure needs to be developed to create growth opportunities, reduce poverty and make electricity affordable and accessible for all ğŸ™† Create quality housing with clean running water ğŸ’§Improve transportation ğŸšŠ technological innovation and communication technologies ğŸ“² Encouraging entrepreneurship and job creation to get rid of forced labour and job scarcity ğŸ‘·‍â™‚ï¸

3 Companies we think are Great

The following three companies are awesome examples of companies that support global prosperity through making a strong, inclusive, and transformative economy â™º All companies are participants of the United Nations Global Compact, whose mission is to mobilize a global movement of sustainable companies and stakeholders to create the world we want ğŸ’ª

VESTAS WIND SYSTEMS A/S

Vestas Wind Systems is a Danish manufacturer that creates, installs, and services wind turbines ğŸ’¨ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡° The core of Vestas’ business model is to produce affordable renewable energy solutions, and to continuously innovate to improve wind turbine efficiency, thus contributing to the fight against climate change 

SKANSKA AB

Skanska AB is an international construction company based in Stockholm, Sweden ğŸ”¨ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª Over the past few years, Skanska has focused on strategically working towards leadership with sustainability. This involves a focus on Health, Safety, Ethics, Community Investment, Diversity, and Inclusion ğŸ˜· In addition, this development company has expanded its low carbon solutions to its clients with a goal to decrease its overall carbon footprint. 

SCANDIC HOTELS GROUP AB

Scandic Hotels is a hotel chain headquartered in Stockholm, with a presence in all Nordic countries ğŸ¨ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª To all its employees, it offers equal conditions regardless of gender, disability, ethnic background, etc. The Group also employs people outside the labor market and has a strong focus on Fairtrade products. All its efforts have led the company to receive several awards in the area of sustainability. 

To wrap it up

We have now introduced you to some companies that support the SDGs within the area of Prosperity, hoping to have inspired you to start an impact investing journey of your ownğŸ’°ğŸ’š Impact investing can be a powerful tool for you to start making a difference and by supporting companies with sustainable values and goals, you will be part of a movement that wants to see tomorrow’s world as healthy, happy and just as possible. Download our app and join the movement now!ğŸ¤ŸğŸ»

So you want to put your money into an investment fund? Awesome! But what are they? ğŸ¤”

Two types of investment funds are Mutual Funds and Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs). These funds are run by groups of professionals ğŸ§‘‍ğŸ’¼ who have dedicated their lives to studying stocks and portfolios. Essentially they do the job of investing for you while you sit back and reap the returns ğŸ“ˆ.

It’s pretty great ğŸ˜.

A good analogy for why to use an investment fund is similar to why you would go out to eat. Even if you are a good cook, it is nice to have someone else do the job for you while you sit back and relax. ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ³ğŸ¥™

Ok, but still, what is the difference between Exchange Traded Funds and Mutual Funds? ğŸ¤“

They are similar in the sense that both pool money from crowds of investors to create diverse portfolios to help grow their investor’s moneyğŸ“ˆ. However, there are some key differences that are important to know when deciding which one will better meet your investment goals ğŸ§—.

Let’s Talk Liquidity! ğŸŒŠ

ETFs have the unique ability to be bought and sold throughout the day. (In Wall Street slang this means they are Liquid ğŸŒŠ). This is because they are passively managed, meaning they will usually try to follow a group of stocks in an index, industry, or particular style of investing. Because of this, the holdings of an ETF are rarely changed during the day â±. 

A mutual fund, on the other hand, is actively managed, meaning that the professionals invest across multiple sectors and industries throughout the dayâ³.  Therefore, mutual funds can only be bought when the stock market closes ğŸ•°. (Meaning it is less liquid than an ETF â„ï¸). Such is because the holdings of the mutual fund can shift if the professionals think it is smarter to change up the portfolio ğŸ§®. 

Overall, the professionals running Mutual Funds are more focused on returns ğŸ“ˆ while professionals in charge of Exchange Traded Funds are focused on seeing their investment choices make long-term gains ğŸ’ª. 

For this reason, fees associated with mutual funds can be higher than ETFs — since you’re paying a professional for their ongoing advice ğŸ•º.

So why does this matter? ğŸ’‍â™‚ï¸

It is really all based on your investment opinions. 

Maybe you think the long-term holding of an index is the best way to invest your money.  ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

Maybe you think it is better to have the professionals actively watch over your money for you. ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸

There is no right answer. Just like how people argue over the best restaurants, people also argue over investment styles. It’s a part of life. 

But how does this tie into Sustainable Investing? ğŸŒ

A great part about both ETFs and Mutual Funds is that they can be specialized to help guide your own sustainable investing ğŸŒ¿. 

If part of your investment strategy is to invest in companies that promote, for example, gender equality, you could choose a targeted socially responsible ETF that will invest your money in a variety of companies with high levels of gender diversity in leadership positions. ğŸ˜

Alternatively, you could choose a mutual fund that invests in a diverse range of companies but specifically not tobacco, weapons, or gambling. ğŸ˜

Both options allow you to invest your money in line with your values, just in different ways. 

Overall, neither type of fund is better or worse than the other. Factors such as risk and return on your investment depend more on the specific portfolio itself, rather than what type of fund you chose. ğŸ¤“

It’s more of a question of what is better for your needs and interests. If you are really split, you could even diversify your own portfolio by holding both ETFs and Mutual Funds at the same time. ğŸ˜„ğŸ¤ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ³

When a company moves from being a privately owned company to a public corporation, it means that people (like you!) can start investing in the corporation ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’»ğŸ”¥

It’s a big change for a company as it creates a new source of capital which it can use to grow its business ğŸ“ˆ  The first time a corporation offers its shares to investors is called an Initial Public Offering (IPO).

So, what do IPOs mean to you? ğŸ¤” 

To make things simple, let’s highlight three key facts that you need to know about IPOs when you’re new to the investing game:

1ï¸âƒ£ A company usually goes public when it reaches a certain growth stage in which it believes to be mature enough and performing well. For a company, launching an IPO can be risky, so it’s something it plans well in advance before taking the final, big step ğŸš¶‍â™€ï¸A public offering costs the firm quite some money (3.5% - 7% of the IPO proceeds) and is a lengthy process, but if things go well, it can help the business expand and increase its profits ğŸ’°ğŸŒŸ

2ï¸âƒ£ Once a company goes public, it becomes tradable on the market. If the IPO does well, investors may take notice and invest further in the company, thus giving it more funds to grow and expand its operations. BUT, there is a catch: if a company does not do well, its brand may lose face and lead to a decline in the value of the company as its share price falls ğŸ˜¯ğŸ“‰

3ï¸âƒ£ While it may sound great to invest in companies shortly after their IPO, it’s generally not recommended for new investors ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸In the first year after an IPO, share prices tend to fluctuate significantly. It might also be hard to find unbiased information about the company’s financial situation since, most of the time, all early reports come from the company itself ğŸ•µï¸‍â™‚ï¸ Therefore, IPO investing is considered to be high-risk investing.

It’s not all bad, though! With time, third parties release more reliable information about the company and their stock, so it might not be a bad idea to wait around after an IPO and see what happens ğŸ¤

That being said, it can be interesting to track companies that plan to launch (or have recently launched) an IPO and to watch out for familiar brands. For example, in December 2020, the rental company Airbnb went public. Whilst the sharing economy has been on the rise, the global coronavirus outbreak has also severely impacted travel. It will be interesting to see what happens next and how the future share price of Airbnb will develop!

Many people who start investing would probably agree that a goal for their investment is to see it grow ğŸ’° â†—ï¸ If you identify with this statement, it might be good for you to take a look at the profits of a company before you decide to invest in it.

Profit essentially shows how good a company is at making money ğŸ’ª In technical terms, it’s the amount of money a company makes (revenue) minus the cost of running the business (expenses).

In the short term, profit often varies, so it’s important to look at a company’s ability to generate profit in the long term ğŸ’« You’ll find this type of information in a company’s annual report or its income statement, but you might also find it useful to check out its profit margin (which indicates the percentage of profit in relation to income) ğŸ“ŠğŸ§ 

On to our next important point ğŸ‘‰ when investing, there are three types of profit you need to know about:

Gross profit ğŸ’¥ This is the money a company makes minus the cost of making and selling its product or service (think of materials, storage, etc.) However, gross profit only gives you a limited overview, since financial obligations such as salaries, rent, and loan interest still need to be taken care of. Once these expenses are paid, you get the â¬‡ï¸

Profit before tax ğŸ’¥ An important shout: taxes vary from country to country, so you might find a company that’s good at making a profit with low expenses but on the other hand is affected by higher tax rates âš–ï¸ The solution to finding an even more exact glimpse into a company’s profit is to look at the â¬‡ï¸

Net profit ğŸ’¥  Also known as net earnings or net income! It’s defined as the total profit the company makes after all expenses and taxes are deducted. From such a number, you’re able to tell whether a company has made a profit or a loss in the time period you’re interested in ğŸ¤“

So we like profit – but does it come at a cost?

If you’re interested in investing with an impact, it’s essential to look past the numbers and learn how the company is making a profit. Your investment is buying into a company carrying out a specific type of business, so you need to be sure that your company is using your money in a way that is in line with your values ğŸ‘ ğŸ’“

For example ... each year, Company X makes good profit. Yet, this profit is largely due to the fact that it minimizes its expenses by paying its employees less than minimum wage and by using cheap materials for its products that may harm the environment ğŸ§ª The long-term effects of these practices have global consequences that affect human rights and climate change ğŸŒğŸ”¥

Company Y, on the other hand, also makes rather good profit, but instead chooses to source material for its products locally and pay their employees a fair wage ğŸ‘¯‍â™‚ï¸ ğŸ‰ In choosing between these two companies, you as an investor have a great deal of power! You can choose profit on its own – or, you can choose profit coupled with sustainability â™»ï¸

Remember: just because a company values sustainability, this doesn’t mean that it will be more or less profitable than others. As you learn more about investing, that’s why it’s so important to be aware of impact and how it relates to basic economic concepts ğŸ˜

When you decide to invest in a company and buy a share/stock through your broker, you are essentially buying a piece of the company's equity ğŸ“ƒ But, sometimes, buying a single stock can be very risky. One way to avoid the risk of a single stock (also called idiosyncratic risk) is to diversify. You have two ways to diversify: 1) to create your own basket of stocks – your own portfolio, or 2), to buy an existing ‘basket’ of stocks – a so-called stock index.

So, what is a stock market index? ğŸ¤”

A stock market index is basically a performance-evaluating tool that tracks the performance of a hypothetical basket of stocks. There are many different types of indices, each representing a portion of the overall market and tracking a different basket of stocks. These baskets can be sector-specific, trend-specific, asset class-specific or geography-specific ğŸ”¬ğŸ—ğŸš† These different indices give a general idea of ‘how the market/sector/.... is doing’ by comparing the stock prices ğŸ‘Œ 

Here are a few of the most popular stock market indices to keep in mind:

1ï¸âƒ£ MSCI World Index (tracks 1,562 stocks worldwide)

2ï¸âƒ£ FTSE 100 Index (tracks the 100 largest stocks listed on the London Stock Exchange)

3ï¸âƒ£ S&P 500 Index (tracks the 500 largest American companies)

4ï¸âƒ£ Dow Jones Industrial Average Index (tracks the 30 most prominent American companies)

You might ask: ‘Just to be sure, how is it again that the price of a share is determined?’

Just as food is bought and sold in a grocery market, shares are bought and sold on the stock market ğŸ› 

The prices of fresh products on the food market are often fixed, but on the stock exchange the prices work like an auction (as in supply and demand). This means that buyers name the highest price they are willing to pay and sellers name the lowest price they are willing to accept ğŸ”“In the end, the final price is settled somewhere in between ğŸ¤ 

These negotiations take place via electronic trading platforms or through the use of professional stockbrokers who manage clients’ portfolios on their behalf.

What are indices and how do they work?

There are specialized companies called index providers (e.g. Bloomberg, MSCI, S&P) that decide which stocks are included in the ‘basket’ and how the weighting of each stock is determined ğŸ¯

The indices can be weighted by different methods that basically determine the weight of a company within the index âš–ï¸Depending on the weight of the company, the performance of the individual company can have a bigger or minor impact on the overall performance of the index.

In the MSCI World index, for example, the largest company is Apple with a weight of about 4 percent. The second largest is Microsoft (3.2 percent), followed by Amazon (2.6 percent) ğŸ’ª

How can you invest in an index?

You can easily invest in an index by buying into an index fund. These index funds are a simple and inexpensive way to become exposed to the selected ‘basket’ of stocks ğŸ›’ 

So how exactly does it work? Basically, the index fund uses a replicating method to copy the index and buy and hold the underlying stocks ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’»These funds are then only adjusted when there’s a change in the underlying index.

Finally, when you invest in an index, it might be good to take a look at the expense ratio ğŸš¨This tells you how much you pay to hold a given index. Furthermore, it identifies the percentage of each dollar invested that’s used to cover management and operational costs. For example, ETFs are a new financial tool and offer a very low-cost alternative compared to actively managed funds ğŸ’¥

And remember: based on your own values and interests, you decide what to invest in and how. That’s why it’s important to do your own research before you start investing your money ğŸš€

The market mechanics of supply and demand are at the foundation of economic thought and theory. ğŸ“š Understanding these market drivers will make it easier for you to understand the stock market and spot new trends. ğŸ§ âš¡ï¸

When talking about supply and demand, we’re basically trying to explain why prices fluctuate on the market and why quantities of goods sold change over time. ğŸ“‰ This is how it works:

1ï¸âƒ£ Supply refers to the quantity of a good or service that producers are willing and able to produce at a given price.

2ï¸âƒ£ Demand indicates the quantity that consumers are willing and able to purchase at that price.

Demand works according to the law of demand, which functions a bit like a balancing scale: If the price of a product increases, the demanded quantity decreases and vice versa. âš–ï¸ Everyone has experienced this directly: When a product we want becomes more expensive, we buy less of it, and when it’s cheaper we typically buy more. ğŸ¤‘

However, the law of demand doesn’t apply directly to the stock market. When the price of a stock rises, investors typically don’t want to purchase less of it – instead, they may actually be more attracted to the given share if it increases in value. ğŸ‘€ğŸ”¥ 

Where the theory does apply is in a company’s sales and operations. If the demand for a company’s product increases they will sell more of it, and, as a result, the company rises in value. Now, the demand for the company’s stock increases! ğŸŒ 

This means that we can break the demand’s influence on the stock market down to this: If there’s a notable increase in the demand for a company’s goods or services, it typically leads to an increase in the stock’s share price. ğŸ“ˆ

For example … 

Let’s have a look at the company Apple Inc. ğŸ If Apple were to increase the price of their iPhones they would most likely sell fewer since less people would be able to afford them. ğŸ“± This would lead to a decrease in profits and ğŸ”œ to a lower value of the company, which could scare away potential investors. As a consequence, the share price of Apple would decrease. 

On the other hand, if Apple could afford to lower the prices of their iPhones, this would plausibly lead to more sales, potentially increasing profits ğŸ¤”ğŸ’° This would mean an increase in company value, attracting more investors and an increasing stock price. 

One final thing to be aware of is some products’ price elasticity – the responsiveness of demand to a change in price. If a product’s price elasticity is low, the change in demand is only minor compared to the price change. For example, if there’s a price change in a necessity such as insulin ğŸ’‰we’re likely to keep on buying it – unlike iPhones which can be substituted for another product!

But how does supply and demand relate to impact investing? 

It’s pretty straightforward: If you’re interested in driving a sustainable future with your investments, you should be aware that simply because there’s demand for a product or service does not mean that it equals sustainability. ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸

For example, you might want to look into a company’s reports on their ESG benchmarks â™»ï¸ and ask yourself if the demand for their product and the potential growth of the business would also leave a positive impact on the world. Be the movement - make!mpact! ğŸ§¡

When you invest in a business, that business must first be legally registered as a corporation. This is different from businesses that are nonprofits, organizations, or sole proprietorship firms. It’s important to be aware of this difference as it explains why there are some institutions you can donate to but not invest in, as for example Save the Children ğŸ‘¶ğŸŒ

A corporation is a group of people that is legally recognised as a single entity. Sometimes a corporation is even referred to as a ‘legal person’ since it must act within the same laws as any ordinary person âš–ï¸For example, a business can enter into contracts, own property, borrow money, and be sued – just like normal people ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ‘§‍ğŸ‘¦

For business owners, the greatest benefit of registering as a corporation is that if the company takes on debt, it is the corporation that is liable to pay it off – not the business owners personally. This is different from a business that’s registered as a partnership where, should the business be unable to pay off its debts, the partners are at risk of losing their personal assets ğŸ™‡‍â™‚ï¸

How does this relate to investing?

When a corporation starts selling part of their business in the form of securities (that’s stocks and bonds, for example ğŸ’°), they first go through an Initial Public Offering (IPO). This means that the public (that’s people like you ğŸ‘¸) can start investing in the corporation. Corporations can also be privately traded by big, institutional investors, but the stock market that we as everyday people deal with only comprises publicly traded corporations.

Corporations essentially want people to invest in them so that they can grow their business. Having shareholders (people who own stock) provides the corporation with more money without having to take out loans from banks ğŸ’…Instead, the shareholders own part of the business and, sometimes, the company shares the profits and pays them out as a dividend (stay tuned on m!club to learn more about what this means for your investments!)

For example...

Let’s say Company X develops an innovative technology for electric cars and has big plans for the future ğŸš™ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ”§

In order to grow, the company needs more money. Instead of taking out a loan and paying interest on the loan, the company decides to register as a corporation and goes public through an IPO ğŸ’ª

Meanwhile, a new investor wants to invest a portion of their money in a sustainable corporation. They choose Company X since it’s a company who is both passionate about environmental issues and has a product that promotes the use of electric cars â™»ï¸ğŸš€

By having such shareholders, Company X can use their newly earned investments to further invest in research for the development of their product ğŸ“šğŸ‘©‍ğŸ”¬ As the business grows and makes a profit, shareholders also see their investment grow. And not to forget: as the world grows more aware of sustainability, more people will choose to buy electric cars, which leads to a higher demand for Company X’s technology ğŸ“ˆ

From the above, here’s then some food for thought: as an investor, your decisions have a powerful effect on the world ğŸŒ±The corporations you choose to invest your money in will spend it towards developing their product, and if that product supports a sustainable future, your investment is making a positive impact on the world. Let’s make it happen! ğŸ”¥

An investment fund is an investment strategy based on the idea of ‘the more the merrier’. ğŸ’ƒğŸ•º

How does it work?

There are many ways in which we can invest in companies. One is to invest in stocks individually by carefully selecting the businesses that seem promising to you. ğŸ‘¸ Another way is to invest in companies through investment funds. By investing in a fund, you let a financial expert – a broker – handle your resources. The broker pools your money with other investors’ money and invests in multiple companies on your behalf. ğŸ’†‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ¤

What are the benefits of this? 

1ï¸âƒ£ Investment funds diversify your portfolio. Funds typically invest in dozens of stocks – this means you don’t have to worry as much about risk factors as when you put your investable resources in only a few individual stocks. ğŸ’…

2ï¸âƒ£ By pooling your money in a fund, investors cut their investing expenses. When you buy stocks individually, you’re the one responsible for all transaction costs. In an investment fund, the fund manager takes care of these expenses. ğŸ’‍â™‚ï¸ Furthermore, investing expenses appear less intimidating as assets are typically bought in bulk. ğŸ§º

3ï¸âƒ£ You don’t need to know all the details about investing or make all the decisions — professionals carefully research the market for you. ğŸ§  and invest in the most promising companies on your behalf. 

What are the considerations?

ğŸ‘‰ Unlike when you purchase shares in a company directly, with investment funds, you don’t get any voting rights in the company. This might be particularly important to you if you are choosing to invest in companies based on their sustainability practices.

ğŸ‘‰ As the fund is managed by someone else, you need to be confident that they are investing in companies that align with your visions and values. You therefore need to do some background research before you decide which fund may be right for you.

ğŸ‘‰ An investment fund may have fees and expenses that you should be aware of, as the price you pay to partake in the fund will impact your financial returns.

To understand what diversifying your portfolio through funds means, consider the case of Company X:

Person A buys stock in Company X because A cares about climate change and Company X works particularly with renewable energy. â™»ï¸â˜€ï¸ The next quarter, the company performs poorly, so Person A’s investment drops significantly. 

Person B, on the other hand, invests in an investment fund that owns some stock in Company X as one asset among stocks from multiple other companies. ğŸ‘ğŸ¢ When Company X has a bad quarter, Person B’s investment also declines, but less than that of Person A, since Company X is just one part of the fund’s portfolio (and Person B’s investment!). ğŸ˜‡

Now you know the basics of investment funds. However, there is always more to learn! You can read more about mutual funds and exchange traded funds right here and be the movement – make!mpact ğŸ’•

Before you start investing, it’s important to do your own research, especially for impact investing. If you plan to align your investments to your values or an existing framework (such as ESG or SRI), it’s necessary to know which companies’ align with those values ğŸ™Œ But how exactly do you do that?

This is where non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and non-profit organizations (NPOs) become useful to you as an investor ğŸ’¡ Most likely, you’ve already heard of the likes of WWF, Greenpeace, Oxfam, and UNICEF – the list is endless! 

While we will not focus on the difference between the two types of organizations, we want to emphasize their strengths ğŸ‘¯‍â™€

For example, both types of organizations thrive for social good instead of financial profits. Both are also passionate about their work and try to expose social imbalances, environmental harm next to other local and global grievances ğŸ’ªğŸŒ Many of these organizations specialize in one specific area and are directly involved with projects. 

1ï¸âƒ£ Projects and campaigns

NGOs and NPOs have been in charge of countless remarkable campaigns ğŸ—£ranging from the strengthening of local communities to providing support for victims of violence, advocating for asylum seekers and refugees’ rights, or promoting women’s rights and child protection âš–ï¸ Recently, more and more projects have started focusing on the conservation of nature and combatting climate change.

2ï¸âƒ£ Resources

Next to campaigning, NGOs and NPOs also provide useful resources on their specialized area of focus ğŸ“šğŸ¤“ So why not leverage their extensive reports and knowledge and use it to find companies for your portfolio that acts with responsibility?

Don’t get us wrong – you cannot invest in NGOs or NPOs! You can only support them by donating to their cause or, for example, by buying their merchandise ğŸ’¸ This money is then used by the organizations to fund their campaign work. But as investors, we of course also want to put our money to work and let it grow.

All right - but how do you do that?

For example … You are a new investor and passionate about addressing gender equality ğŸ‘«You start searching different NGOs focusing on gender equality. In their reports you may find that the company you wanted to invest in is treating their employees like ğŸ’©

In the same report, however, the NGO mentioned a competitor for said company which happens to be a role model for the industry – and voilà! You’ve found a company that aligns better with your values and beliefs ğŸ‘

Imagine if everybody would invest in this way! No one would continue to support the bad governance of firm A and would switch to company B ğŸ¥³This shift by investors won’t go by unnoticed by company A and puts pressure on it to change.

All of this is to say that being an informed investor and actively supporting companies that act sustainably gives you a lot of power. So make use of all the research that’s available from NGOs and NPOs, and you’ll be sure to make a lasting impact ğŸŒ ğŸ’

As a first-time investor, you’ve most likely come across the terms sustainable investing, thematic investing, and impact investing. ğŸ’¬ If these words all seem foreign and mysterious to you, don't worry – we’re here to help you untangle the mess!

Generally speaking, sustainable finance is an umbrella term that encompasses the three investment methods mentioned above. â˜‚ï¸ğŸ¤² As you begin investing and start building your own portfolio, you may choose one of these methods, or a combination of them, if you aim to incorporate sustainability in your portfolio. â™»ï¸ They all represent different investment strategies, so, without further ado, let's get into it! 

Sustainable investing ...

is when you explicitly incorporate sustainability measures and metrics (such as ESG criteria) into your search for stocks to invest in. There are two different ways to do so: 1ï¸âƒ£ integration and 2ï¸âƒ£ screening. 

Integration put simply, is when you take a specific ESG metric, such as carbon emissions ğŸ­ğŸ’¨ and try to estimate future impacts in your analysis. The world is moving towards reaching a ‘net zero’ and almost every country and company plan to reduce most of their carbon emissions. ğŸ˜·

One consequence is that companies emitting large amounts of CO2 through their production of goods are likely to be affected by a higher carbon price since companies need to buy CO2 certificates to offset their pollution. ğŸŒ²ğŸŒ³

If companies continue to emit constant CO2 amounts in spite of higher offsetting prices, the cost of offsetting is bound to increase, which will lead to decreasing profits. The company value would depreciate, leading to a lower share price. ğŸ“‰ All in all, implementing such metrics into your analysis can help you better assess risks and, ultimately, increase your return on investments. ğŸ‘

Another way to approach sustainable finance is to do a screening, where one applies filters to create a ‘basket’ of stocks or a specific stock index. These filters are based on your investment preferences, values, and ethics. âš–ï¸ ğŸŒ 

There are different methods of filtering:

ğŸ‘‰ Negative screening is used to exclude ‘bad’ stocks, also called sin stocks, from your further analysis. It should be noted, however, that negative screening can hinder your performance and reduce diversification. 

ğŸ‘‰ With positive screening (also referred to as best-in-class screening ğŸŒŸ), you simply select a sustainability metric and benchmark all companies in a sector. You then proceed with your analysis using only the companies that perform best according to your metric.

ğŸ‘‰ Norms-based screening is used to exclude anything that does not meet certain minimum standards such as ‘ILO’, ‘the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises’ or the ‘UN Global Compact’.

We hope you now have a clearer picture of what sustainable investing is. ğŸ’°ğŸŒ± So let's jump into the next investment method.

Thematic investing ...

is another way to buy shares or other investments that benefit from a certain trend. This trend does not necessarily have to be related to sustainability or social issues. ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸ It can range from hydrogen and electric cars to remote working and meat alternatives. It may also involve higher risk, as investments are concentrated in one industry or sector, potentially leading to increased volatility.

Impact investing ...

is a term that first appeared in 2007. It should be noted that impact investing is not a protected term and different definitions exist. One of the most widely recognized definitions is that of the Global Impact Investing Network (GIIN). ğŸ“– It defines impact investing as investments specifically aimed to address social or environmental challenges (e.g. education, clean energy, and healthcare). ğŸ’“ It can therefore be seen as a subset of thematic investing. Furthermore, impact investing particularly draws upon the concept of the measurability and quantification of impact. 

Whew, that was a lot of information! ğŸ˜… Hopefully we helped you untangle any messy definitions, and you can now distinguish between the different methods. ğŸ¤“ So, let's start making our portfolios sustainable! Join the movement – make an impact!

articles.a_content:
“Can profit and impact be combined?” ğŸ¤”

You may have asked yourself this question many times as an impact investor. But let us reassure you: these doubts are misplaced. The bottom line is that tons of studies have confirmed that sustainable investments do not yield lower returns than their non-sustainable counterparts. ğŸ‰

Impact Investing

‘Impact Investing’, which has been on the rise in recent years, refers to investments that generate a measurable, social and environmental impact alongside a financial return. Sounds nice, right? ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸

Since 2012, this investment strategy has grown at a rate of 107.4% annually. In 2020, sustainable investments account for almost 20% of all assets under management. And this number is only projected to rise in the future. ğŸš€ Millennials, Gen Z, and future generations are expected to continually increase the alignment of their investments with personal values. In a recent Morgan Stanley survey, 95% of millennial investors cited an interest in sustainable investing – and approximately one-third of all investors in their 20s and 30s already seek financial advisors providing value-based investing. ğŸ¤²ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’»

Additionally, macro-economic trends such as a staggering population increase will create bottlenecks in demand for important resources including food, water, and energy. ğŸ˜¨

This means that innovative solutions will be required to tackle resource scarcity, clean sanitation or the provision of clean water. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ”§ğŸ— In turn, sustainable investment opportunities will continue to grow and most likely accelerate, with corporations relying on necessary funding to fulfill their missions. 

Trade-off between profit and impact

Definitions and statistics about impact investing aside, the big question remains: do we have to sacrifice our financial return in order to invest impactfully? And if so, how much? ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

In case these concerns are on your mind – don’t worry! You’re not alone on this. ğŸ‘« In fact, the number one doubt for 79% of individual investors concerning sustainable investments is on such investments’ performance. Yet, let us debunk these fears: to this date, the very vast majority of empirical evidence claims these beliefs to be false. âŒ

ğŸ‘‰ For example, The Royal Bank of Canada analyzed over 50 major studies and concluded that socially responsible investments do not result in lower financial returns. 

ğŸ‘‰ Similarly, researchers from the Wharton Social Impact Initiative investigated 53 impact-investing private equity funds and found that there was no evidence to establish a compromise between maximizing financial returns and impact. 

ğŸ‘‰ Harvard University scholars also found similar positive conclusions, and so did researchers from the University of Hamburg in 2015 when they examined more than 2000 studies. 

The reasoning behind all these studies is quite straightforward: by integrating sustainability factors into the investment process, companies that are expected to perform poorly over time due to engagement in unsustainable activities are eliminated as possible investments. ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ğŸ“‰ In even simpler terms: your investments will be future-proof because the companies in your portfolio will be future-proof!

Long story short â¡ï¸ tear down your fears – impact and financial returns do not oppose each other and you can maximise both objectives at the same time. ğŸ¤

So what are you waiting for? Be the movement – make!mpact! ğŸ’—

Most of us would all agree that gender equality is good – and more than that, necessary! ğŸ‘©  ğŸ¤ ğŸ‘¨ In this sense, it would of course be amazing if our investments supported women. And by the way: if you’re interested in this, you might want to check out our article on ‘Investing in Dignity’ to get a few tips on where to start ğŸ’¡

However, there’s something almost as important as investing in women: getting women to invest ğŸ’¸ 

Did you for example know that, on a global scale, women invest a higher proportion of their income in their local communities than men do? That’s why, as Melinda Gates put it, it’s wise to invest in women, since ‘when we invest in women and girls, we are investing in the people who invest in everyone else.’ â™»ï¸

Some might believe that to get more women to start investing, one should focus on women’s financial literacy or having more women talk to financial advisors. Yet, these conceptions might be a bit outdated. Here’s why ğŸ“£:

Women who invest tend to do so with patience and also take fewer risks. However, this does not mean that they don’t take risks. They just tend to be more prone to spending more time researching a stock before making an investment decision ğŸ¤“ Additionally, studies show that men are more confident in their investing decisions – even sometimes overconfident. So, while men trade 45% more often than women, female investors outperform their male counterparts each year by half a percentage point ğŸ‘¯‍â™€ï¸ğŸ’¸

To summarize, there are two reasons that suggest it is important to get more women investing: 1) they invest a greater proportion of their money in their local communities than men, 2) they tend to make wise investment decisions when they choose to invest ğŸ™‡‍â™€ï¸ So, it is easy to see how we might see more investments with impact if more women invest!

So why don't more women invest? 

Even in parts of the world where men and women juggle household duties equally, it is still mostly women who take responsibility in planning and delegating said tasks. In recent research, it’s been called ‘the mental load’ ğŸ¤¯ meaning that women often end up thinking of more immediate needs such as household duties rather than long-term things such as the financial future of the household ğŸ 

Furthermore, there’s the reality of the gender pay gap. It means that women accumulate less wealth over time than men, and also that they have less money available out of their budget that they can invest on a regular basis. 

What can we do to change this?

The gender pay gap will unfortunately not be closed from one day to the next – but even with the ‘mental load’ that some women carry, there are ways to get started investing as soon as today! ğŸ’°

1ï¸âƒ£ Plan to make investing a habit. You can invest a certain percentage of your income each month or, if your finances are not quite sufficient, even as little as $10 per month. The most important thing is to start researching regularly and make investing a habit ğŸ‘Œ

2ï¸âƒ£ Social trading, or, as its subcategory is called: Copy Trading. This is basically online investing where you copy the habits of a few popular investors. You should still do your own research and make independent decisions, of course, but taking inspiration from what other successful investors are doing is an easy way to spot current trends.

3ï¸âƒ£ If you are a woman who is already investing, tell your friends to join you! Motivating people in your network to slowly get into investing and making it a topic of conversation in your everyday life will introduce you to new ideas and make investing fun ğŸ¤  Moreover, it will empower the women around you to take charge of their financial future and make an impact on the world around them.

So does that then mean that women are better at investing than men? No – in short, no one gender is necessarily definitively better at investing than the other ğŸ˜‡ But knowing that 1) women face more hurdles in getting into the investment game than men and that 2) women tend to invest more impactfully, it is worth thinking about how women can feel empowered to start investing ğŸ’ª

With this in mind, go tell your friends – female or male! – to get started on their investing journey if they’ve not already joined you. Be the movement – make impact ğŸ’“

A big part of sustainable investing is, of course, understanding how to invest and finding the right company to invest in. ğŸ’¼ That’s why, today, we’re introducing you to a few do’s and don’ts in investing that might help you find those investments that both yield a return and match your values!

âœ”ï¸ DO understand what you invest in and do it long-term! 

Knowledge is power! ğŸ§ âš¡ï¸ Just because you’ve heard about an up-and-coming business in an article or from a friend does not mean that you should start investing in said business. Always make sure to do your own research beforehand.

One key element is understanding where the business makes the most money. ğŸ’° For example, do you know Amazon’s main revenue driver? You should also think about the company's future! A company may look interesting now, but will it still make profits in 10 years? â³ Once you feel confident that a stock is both likely to increase in value and also matches your beliefs, feel free to invest away.

ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ DON’T let your emotions interfere!

Investing should be done on a rational basis. As people, we’re emotionally driven, â¤ï¸ and while emotions help us make decisions, they should not play a part in deciding to invest in a company or not. You may be extremely excited about a company, but if it has bad financials, it may face bankruptcy. 

One good example is FOMO (= in the sense of investing). ğŸ¤‘ Many investors tend to sell their stocks as soon as they have made a good return, but, it would probably be more profitable for them to hold on to such good investments even longer! 

FOMO works the other way around, too: Many investors tend to hold on to their bad investments forever instead of selling as soon as their performance deteriorates. ğŸ“‰ Investing in better stocks would then be an option instead.

âœ”ï¸ DO make sure your portfolio is diversified!

Many investors choose to diversify their portfolios since it allows them to minimize the company-specific risk and therefore the overall risk of their portfolio. ğŸ’¼ However, you should not think that simply by buying different assets classes, you will be making your portfolio bulletproof against any downturns.

Holding different stocks may protect you from one company's stock decreasing but not if the whole stock market decreases. Bonds, for example, are a good diversifier if the interest rates go up (bonds value increase, stocks decrease) – but what if there’s a financial crisis? ğŸ¤¯ You can add many more asset classes such as real estate, art, crypto assets, and many more. ğŸ–¼ The risk of a decrease in value of your portfolio will thus minimize (but never be at zero!).

ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ DON’T attempt to time the market!

It sounds like the easiest play: When the stock prices within a certain sector or even for the market in its entirety are low, and you have a good gut feeling about future prospects of a company, you want to buy its stock now before the price increases. Meaning you’ll make a big profit. ğŸ’¸ğŸ˜‡

Yet, you might want to take another moment to think it over! âœ‹ Market trends can be extremely hard to predict and depend on numerous factors such as the emergence of a new technology, a change in the regulatory environment amongst other policy changes. ğŸ“ 

To make things even more complicated, there are unprecedented events that are impossible to forecast. For example, think of Christiano Ronaldo moving his coke bottle out of the picture during a press meeting at the 2020 Euro Football Championships âš½ï¸ – the market value of the Coca-Cola stock decreased by $4 billion!

Historically, the market is likely to increase over time – it’s just a matter of time. â° Up until now, every market index has recovered from its many falls. So make sure to stick to your financial goals! Impact investing is a long-term strategy rather than short-term trading, and that’s why attempting to time the market might be hurtful. ğŸ’”

ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ DON’T excessively check your investments!

Imagine you’ve just bought a new stock from a business you’ve been excited about for a while and finally made a decision to invest in – it’s tempting to check in every couple of minutes to see how it’s doing. ğŸ‘€ Don’t drive yourself crazy and start doubting if the stocks decrease a bit after you bought it, though! You are investing with long-term goals, and your investments are likely to increase in the long run. It’s all about patience! âœŒï¸ Whereas the market might fluctuate, you will see the growth of your investment in the long run.

All in all ... 

Be aware of your own biases, try to follow some of the above advice, and allow yourself to trust in your own analysis and research – that already makes you a better investor! ğŸ¤²ğŸŒ So what are you waiting for? Go find some investments that make an impact on the world and apply them to your financial goals.

Be the movement – make!mpact ğŸ’

In recent years, and especially since 2020, protests for racial justice have risen across the world. âœŠğŸ¿âœŠğŸ½âœŠğŸ¼ A wave of information has been spread along with them: The bottom line being that people of color suffer racism both institutionally and in all aspects of everyday life. You probably won’t be surprised that this the case for finance, as well! ğŸ’°

For example, in the US, people of color pay consistently more in student loans, and white people are approx. 27% more likely to be homeowners than people of color. All of this is to say: Certain financial barriers exist for people of color simply because of their race. âš–ï¸

But how does racial justice even relate to investing? 

While it might seem difficult, there are many ways through which your investments can directly or indirectly support racial justice. So if you’re interested in supporting communities of color through your investments, now’s the time to listen up. ğŸ“£

Here are four different ways to start investing in racial justice:

1ï¸âƒ£ Supporting businesses owned by people of color 

While this of course can also be done by everyday actions such as buying your next vacation read or winter sweater, you can also decide to invest in businesses owned by people of color. ğŸ¦

While executives of the biggest publicly listed companies tend to be white men, you’ll find that companies owned and run by people of color are more likely to be small or midsize. ğŸŒ± In the meantime, smaller companies tend to outperform average large companies in the long run. 

Therefore, if you research thoroughly, you may be able to spot small companies that have promising growth potential and are also run by people of color. ğŸ’ªğŸ’¸ Such an investment would be making an impact!

2ï¸âƒ£ Buying into funds with a racial justice filter

Currently, there are not too many of these on the market. In fact, as of February 2021, there’s only one: the Impact Shares NAACP Minority Empowerment ETF (NACP). ğŸ—‚ It tracks the Morningstar Minority Empowerment Index and focuses on companies that meet the guidelines of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). Some of its top holdings include Apple, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson, Visa, and Disney. ğŸ“Š

Apart from this ETF, you might also want to look into some funds focusing on specific ESG criteria and track how they are doing on racial justice.

3ï¸âƒ£ Supporting businesses that incorporate racial diversity 

Many studies have proven that, from a business management perspective, more diverse teams lead to more creative solutions, and, in the end, more profit for the company. ğŸ¨ğŸ’¡ Investing in diverse companies could therefore be setting yourself up for good returns. 

When doing your research, do however be aware to check for people of color in all levels of leadership positions. ğŸ—³ğŸ‘©ğŸ½‍ğŸ’¼ ‘Diversity’ is sometimes still promoted when people of color are leading only from the very bottom of an organization instead of across it.

4ï¸âƒ£ Recognizing that investments, just like the SDGs, can create a domino effect of change 

Once you trigger one element of impact, more will likely follow. That’s why it’s so important to do your research! ğŸ“š Here’s two examples from Ellevest that you might like to incorporate into your investing knowledge:

ğŸ‘‰ Unhealthy food and beverages: Companies who make their living by selling such products usually spend lots of money on targeting low-income, often non-white communities. ğŸ”ğŸ¥¤ It leads to increased health issues for people of color and has a particular impact on the children in this community.

ğŸ‘‰ Fossil fuels: People of color are more likely to die from climate-change-related conditions such as air pollution. ğŸ­ğŸ˜· The fossil fuels that are released in the supply chain of a product might therefore have a damaging impact on non-white communities.

These two examples basically show that by investing in companies that do not release fossil fuels or companies that support human health, it’s likely that by investing in those companies, you are somehow fighting against racial injustice. âœŠğŸ¾ It’s all one big domino game and if you do your research well, maybe you can target the domino piece that will make multiple others fall. ğŸ¯

And the takeaways? 

Investing for your own financial gain while supporting racial justice is more than possible. And hey! By investing in companies that support racial justice in one way or another, you are letting the market know that you, as a consumer, are interested in promoting diversity, equity, and justice. âš–ï¸ğŸ¤¸‍â™‚ï¸ Both money and information are powerful tools when it comes to investing. We hope that this article has given you a hint or two on how to start investing with impact. ğŸ’¸ğŸŒ±

Alright, peeps! ğŸ¥ We’re about to get a bit technical, but stay with us – after this read, you’ll hopefully be a smarter impact investor than you were before and have an easier time analyzing all those reports and numbers ğŸ¤“ That’s why today we want to talk to you about multiples.

The Basics ğŸ“–

A multiple is a ratio that measures some aspect of how well a company is doing financially and is computed by dividing one number by another.

For example, the so-called Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratio is calculated by dividing the ‘share price’ by the ‘Earnings Per Share’ (EPS). This ratio expresses how much we’re paying for each 1€ of EPS. 

Think about Amazon and eBay – both offer a relatively similar online market platform but vary significantly in their P/E ratio âš–ï¸: 

  • Amazon: 70.75 

  • eBay: 16.7. 

These two companies are therefore trading at values of 70x and 16x of earnings respectively, which signals that Amazon is valued much higher than eBay ğŸ˜²

This already gives us a great impression of how multiples can be used by investors: they act as instruments to compare similar companies in order to spot the most profitable investment opportunities ğŸ˜ğŸ’«

Stocks with very high multiples may be overvalued, just as stocks with very low multiples may represent undervalued stocks and potentially great investment opportunities. 

The multiples to remember ğŸ’¡

There are generally two categories of multiples: 1ï¸âƒ£ Enterprise value (EV) multiples, and 2ï¸âƒ£ Equity multiples. For the first category, under which EV is calculated as Equity + Debt - Cash, the following key multiples exist:

ğŸ‘‰ EV/Revenues

ğŸ‘‰ EV/EBIT (Earnings before Interest and Tax) 

ğŸ‘‰ EV/EBITDA (Earnings before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortisation) 

EV multiples generally have the advantage that the whole capital structure is taken into account. This means that EV multiples are super useful if your chosen company has a very different capital structure from other comparable companies ğŸ¯Just imagine trying to evaluate a company with very little debt if all your comparable companies were drowning in loans ğŸ¥µ

For Equity multiples, which usually have the share price ‘P’ as the numerator, the following multiples are frequently used:

ğŸ‘‰ P/E

ğŸ‘‰ Price-to-Book ratio (P/B) (‘Book’ refers to a company’s book value of all assets)

ğŸ‘‰ Price-to-Sales (P/S)

Bewareâ—ï¸In case any Earnings metric (EBIT, EBITDA) should be negative, switching to Multiples with ‘Sales’ or ‘Revenues’ as the denominator is the way to go – it allows you to avoid negative Multiples ğŸ‰

The Multiples Approach 

Now that we’ve got the basics covered, let’s dive deeper into where else multiples can be applied. Most importantly, they are used as a valuation tool dubbed the ‘Multiples Approach’ (MA), in order to calculate the enterprise or equity value of a specific company ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’»ğŸ’° 

How does that work?

The Multiples Approach is based on the idea that shares of similar companies should also be valued similarly ğŸ™Œ That's why it's also often called ‘comparables analysis’.

The basic idea is that you take an average of a specific multiple for all the companies which are comparable to the one that you are investigating, and then use that multiple to calculate your desired company value ğŸ”¥ But let's go through this step-by-step:

1ï¸âƒ£ Selection of comparables

After choosing which company you want to evaluate, find the most fitting comparable companies. This is super important as these comparables alone are basically used to value the chosen company ğŸ’¡ You should consider that a small, but meaningful group of comparables will yield much better results than a broad industry sample. Key criteria to find comparables are industry classification, geography, size, growth, and profitability ğŸ’¥

For example …

Think of Lufthansa, Germany’s flagship carrier and the largest European airline by revenue: with the majority of operations and flights in Europe, a comparable company should not only be another airline with a similar business model but also one operating primarily within Europe ğŸ›«ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Additionally, comparables should have a similar size to Lufthansa in terms of revenues, and they should follow a similar profitability path.

In this context, AirFrance-KLM and IAG (which comprises the airlines British Airways and Iberia) serve as great comparables ğŸ˜‡ In contrast, low-cost carriers such as EasyJet and Ryanair might be less suitable, due to their low-cost business model which, for the latter, has resulted in margins much higher than Lufthansa’s.

2ï¸âƒ£ Valuation

The first step is to choose a fitting multiple based on the explanations above ğŸ“Š Subsequently, you calculate the average of your chosen multiple over the selection of comparables. Finally, that average is multiplied with the respective denominator metric for your company. 

For example …

Let’s get back to Lufthansa! âœˆï¸ After key competitors have been identified and a specific multiple chosen (e.g. EV/Revenues), this multiple is averaged over all comparables. Then, that average is multiplied with Lufthansa’s revenues from last year. 

And, voilà – you’ve valued your very first company by calculating its enterprise value! ğŸ¤© Not too bad, huh? We hope that this allows you to make some well-informed investment decisions based not just on a company’s sustainability mission but also it’s financials. So go be the movement – make!mpact ğŸ¤²â£ï¸
