In this new series of company spotlights, we’re highlighting specific industries and companies. In today's first edition, we’ll start with Beyond Meat ğŸ¥©ğŸŒ± You may have heard plenty about their burgers, but do you know anything about their footprint, impact or financial situation? No worries, after having read this article you’ll be up to date! ğŸ“…

But why is the meatless industry of relevance? Most will have a straightforward answer to this – it’s better for the environment. And, indeed, livestock ğŸ®ğŸ· is a major contributor to many environmental issues, including greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, soil erosion, extensive use of land, and high water usage. Besides, plant-based meat is healthier and could reduce obesity ğŸ¥¦ The shift towards the meatless industry is also fostered by several scandals, such as working conditions and the ethical treatment of animals.

So, let’s have a look at Beyond Meat, a producer of plant-based meat alternatives founded in the US in 2009 by Ethan Brown ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Having cooperated and sold their products in supermarkets, the company now has several products on the market and partnerships with some of the world’s biggest food chains, including McDonald’s, Taco Bell and many more ğŸ”ğŸŒ® With its current share price of 124 USD, the company is valued at $7.94 billion.

Sustainable Development Goals

Beyond Meat’s mission is to shift people’s meat consumption to more sustainable, plant-based alternatives ğŸ˜‹ğŸ¥— By doing so, the company itself claims to tackle the following four key issues: human health, climate change, constraints on natural resources, and animal welfare.

Four SDGs emerge amongst the most important impact areas for Beyond Meat ğŸ‘‰ SDG 3, 12, 13, and 15. Let’s have a look at each of them individually:

Good Health and Wellbeing

We’ve heard it all before: excessive meat consumption is bad for our health ğŸ¥µ In a recent study conducted at Stanford University, researchers evaluated the impact of replacing animal-based meat with plant-based alternatives such as Beyond Meat. The results are clear: substitution to plant-based alternatives significantly improved participants’ health, as measured by the three categories: 1ï¸âƒ£ cholesterol level, 2ï¸âƒ£ heart disease risk factors, and 3ï¸âƒ£ bodyweight.

Responsible Production and Consumption

Our current diets promote the seemingly infinite growth of meat production and consumption ğŸ“ˆ This is also channeled through media and publicity, which still to date deceive and encourage us into further consumption. Production will only decrease if we as individuals change our behavior substantially, consume in moderation, and thus reduce our meat demand overall ğŸ™Œ This is where Beyond Meat steps in: through their plant-based offerings, they provide us with a sensible alternative for more responsible consumption ğŸ•º

Climate Action

Grazed animals are the largest source of methane emissions – and, so, the consumption of sustainable diets such as those based on vegetables, grains, nuts and seeds, presents important opportunities to reduce GHG emissions ğŸ¥•ğŸ¥œğŸ™‹‍â™€ï¸ A recent study from the University of Michigan has confirmed this viewpoint by conducting a life-cycle analysis of beef vs. plant-based burger patties. Results pointed towards a GHG emission reduction of 90% when substituting beef with the far-more-sustainable pea protein ğŸ‘

Additionally, animal grazing significantly contributes to the world’s deforestation ğŸ˜° since it accounts for 70% of agricultural land. Imagine if we could convert that land back to grassland and forests! It’s a dream that may one day become reality: the above-mentioned study estimates that plant-based patties have 93% less impact on land use than beef patties ğŸŒ³ğŸ™

Life on Land

In the past decades, global biodiversity has gradually decreased ğŸ›â†˜ï¸ By means of animal grazing, the meat industry has indirectly contributed to this. This is because grazing prevents the conservation and revegetation of lands which are considered most effective in slowing biodiversity loss. In this way, companies producing meat alternatives indirectly contribute to slowing biodiversity loss ğŸ¤²ğŸ¯ as animal grazing is avoided entirely.

ESG Risks

So far, Beyond Meat showed a positive impact in many areas – but all that glitters is not gold â›” Let’s have a more detailed drill-down of ESG Risks in accordance with the SASB Materiality Map. It identifies the biggest ESG-related issues which are likely to affect the financials and operations of companies of a specific industry ğŸ—

Environmental risks

Despite significantly reducing GHG emissions in comparison to beef patties, Beyond Meat’s burgers are still packed in plastic and use cardboard, which both require loads of energy and resources (11% of total emissions, 21% of total energy use, 14% of total water use) ğŸ”ŒğŸ’¦ Why not use recycled materials? ğŸ§

Moreover, a sustainable supply chain is much more important than organic farming. True: organic farming limits the use of fertilizers and other chemicals ğŸ§ª But in the case of Beyond Meat, the main ingredient is peas. Sourcing this ingredient in a sustainable way, i.e. without much land destruction or large crop failures, and under good and ethical working conditions ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸŒ¾â˜€ï¸ weighs more than the use of pesticides.

Social risks

Health-related issues have revolved around Beyond Meat’s burgers. Classified as “ultra-processed food” (FAO, Noval Classification Scheme), the burger contains a large number of ingredients and requires a thorough manufacturing process â° A recent study has even discovered that one of the burger’s many ingredients was in fact residual mineral oil â›° 

Another social risk factor is product affordability âš–ï¸ Oftentimes, shifting consumer preferences towards more sustainable solutions such as Beyond Meat depends heavily on the price. And not only are Beyond Meat’s products significantly more expensive than meat (US: meat $2.80/pound vs. Beyond Meat $6.25/pound) – they are also priced higher than the majority of other providers of plant-based food ğŸ’µ

In terms of supply chain management, the sourcing and pricing of pea protein represents the greatest risk and should be researched in more detail before an investment ğŸš¨ For example, the company’s main pea suppliers could be analyzed for labor practices, human rights, corruption, and other contract details.

Governmental risks

The Board of Directors takes a large role in the control process of a company by monitoring the behavior of the executive management ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘€ In order to fulfill this task, the board should be as independent of the management as possible. Whenever the roles of Board Chairperson and CEO are bundled in one person, company supervision is naturally less independent ğŸ˜’

At Beyond Meat, the founder Ethan Brown is NOT the board’s chairperson – however, he still sits on the board ğŸ’¼ And we can all easily envision what kind of power he then holds not only as CEO but also as the founder of the company. Would we dare to disagree with Ethan Brown on important matters if we sat on the Board of Directors? We certainly should! But, in reality, that may be much harder than we think ğŸ˜¬

Beyond Meat also faces transparency risks ğŸ” The rating agency S&P Global measures how transparently each company reports on its operational, environmental and climate change risks. Most recent data from 2018 shows that Beyond Meat scores a 0 (which translates to nothing!), while competitors have disclosure rates of 98% or higher ğŸ¤” Higher disclosure rates do not necessarily translate into ‘more sustainable’, but in Beyond Meat's case, the company does not provide a detailed quantification of its GHG emissions, nor does it publish a comprehensive sustainability report ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

Financials

Now having seen the ESG risks associated with Beyond Meat, it’s time to dive deeper into the financials of the company ğŸ¦

Revenue has been increasing tremendously over the last few years ğŸ’… From only $16 million in 2016, annual revenue increased to $407 million in 2020 and is expected to rise to $2.09 billion in 2025. The Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT) have been negative in all years.

Through its IPO in 2019, Beyond Meat raised $250 million, with which it could easily finance the current cash burn for several years more ğŸ¤ In 2020, the company had a negative Cash Flow of $100 million, a sharp increase of over 36% compared to 2019 ($-73 million). 

Despite negative EBITs and profit margins, the company has consistently outperformed its main competitors (Tyson Foods, The Kroger Co. and Sweet Earth Brand) in terms of share price development ğŸ¤´ The outperformance can also be grasped by looking at some multiples. In both ratios, Price/Sales and EV/Revenue, Beyond Meat exceeds values of 20, whereas main competitors range between 0 and 5 ğŸ’ª Clearly, investors associate high expectations for the future development of Beyond Meat.

Conclusion

Beyond Meat is a great example of a company that creates impact mainly by offering a substitute product to meat ğŸ—ğŸ¥¬ As one of the industry leaders, they are taking a front seat role in battling climate change, health-related issues, and the loss of biodiversity, moving to an overall more responsible production and consumption. This impactful viewpoint is shared by many investors ğŸ’¸ who value the company at a significant premium compared to its key competitors, in spite of negative financial profits in the past â—ï¸ Additional risks such as lower product affordability, close alignment between supervision and management of the company and lack of transparency must be taken into account before an investment.

We’ve previously talked about thematic investing – today, we’ll return to this topic and expand on some focus areas: Cleantech and Climate Tech investing ğŸŒ±

Cleantech, sometimes referred to as Greentech, describes an investment strategy that focuses on supporting only companies that aim to reduce environmental damage ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ­ This can be done by investing in new technologies that seek to reduce resource depletion, improve energy efficiency or promote sustainable use of resources â™»ï¸

Cleantech investing became a widely known concept in the mid-2000s as investments with an environmental focus became fashionable ğŸ’…âœ¨ If you take a closer look at the field, you will find that companies from many different sectors fall within the investment spectrum. These range from energy generation and storage ğŸ“¦ to transport ğŸšš and recycling. Companies that develop specialized solutions for water treatment, cleaner air or more sustainable agriculture also fall under Cleantech. 

A characteristic of Cleantech is that it is often very asset-intensive ğŸ’¼ and relies on large investment tickets, making it more difficult to scale (compared to Climate Tech).

Several trends can be observed within the Cleantech market. Most of them are not necessarily new inventions – take wind energy ğŸª and electric vehicles, for example – but new developments make their use much more affordable ğŸ™Œ Technological advancements are creating new opportunities for further innovation and opening up the market for widespread adoption in large-scale projects and in private homes. The sector is forecast to grow globally to $2.5 trillion by 2022 ğŸ”¥

At a first glance, Climate Tech seems very similar to Cleantech, but it differs in the details ğŸ” Climate Tech is defined by PWC as "a broad set of sectors tackling the challenge of decarbonizing the global economy, with the aim of achieving net-zero emissions before 2050". These sectors include easily scalable companies engaged in carbon capture and storage and better carbon management (improving transparency and accounting) ğŸ’¡ğŸ—„ Famous examples are multi-billion companies like Tesla, Beyond Meat and Nest.

Pale Blue Dot, a specialized Climate Tech Venture Capital fund, distinguishes three different categories within the sector: 

1ï¸âƒ£ Reduce: this category includes all products and technologies that incrementally increase and improve our current status quo (increasing energy efficiency or minimizing waste) ğŸ˜ 

2ï¸âƒ£ Reverse: this is associated with more radical change and focuses on removing carbon from the atmosphere through carbon capture or reforestation ğŸŒ²

3ï¸âƒ£ Preparing for a new world: this is about trying to develop technologies to help deal with the impacts of climate change such as weather disasters ğŸŒª and food and water security. 

A 2020 study by PwC concluded that venture capital investment in Climate Tech will total $16.1 billion in 2019, a 3750% increase since 2013. Compared to investments in Artificial Intelligence, Climate Tech grew three times as fast as AI! ğŸ“ˆ

Both of the above investment themes fit perfectly with our DNA at make!mpact: invest with purpose ğŸ’¸ğŸ’ They create opportunities to change the future and are definitely worth diving deeper into and investing in – both for the impact and the return âœŒï¸

In this article, we’ll be talking about Oatly. Maybe you have not only enjoyed their oat drink in one of your most recent coffees â˜•ï¸ but were also aware of their commitment towards a more sustainable and transparent food industry. Or, did you possibly stumble upon one of their bold marketing campaigns, such as this one? â†˜ï¸

But enough of the fun facts – let’s get to it! ğŸ‘Š

Oatly Group AB was founded in 1994 and is headquartered in Malmö, Sweden ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª It focuses on the development of oat-based products such as milk, yogurt, cream and ice cream ğŸ¦ Since going public in 2021, Oatly is the only other listed company after Beyond Meat to only develop plant-based products.

So, what are the reasons behind the growth of the plant-based food and beverage industry? ğŸ§ğŸŒ± For example, just in the US, plant-based foods were responsible for a sales volume of $7 billion USD! That’s a 43% increase over the last two years ğŸ’° And guess what item contributed the most? You got it – plant-based dairy substitutes, comprising approximately one-third of total sales. 

Now, back to the question at hand: why are people so caught up in oats? ğŸŒ¾ For starters, many people abandon dairy milk due to lactose intolerance. Beyond that, however, one of the key reasons to embrace Oatly’s products lies in the fact that plant-based drinks emit only around one third of the GHGs dairy milk does ğŸ™Œ As for land use, dairy milk requires ten times as much agricultural space as plant-based alternatives!

Sustainable Development Goals

Let’s ask the important question: where does Oatly specifically create the most impact? ğŸ’¥ Oatly itself declares that it “aims to drive a systematic shift toward a sustainable, resilient food system that empowers people to choose solutions that improve their lives and ensure the future of the planet for generations to come.” ğŸŒ As such, the following SDGs emerge as the most important ones for the company: 

SDG 2: Zero hunger ğŸœ

Oatly is cooperating with NGOs and research bodies to continually improve sustainable farming methods. Additionally, since 87% of total purchase volumes trace back to oats, Oatly relies to a large extent on oat farmers ğŸ‘©‍ğŸŒ¾ To develop sustainable and long-term supplier relationships, Oatly is only cooperating with oat farmers who have previously passed a thorough evaluation ğŸ” Among other factors, suppliers have to prove that they are socially sustainable (e.g. no corruption, high safety regulations) and environmentally sustainable ğŸƒ (e.g. no usage of growth regulators or glyphosate, certified production methods). 

SDG 3: Good Health and Well-being ğŸ‘©‍âš•ï¸

Oatly particularly claims to help achieve target 3.4, relating to the reduction in the number of deaths caused by non-communicable diseases (e.g. heart attacks, diabetes) ğŸ’” Among others, Oatly’s products contain less saturated fat than dairy milk ğŸ¥› This type of fat is, on average, overconsumed and associated with a higher risk of non-communicable diseases. In contrast, fiber ğŸŒ¾ which is underconsumed compared to its recommended dose, is included in Oatly’s products to a larger extent than in dairy milk. 

SDG 8: Decent work and economic growth ğŸ“ˆ

Oatly is committed to creating equal-pay employment âš–ï¸, safe working conditions and established worker rights. As the company keeps growing into the US and Asia, Oatly globally implements its internal Code of Conduct in an attempt to create equal conditions for ALL employees ğŸ’– In terms of gender equality, male and female employees both comprise around half of the total employees AND team management positions. 

SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production ğŸ—

By advocating for healthier, more sustainable diets through its role as an external communicator, Oatly is particularly contributing towards target 12.8. The company plays a public role in media with several awareness-raising ads ğŸ“° and appearances at panel discussions, but also through interaction with governments, as demonstrated by the “German Petition” âœŠ This petition was Oatly’s campaign to make climate footprint declarations mandatory for companies in Germany – through which it gathered more than 50,000 signatures ğŸ¥³

SDG 13: Climate Change ğŸŒğŸ¥µ

Climate change is probably Oatly’s biggest impact area. Most importantly, a life cycle analysis conducted in 2013 concluded that by substituting dairy milk with an oat-based drink, GHG emissions, land use and energy consumption would be reduced by 80%, 79% and 60%, respectively ğŸŒŸDespite the fact that this study would have yielded less extreme numbers if the dairy farms in question had been organic, it appears that Oatly still has a significant impact within SDG 13. 

Additionally, one of Oatly’s major achievements is the precise quantification of the climate footprints of 132 products ğŸ‘£ğŸ’š Overall, the company has demanded that the entire food industry be more transparent about their products’ footprint. With all these efforts, the company is a key impactor towards achieving target 13.3 of increasing knowledge and capacity to better cope with climate change ğŸ§ 

ESG risks

The E

Oatly itself has come to a very crucial realisation: quickly and flexibly adapting to sky-rocketing demand may come at the expense of environmental impact ğŸ˜³ For example, the single largest carbon-driver for the company was transportation ğŸš› And, in recently entering the Asian market, the company has thus far relied on transporting products solely via aircraft. As a consequence, despite Asia comprising only a margin of total revenues, the distribution to the continent accounted for 52% of Oatly’s total CO2 emitted through transportation âœˆï¸ğŸ’¨

Similarly, the proportion of renewable energy used went down from 62% in 2019 to 49% in 2020, resulting in a 35% increase in climate impact from energy usage ğŸ˜’ One of the main drivers behind this change was that new production plants in the Netherlands and the United States run on fossil fuels ğŸ­ 

The S

Currently, social risks are limited. You could, however, point out that future emphasis should be on corruption, or safe working conditions, as Oatly is expanding further into less developed countries outside of Europe and North America ğŸŒ

The G

There are quite a few risks in this category, so, for overview, we will split them up into a few key issues: 

Transparency 

For starters, there are not many companies in the food and beverage industry that report as thoroughly on the carbon footprint of their products as Oatly does ğŸ“

However, more reporting does not ALWAYS mean more transparency. For example, as pointed out in a recent report from investment management firm Spruce Point Capital Management, Oatly allegedly hides the fact that oat drink has substantially higher water usage ğŸš° than dairy milk by simply cherry-picking the metrics that paint the most rosy picture ğŸ˜Ÿ

Accounting

The same report alludes to serious accounting issues at Oatly ğŸ§® Most importantly, revenues are claimed to be overstated, as there is a noticeable deviation between the historical growth in revenues and accounts receivables. On top of that, the gross margin calculation of Oatly does not include outbound shipping and handling costs ğŸ— Both factors would decrease the margin, particularly considering that outbound shipping costs are currently increasing with Oatly’s expansion into Asia â†—ï¸

Ownership

In 2020, Oatly sold a $200m stake to the private equity firm Blackstone ğŸ—„ While there is nothing wrong with that per se, the ownership transfer is among the most consequential governance-related risks for Oatly. Why? ğŸ¤”

Blackstone fundamentally violates many of the values that Oatly’s key consumers stand for and which Oatly is marketing itself towards ğŸ’£ For example, Blackstone previously held investments in a Brazilian infrastructure company linked to the deforestation of the Amazonian rainforest ğŸŒ³ğŸ•³ğŸ§¹ Blackstone’s co-founder has also donated towards the political campaigns of Donald Trump and Mitch McConnell, both frequently accused of fraudulent and corrupt behaviour.

Financials

Oatly’s financials have been characterised by red numbers over the previous years ğŸ“• In fact, the “history of losses and inability to achieve or sustain profitability” has been cited as the company’s number one business risk by Oatly itself â—ï¸ In 2020, despite an impressive 106.5% revenue growth and the emergence as the top oat-product brand in Europe, North America and Asia, total expenses increased significantly, resulting in a negative EBIT and profit margin ğŸ˜¬ 

Nevertheless, Oatly is outperforming all its competitors with an extremely high valuation ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸ A multiple comparison yields multiples exceeding values of 20 while competitors score values below 5. Where does this come from? As Spruce Point puts it, investors are tempted by the industry outlook for plant-based products, Oatly’s revenue growth and its commitment towards sustainability â™»ï¸ However, possible investors may want to be careful, as the plant-based milk-substitute market is becoming increasingly more competitive with low entry barriers and high dependency on certain raw materials such as oats and soy ğŸ’ª 

Conclusion

Oatly is not only a world leader in the plant drink market, it also contributes to a more sustainable and healthy world ğŸ‘ Specifically, it increases transparency in the food industry, has lower GHG emissions compared to the dairy counterpart products, contributes towards sustainable agriculture and actively engages in the public debate ğŸ—£ Despite a history of losses, an increasingly competitive market and substantial governance-related risks, the company is growing impressively and is valued at a premium compared to competitors ğŸ˜

If you believe, as we do, that the best way to initiate sustainable change is to make an impact together ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ‘§‍ğŸ‘¦ – then you must have heard of crowdfunding! But are you familiar with all the different types of crowdfunding that are out there? No worries, we’ve got you on this one! ğŸ’ª

Crowdfunding: what is it and how does it work?

Crowdfunding is a way of collectively sourcing capital, mainly for startups and projects, but also for more developed companies. Through many small contributions, it allows for financing means outside institutional circuits ğŸ¦ and that’s why it’s a popular choice for funding up-and-coming projects.

The operation of crowdfunding is quite simple and based on an online platform ğŸ–¥ that connects the fundraisers to the crowd ğŸ’‘ It’s also here that you’ll find all the information you need to evaluate the project and learn what your financial support will go towards.

Good to know ğŸ§: crowdfunding platforms usually charge fundraisers a fee ğŸ’° in return for the security and visibility that their platforms provide. Often, crowdfunding is also based on an all-or-nothing funding model. This means that you either achieve your goals and receive your crowdfunded means ğŸ‰ or that everyone gets their money back ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

And now’s when things get exciting! You’re about to become a connoisseur of all types of crowdfunding ğŸ† 

What are the main types of crowdfunding?

1) Crowdlending

Crowdlending is similar to a standard bank loan ğŸ¤ğŸ’° There are two main distinctions to be made: 1) the peer-to-peer lending, which is basically between individuals and, 2), crowdlending for companies. There are different financial instruments suited for different needs, and can be subdivided into three main subcategories: 

1ï¸âƒ£ Interest-bearing loans which means the money you loan will be repaid over a defined term and you will earn a return through the interest ğŸ’¸ paid on the loan.

2ï¸âƒ£ Interest-free loans which are the same as 1ï¸âƒ£ but without interest.

3ï¸âƒ£ Mini-bonds are a kind of debt-securities suited for companies only ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’¼ It is similar to a normal loan, but it represents a debt issued by companies. In practice, the debt is in the form of a promissory note, bearer note or a bond and can sometimes be traded on public markets ğŸ›’

2) Equity crowdfunding

The investment takes the form of an equity stake in the company ğŸ—‚ And it can be: 

1ï¸âƒ£ In capital (then you are remunerated in the form of dividends or capital gains from the sale of shares) ğŸ’µ

2ï¸âƒ£ In bonds (then your remuneration takes the form of interest) ğŸ“ˆ

3ï¸âƒ£ In return for royalties (and your remuneration takes the form of commissions on turnover) ğŸ…

3) Rewards-based crowdfunding

This crowdfunding model allows the project creator to keep full ownership. The model is based on the individuals' contributions to a project or business in return for a non-financial reward, such as goods or services ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’»

4) Donation-based crowdfunding

Donation-based crowdfunding rests on the principle of giving without compensation. Funds are raised through donations or sponsorships and used towards charitable projects run by individuals or organisations ğŸ¤²ğŸ’¸

5) Profit-sharing 

This new kind of crowdfunding built around revenue-sharing contracts may serve the interests of both businesses and investors. It’s based on sharing the future profits of enterprises or revenues with the crowd in exchange for immediate funding ğŸ’¹

6) Hybrid models

Finally, this form of crowdfunding offers businesses the opportunity to combine different elements of crowdfunding models ğŸ¤¹‍â™‚ï¸ – for example, one could mix equity and rewards-based crowdfunding.

Are there risks to crowdfunding? ğŸ¤”

There are probably as many risks to crowdfunding as there are types of crowdfunding. And you should always be aware of these risks – they’re part of the investment game ğŸ‘» But clearly risks in crowdfunding are higher than in the stock market (no secondary market, no liquidity, less regulation, no track record) ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

Also you can be exposed, for example, to scammers who set up attractive projects to dupe naive or first-time investors ğŸ˜ˆ Or, management of the invested business or project may have difficulty scaling it which in turn leads to capital erosion rather than wealth creation ğŸ¥º

However, this should not keep you from investing via crowdfunding â—ï¸ There might still be a lot of potential for investing in impactful projects. For example, you might find a great, transparent and believable crowdfunding campaign wherein the gains go towards a business that supports the education of women for the tech industry ğŸ‘¾ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’» In the end, this might speak enough to your values to dare investing in the early game via crowdfunding.

So, as always: beware of risks but don’t be afraid to invest where you think you can make an impact ğŸ’˜

Over the last decade and, in particular, throughout the pandemic ğŸ˜·, we witnessed an acceleration in sustainable investments. In the first quarter of 2021, European sustainable funds attracted 51% of all investment fund inflows in Europe! Additionally, the financial services company MSCI has seen the number of their ESG-related Equity ETFs increase from 12 in 2014 to an incredible 233 in 2020 ğŸ¥³

Sounds great, right?! Not entirely. Naturally, the increased popularity has led to fears of a potential ESG bubble ğŸˆğŸ’¥ The (probably) most famous advocate of such a bubble is Eiji Hirano, the former head of the world’s largest pension fund, Japan’s Government Pension Investment Fund. 

In a bubble, an entire industry is overvalued with high prices due to sky-rocketing demand ğŸš€ and highly-concentrated capital. Since their financial outlooks do not support such high stock prices, the companies’ valuations would be unjustified âš–ï¸ It is implied that this bubble will eventually burst, resulting in a sharp devaluation of the overheated market ğŸ“‰ To sum it up with the words of Nobel laureate Eugene Farma: a bubble is an “irrational strong price increase that implies a predictable strong decline”.

Why we will likely not see an ESG bubble âœ…

Are fears of an ESG bubble justified? The short answer: not really ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸ While some specific stocks seem overvalued, the entire industry is certainly not! 

First of all, there is not nearly a sufficient amount of capital in ESG and sustainable investments to tackle the grand challenges of our time â° Thus far, ESG mutual funds and ETF assets globally amount to $4.5 trillion. While this may sound like a lot, the UN expects that, for the transition towards a low-carbon and resilient economy, investments of at least $60 trillion before 2050 are required ğŸ˜²

Accordingly, Larry Fink, the CEO of the world’s largest asset management firm, BlackRock, labels the ESG trend as a lasting “tectonic shift”, rather than a temporary bubble ğŸ‘Œ Furthermore, a recent study conducted by Core Data Insights concluded that ESG is “clearly a megatrend that is here to stay” ğŸ† The majority of participants of the study believed that ALL funds will be incorporating ESG factors within the next five years. 

Secondly, a bubble is argued to be naturally prevented by the current ambiguity revolving around ESG. For example, a fund may label itself as ‘ESG’, ‘green’ or ‘sustainable’ by simply avoiding the ‘worst-in-class’ companies ğŸ˜’, a process called negative screening. This, however, is only one approach to sustainable investing. Alternatively, funds could actively analyse portfolio companies in depth based on custom and specific ESG criteria ğŸ’¼ğŸŒ± Or, they could act as passive ESG funds, simply adjusting weightings based on publicly available ESG scores. 

Either way, not only is there a variety of methods on how to set up an ESG fund, there also exist various ESG criteria ğŸ“‹ Overall, this ambiguity avoids a concentration of capital and, in turn, a bubble, as different ESG funds include different companiesğŸ¬ğŸ« 

The numbers

The most well-known ESG indices have for long been valued similarly to the broad market, a trend unaffected by the global COVID-19 pandemic. For illustration, the following graph shows various ESG and SRI indices developed by MSCI ğŸ“Š They are compared against the benchmark ‘MSCI All Country World Index (ACWI)’, which is the broadest index MSCI offers with exposure to companies from all around the globe, covering both developed and emerging countries ğŸŒ

(Source)

The results seem obvious: there are, to date, no signs of an ESG bubble, as all portrayed ESG indices move in line with the benchmark ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’» Accordingly, ESG indices typically yield no P/E ratios that exhibit signs of overvaluation. 

There are only a handful of stocks from select industries that do appear overvalued ğŸ’° – however, they do not affect the valuations of their respective ETFs noticeably. The most ‘bubbly’ companies to date emerge from the renewable energy, electric vehicle, and waste- and water management industries ğŸš—â™»ï¸ These are the companies most at risk of being incapable of delivering the financial returns that their valuations suggest. For example, a mini bubble recently burst for the Danish energy company Ørsted ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡° who suffered from a significant share price drop after a sharp rise and all-time peak in January 2021 with a P/E ratio above 50!

So, what should we do?

First and foremost, we should be aware! ğŸ§ That is, aware of specific industries and companies which may be overheated due to public interest ğŸ•µï¸‍â™€ï¸ğŸ”¥ Here, a multiple comparison may come in handy to quickly understand how overvalued certain assets are. 

The current narrow focus on only a few industries also represents a great opportunity for investors, since certain industries have thus far been neglected ğŸ‘€ For example, the buildings and construction industry is a major energy-consuming sector and its capital-backed transformation could contribute significantly to lower GHG emissions ğŸ—ğŸŒ† 

We also have to be aware of the growing trend of greenwashing! ğŸ˜³ With surging ESG demand, existing funds have rebranded themselves as ESG funds without changing their investment strategies. Similarly, many newly-established funds often simply label themselves ‘ESG’ or ‘green’ without action or further ado ğŸ˜¡ As a result, ESG-labeled funds and their non-ESG counterparts tend to have the identical companies as largest holdings, which raises questions as to how thoroughly and entirely ESG factors have actually been accounted for ğŸ¤”

Overall, investors like us should understand ESG as an analysis tool and not simply a “name tag” for marketing purposes. That way, we can make great investments into companies which actually provide the change we need ğŸ’ªğŸ’–

At this point, the world has been through multiple political top meetings in order to figure out how to solve the climate crisis ğŸŒğŸ”¥ The result has, so far, mostly been states’ voluntary signing of the Paris Agreement from 2015, so the question from environmental movements fronted by the likes of Greta Thunberg is now: are politicians too slow in creating change? ğŸ¤”

Perhaps they are! Nevertheless, it matters when new compacts on climate change are agreed upon ğŸ— In latest news, the EU has renewed its goals for a greener Europe by 2050 by significantly tightening its benchmarks and speeding up the transitional process ğŸŒŸ For example, the Green Deal declares that the EU should be the world’s first climate neutral continent by 2050, and that it pledges to cut its greenhouse gasses emissions by 55% by 2030 compared to the levels of 1990.

Of course, all this may have a few implications for you as an investor ğŸ’¸ So let’s get into the deets of the new EU Green Deal!

1) Cars ğŸš˜

Here’s a big fact for you: from 2035, all new cars in the EU will have to be zero-emission ğŸŒ«ğŸš« This means a big change for the automobile industry – but seeing that 12% of the EU’s carbon emissions are directly traceable to cars, such a change might also be necessary ğŸ‘Š

Some heavy-lifters in the industry have already committed to a future that follows the EU’s regulations. For example, car brand Volkswagen expects 70% of its car sales to be electric by 2030, while Audi will only launch electric car models from 2026 and gradually phase-out their combustion engine until 2033 ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ªğŸ”‹

2) Energy efficiency ğŸ”Œâš¡ï¸

It’s now been announced that 40% of the EU’s energy is planned to be derived from renewable energy by 2030 ğŸŒ¬ instead of the 32% that was previously the goal. More efficient use of energy is also being promoted across all sectors. For example, governments will have to renovate 3% of public buildings each year to accommodate energy efficiency, and all buildings in the EU by 2030 should be using 49% renewable energy â™»ï¸

Another thing to be aware of is the Emissions Trading System. This is the part of the Green Deal that basically forces businesses across different sectors to cut down their emission of greenhouse gasses faster than previously planned â° However, moving at a pace faster than planned might come at a price for consumers: for example, energy bills are believed to soar as a result of the new regulations ğŸ’¥

The EU has set up a social fund to ensure that low-income families and individuals aren’t put at risk from these changes ğŸ¤² ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ‘§‍ğŸ‘¦ Yet, we can’t be sure that the fund will be big enough to ensure that furthered inequality, or worse, ‘energy poverty’, doesn’t arise as a result of the transition towards a greener EU. 

3) Aviation and shipping ğŸ›©

This time around with the Green Deal, there are no excuses nor exceptions ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ That’s why both the aviation and shipping industries are expected to be hit hard by the new regulations. For the first time, the shipping industry is being included in the Emissions Trading System, which with its significantly higher carbon prices will force the industry to think of greener supply chains ğŸš¢ â˜˜ï¸ The airline industry will also have to commit to a greener future, since no plane will be allowed to depart from an EU airport without blended, more sustainable fuel in its tank â›½

4) Reforestation ğŸŒ³

Finally, the EU is well-aware that going green isn’t just about reducing emissions, but also about managing the carbon that’s already there ğŸ¤ The solution? Guarding forests and planting many more trees!

It’s basically creating natural carbon ‘sinks’, which are now targeted to absorb 310 megatons of carbon every year instead of the 230 that was previously the goal ğŸ’

But will these changes actually be felt? ğŸ¤¨

Most likely, if you’re an EU citizen ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º you’ll be able to feel small changes in your everyday life: your airplane tickets might become more expensive, and so may your energy bills. Within a few years, you’ll probably also feel a change in infrastructure that supports more electric cars around the European highways and makes travelling by rail faster ğŸ›£ ğŸš

Even if you’re not an EU citizen, the new EU Green Deal might affect your local trade patterns or policies â—ï¸ For example, the EU Emissions Trading System ensures that the EU market isn’t undercut by foreign import of materials such as aluminium, steel, cement, and fertilizer coming in from countries such as Norway, China, and Russia. It’s also a well-known fact that the EU is a force to be reckoned with when it comes to regulations and international law ğŸ‘©‍âš–ï¸âœ¨ So: even if the Green Deal only concerns the EU, it might also push some agendas abroad.

So, what does the Green Deal mean in the here and now? ğŸ‘€

Transforming the EU to a green EU will be costly ğŸ˜’ But, with research and consideration for the above goals and its effects on the companies within the most affected industries, you might be able to target not just where you can make an impact, but also where you can make a profit! ğŸ’ğŸ’° 

Remember that we’re lucky to know the EU’s targets years ahead of when they’re supposed to be lived up to by the sectors they affect! ğŸ— If you invest smart, early and for the long-term, you might then see good returns within the coming years.

From here, the rest is up to you! Be the movement – make!mpact ğŸ™

You might have heard the word ‘dividends’ thrown around in finance-themed films, TV shows or in newspapers ğŸ“º ğŸ¤‘ That’s why, today, we’ve decided to introduce you to this concept to you in a short and sweet article!

What is a dividend?

A dividend is a way for a corporation to distribute its profits to its shareholders. In reality, there’s a lot more to the concept, but the principle stays the same ğŸ‘¯‍â™‚ï¸ So we can consider it as the income that remunerates the investment you make in a company ğŸ¤  Basically, this income can be defined as: 

1ï¸âƒ£ A residual income, because it is only distributed to shareholders once all other partners in the company have been paid ğŸ¤ğŸ’¼

2ï¸âƒ£ A random income, because it cannot be predicted with precision, as it depends on the current economic and social circumstances and the company's performance ğŸ¤·

So, how does it work?

In all cases, the amount of the dividend is proposed by the board of directors ğŸ‘©‍âš–ï¸ and voted through at the general meeting of shareholders. 

The resulting amount is generally based on three parameters:

1ï¸âƒ£ The level of profits made by the company: Indeed, the dividend is most often taken from the company’s profits ğŸ’¸ And, of course, the greater the profits, the more generous the company can be with their dividends (all other things being equal).

2ï¸âƒ£ The future investments to be undertaken: As we’ve just seen, the cash flow available for dividends is supposed to have already covered the company's investments. However, in the case of major projects, shareholders may decide during the general meeting of shareholders to temporarily defer the distribution of dividends ğŸ™…

3ï¸âƒ£ Shareholders’ expectations: Shareholders may voluntarily forgo their expected immediate dividend’s income in hopes of higher future income ğŸ¤ Similarly, in the absence of interesting projects, they may decide to distribute the entire year's profit and even, as a special dividend, draw on the spare reserves already built up.

For example ….

Let’s suppose that you invest in a company that makes the most incredible, magnificent, delicious, and sustainable cakes: Cake!mpact ğŸ‚

Well, now you buy 100 shares of your favorite cake company for $10 each ğŸ° So you’ve invested $1,000. And, each share pays a $1 annual dividend (which is a really nice dividend). So, after the course of a year, you would receive $100 in dividend payments. That works out to a 10% dividend yield – giving you an extra slice of that lovely cake that you bought in for ğŸ‚ğŸ° Nice! ğŸ˜‹

Now, what can you do with this newly earned money? ğŸš€ Here’s a few common options:

ğŸ‘‰ Reinvest them to buy more shares of the company.

ğŸ‘‰ Buy stock in a different company.

ğŸ‘‰ Save the money.

ğŸ‘‰ Spend the money (for example use it to buy a takeaway coffee to have alongside your favorite cake â˜•ï¸)

Btw – here's some tools to analyse a company’s dividend policy!

Finally, there are three main indicators that will allow you to analyse the dividend policy of a company:

The payout ratio: This refers to the portion of net income distributed as a dividend. So, if a company pays $0.25 per share dividend and earns $1 per share in net income, the payout ratio is 25%. Generally, the lower the payout ratio, the more durable a dividend should be ğŸ¤˜

The DPS (Dividend Per Share): As the name suggests, the DPS indicates the dividends issued by the company for every outstanding share ğŸ˜‡ 

The dividend yield: This is measured by dividing the dividend per share by the price per share. Expressed in percentages to simplify the comparison over time and performance in relation to other shares ğŸ“ˆâ³, it's a good tool to manage your share portfolio. 

Now that you’ve learned more about a concept as positive as dividends, there’s no reason for you to not get started investing. There’s money to get in return and an impact to leave behind. So be the movement – make!mpact ğŸ¤—ğŸŒ

More than 16,000 bikes in 71 cities is the size of the fleet of the Danish bike-sharing company Donkey Republic ğŸš´‍â™€ï¸ It was established in 2014 by the current CEO, Erdem Ovacik, and co-founders Alexander Frederiksen, Rune Kokholm and Jens Frandsen. After only seven years, the company went public on May 25th 2021 ğŸ˜²

Donkey Republic owns 13,420+ bikes across 15 cities. The self-owned bike operations are categorized as a Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) business ğŸ’¼ Aside from operating its own hubs, Donkey Republic also licenses out its platform and app under Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) to partners ğŸ¤ Currently, the companies’ partners have deployed more than 3,100 bikes in over 60 countries. In order for partners to use the platform, they pay monthly fees to Donkey Republic ğŸ’µ 

FYI: Donkey Republic’s main revenue driver is the MaaS operations, accounting for 80% of total revenue. It’s forecasted annual growth of 15-20% per year, translating into 45-60 thousand additional bikes introduced in their fleet each year ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸

What’s the relevance of the mobility-sharing industry?

In short: it taps into megatrends such as the sharing economy, urbanization and sustainability. Here, Donkey Republic envisions to make city life better with affordable and responsible bike-sharing and is supported by public funding ğŸ¤²ğŸ’° Furthermore, the EU aims to achieve a reduction of 90% of carbon emissions from the transport sector by 2050. Special emphasis is put on developments in cities ğŸŒ†ğŸš• where air pollution is felt the most. Bikes can play a big role in achieving this goal!

Sustainable Development Goals

According to the Investors Memorandum filed for Donkey Republic’s IPO, bike-sharing can be used to impact and improve the following SDGs:

 

SDG 3: Good health and Well-Being ğŸƒ‍â™€ï¸

The EU’s new strategy entails a growth in bike infrastructure, ultimately reducing the number of traffic deaths (SDG Target 3.6). Designated bike lanes not only minimize individual car traffic in cities, but banning or reducing cars in cities will most likely also make riding a bike much more attractive ğŸš² ğŸ† Bike-sharing companies like Donkey Republic will benefit from this development. 

The WHO also estimates that, every year, around 7 million people die from air pollution and that 9 out of 10 people breathe air exceeding recommended contamination levels ğŸ˜· Through cycling, the air quality can be improved, reducing urban air pollution and the number of deaths and illness from hazardous air! ğŸƒ 

There are numerous individual health benefits from cycling, ranging from improving mental well-being to weight loss, or reduced risk of cancer or heart illnesses ğŸ˜„ The European Cyclists' Federation estimates that cycling in its 28 member states is capable of preventing 18,100 premature deaths.

SDG 11: Sustainable cities and communities

In 2018, more than 55% of the world’s population already lived in large cities ğŸŒ‰ This is forecasted to increase to 68% in 2050. By the same token, cities also account for 70% of carbon emissions ğŸ˜Ÿ SDG Target 11.2 seeks to provide access to safe, affordable and sustainable transport systems for all by 2030 – can you think of any concept more suitable than bike-sharing? â™»ï¸

SDG 13: Climate action

Climate action more or less speaks for itself – if we want to keep global warming below 1.5°C (we have to!), we need to cut carbon emissions ğŸ­ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ A privately-owned, combustion engine-powered vehicle produces 162 grammes of CO2 per passenger kilometre (pkm), versus a privately-owned bike 17 g/pkm, or a shared bike which releases 58 g/pkm â—ï¸This stands in stark contrast to the 276 g/pkm emitted from a shared combustion engine-powered car. 

Generally speaking, privately-owned bikes are more resource-saving due to their much longer expected lifetime, with private bikes being kept for 5.6 years vs shared ones for 1.9 years â³ In addition to a shorter life-time, the operational services (e.g. the bicycles’ distribution by van) have a big impact on CO2 emissions ğŸ˜³ However, it may not be feasible or practical for everybody to own a bike of their own, and thus bike sharing becomes ideal for social reasons ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸

ESG overview

Environmental factors

The impact is quantified for the city of Copenhagen and is amounting to €1.1 in congestion savings, 434 grams of CO2 saved and €4.3 in health benefits per trip ğŸ¤© These calculations are based on an average length of 3 km per trip.

However, once the bikes are slightly damaged or abandoned by a bankrupt company, the bikes pile up in so-called bike graveyards â˜ ï¸ and create huge amounts of garbage. Furthermore, the bikes become electronic waste ğŸ“±ğŸ—‘ Even normal, non-motorized bikeshare bikes contain hazardous lithium-ion batteries and toxic circuit boards which need a different form of recycling than normal metal ğŸ”‹ So, as green and sustainable as the business model seems, companies like Donkey Republic produce large amounts of garbage and need to ‘establish responsible end-of-life policies’. 

Social factors

There are no major red flags in terms of social risks for Donkey Republic, but there are some considerations that could be addressed by bike-sharing companies in general: one example being transport affordability ğŸš¨ Bike sharing is cheaper than owning a car, but there are still many citizens who are unbanked or cannot afford to pay $1 per ride ğŸ˜• Special city programmes (such as $5 annual passes for low-income households) allow everyone to benefit from the network, minimising discrepancies in wealth and ownership of bicycles. Another solution could be to integrate the bikes into public transport! ğŸŒ

In terms of service area, it's up to the bicycle companies where to place docking stations or where to expand their service area. Some low-income areas could simply be excluded. In San Francisco, for example, at least 20% of docking stations must be in these low-income communities ğŸ‘Œ Donkey Republic also plans to expand into cities of different tier-level cities and not just focus on the main cities.

Governance factors

Donkey Republic allows individual entrepreneurs and companies to make use of its brand and establish their own bike-sharing hubs in their preferred locations. Depending on the individual contracts, Donkey Republic often supports investments and takes over the marketing in order to keep a unified brand ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’»ğŸ’¸ These costs are also split. Nonetheless, the contracts allow for flexibility and opportunities for co-branding in specific cases.

Furthermore, the board consists of 6 members, out of which only two are independent ğŸ˜³ The other four members are shareholders of the firm. One can say that this is not an independent board and could potentially lead to biased controlling in favor of their investments ğŸ¤”

In terms of transparency, the company, in addition to the Investors Memo, provides a spreadsheet with more detailed calculations and sources to provide greater transparency on how impact and savings are calculated ğŸ”

Financials

As Donkey Republic is still a young company ğŸ‘¶ there is no extensive financial information available about the enterprise yet. Clearly, the firm is building and expanding its operations and is not making a profit yet ğŸ—ƒ The EBIT amounted to DKK -23,740 in 2020.

However, the company forecasts to be profitable by 2024, with a turnover between DKK 185-225 million and a profit margin between 5-10% ğŸ“ˆâœ¨ To achieve this target, Donkey Republic plans to expand into what they label Tier 2 (200 thousand to 1 million inhabitants) and Tier 3 (30 thousand to 200 thousand inhabitants) cities ğŸ—º This expansion is supported by a high share of public funding.

Additionally, the lifting of restrictions in the wake of COVID-19 and the increasingly vaccinated population will allow more tourists to visit the cities in which Donkey Republic operates, driving up revenues ğŸ¤‘ While revenues in 2020 decreased to DKK 21.6 million from DKK 33.4 million in 2019, the figures still indicate a healthy, loyal and primarily local customer base. Pre-pandemic, Donkey Republic already managed to run its MaaS operations in its established cities profitably ğŸ’ª

In 2024, Donkey Republic expects to expand its bike fleet to more than 53,000 bikes and e-bikes. As mentioned, this will represent a growth rate of 15-20%, which is higher than the average market growth of 14%, according to statistics ğŸ“Š Public funding paid by municipalities to set-up a bike-sharing solution accounts for 55% of sales, which is quite significant! 

With a deal win-rate of 59% from 2018 to 2020, the company has a solid value proposition for cities ğŸ‘ğŸ™ Its close cooperation with cities and significant market experience puts it ahead of some competitors, including e-scooter providers that are also entering the bike-sharing market ğŸ˜

The company plans to use the DKK 110 million in capital raised from its IPO for business development (15%), software development (25%), hardware development (10%) and fleet expansion (30%), and will keep what they call a "war chest for blockbuster deals" of about 20% ğŸ‘›ğŸ’°

In terms of valuation, green and sustainable companies often benefit from a premium (higher stock price than intrinsic value), just like Donkey Republic. There are not many listed bike-sharing companies, which makes an industry comparison considerably difficult ğŸ˜¬ The Price-to-Sales multiple is 8.2 and the Enterprise Value-to-Sales multiple is 4.6. The management estimated 2024 EV-to-Sales multiple to be 0.8, which is slightly lower than its United States-based competitor Helbiz' multiple of 0.9 âš–ï¸ With a current market cap of €25 million, the company trades higher than its pre-money valuation of €17.3 million.

Conclusion

All right, to sum up all of this information: Donkey Republic definitely serves current demands and trends with its sustainable solution to affordable transport âœ… The business model with a focus on profitable growth instead of fast growth and public financing is a more defensive approach than many of Donkey Republic’s competitors pursue, but could turn out to be a major success driver ğŸ˜

According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN, the world is able to produce sufficient food for all 7.674 billion inhabitants on the planet ğŸŒğŸŒ½ Nonetheless, in 2020, 720-811 million people still went to bed hungry. This number increased by up to 161 million people from 2019 as a result of the pandemic ğŸ˜·

Global hunger has been particularly on the rise since 2014, with currently 25.9% of the world’s population affected by moderate or severe food insecurity. SDG 2 aims to end hunger for all people and ensure sufficient food all year round by 2030 ğŸ¤²ğŸ¥¦ – however, we do not seem on track for meeting this target. So, why is it that so many people suffer from hunger when we are able to provide food for everybody? ğŸ˜’

There are many reasons for the persisting hunger in the world. For one thing, there is a strong correlation with poverty, which stems from social, political and economic factors. Other factors include wars and conflicts that lead to instability and cause famines âš”ï¸ Another major impactor is weather. It sounds simple: If there is no rain, there will be no grain … ğŸŒ§ğŸš«

Fortunately, many organizations are fighting world hunger, sparking hopes that the 2030 target can still be met. Furthermore, sustainable consumption trends, such as becoming vegetarian or even vegan ğŸ¥¬ may also present a solution for the future. As mentioned in our company spotlight on Beyond Meat, 70% of agricultural land is used for animal grazing ğŸ„ This land usage could be reduced by eating less meat – but is there a more obvious idea for innovation in farming that might solve world hunger?

In fact, there is: vertical farming ğŸ‘©‍ğŸŒ¾ğŸ’¡ Through it, crops are stacked in several vertical layers with an artificially controlled environment. One thing that has become clear after the pandemic is that food chain safety needs improvement – and vertical farming could be one solution. Not only can land be used more efficiently, it also allows individuals to select and freshly pick fruits and vegetables on-site when they are needed ğŸ¤ 

For example, salads, basil or mint could be grown locally on-site in supermarkets, schools, restaurants, or basically wherever and whenever consumers want fresh products ğŸ¥—ğŸ’† Fresh produce can then end up on our plates minutes later!

But who comes up with all these ideas … and who funds them? ğŸ¤” Oftentimes, it is the startup sector, composed of the most innovative and brilliant entrepreneurial minds ğŸ§  that brings these inventions to light. As these companies are usually quite small and associated with a large business risk, they rely on risk capital such as Venture Capital for funding.

What's happening in the Venture Capital market?

The news media Sifted described Europe as an emerging powerhouse of eco-friendly startups ğŸ’¼ğŸŒ± While Europe was able to decrease carbon emissions by 24% from 1990 to 2019, slightly higher than targeted (estimate 20%), predictions forecast a missing of the 2030 targets. 

Simultaneously, consciousness for more sustainable solutions has been growing, which in turn has fueled the investment flow into Venture Capital ğŸ’¸ ğŸ¢ In 2019, net zero-seeking companies received funding of €2.56 billion, an increase of 129% from 2018. 

With this, Europe managed to grow faster than the US (which only grew 16%) and China (which experienced negative growth of -30%) ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡ºğŸ’ª However, the US still remains the largest VC market in the world, raising €5.52 billion in 2019 ğŸ¥‡The largest investment ticket (€633.92 million) in the US was secured by the electric vehicle producer, ChargePoint. In Europe, InFarm, a Berlin-based vertical farming company, raised €331.75 million ğŸ˜²

What are some other innovations that help feed the world?

After the Netflix documentary SeaSpiracy ğŸ¦, many became aware of the problems within the seafood industry’s farming methods. The rising demand for fish is a growing burden on nature and animals with many species already overfished (65% of species in Europe, 96% in the Mediterranean), or almost extinct â˜ ï¸ğŸ˜ Moreover, there is big controversy about fish farms and their environmental impact ğŸ›¢

Meanwhile, a study by The Nature Conservancy showed that seafood is, ahead of chicken, the world’s largest source of animal protein ğŸ’ª accounting for 28% of total animal-based food production. But what if there, similar to synthetic meat or plant-based meat alternatives, is a substitute to fish? ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸

The Swedish startup Hooked has developed what they claim to be the first world’s plant-based shredded salmon product. Hooked distinguishes themselves from other startups by trying to mirror the nutrition of salmon by including raw sea-oriented materials such as algae or seaweed ğŸŒŠ 

Their plant-based salmon and tuna consists of soy protein ğŸ§¬ and natural flavours are added to give the product a similar taste and look. Additionally, the plant-based salmon is free of heavy metals or antibiotics which many fish nowadays carry to a concerning level. If you’re ever in Sweden, you should give it a try! ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª

And how does food appearing out of plain air sound?

Utopic? – Definitely not! ğŸ˜‡ The Finnish startup Solar Food has made this possible ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡® The product is not based on any conventional agricultural products, but is made out of renewable electricity, water and air combined with special bacteria ğŸ§« The created protein is called solein and is said to have a neutral taste. The scientists behind it even describe it as changing in flavour depending on where and how it's used ğŸ‘¨‍âš•ï¸ğŸŒ¤

And what about insects?

Burgers and bread made from bugs and insects may sound unappetizing ... But, termites, grasshoppers, scorpions, and silkworms should not be neglected for their role in saving the world ğŸ¤© ğŸ›ğŸœ And the market for bugs shows potential! In 2019, the global edible insect market exceeded $112 million and is expected to grow annually by 47% to a value of over $1.5 billion in 2026 ğŸ”¥ 

Insects are also a much more efficient source for iron and protein – they add essential vitamins and minerals to our diet. Aaaaand, it’s actually already possible to find everyday products that contain bugs and other sustainable substitutes when you go shopping ğŸ‘ŒğŸ›’ 

Finally, while the food conversion rate for beef is 20-to-1 (20 pounds of feed result in one pound of meat), the conversion rate for bugs is 2-to-1 ğŸ’…

Conclusion: the future of food shows potential ğŸ†

As you might see, there’s a trend here! The food industry is full of innovations that can change the way we eat – which is something we may have to do if we want to preserve our planet ğŸ‘ğŸŒ  The startups we’ve mentioned here may be at the brink of bringing about the shift in our food consumption habits that we’ve been waiting for. So, the next time you crave a burger, how about trying out the bug version? ğŸ˜‰

With the surge in electric vehicles, public transportation and carpooling, it is safe to say that sustainable transportation is on the rise ğŸš—ğŸŒ± In this article, we discuss the carsharing company GreenMobility. It was founded in Denmark ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡° and seeks to combat climate change through electric cars that can be rented on-demand for short, seamless and sustainable trips. Sounds nice, right? Let’s get to it! ğŸ˜

Company introduction

GreenMobility was established in 2016 and went public in 2017. According to their annual report, the Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) business went from having only 40 cars operating in Copenhagen at launch to 950 cars in 2020, spread across four European countries: Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Belgium ğŸ”¥ 

Their growth and success is largely driven by the increasing trends in urbanization and care for the environment ğŸŒ†ğŸŒ³ Cities continue to grow larger, and, instead of having to pay hefty prices for car maintenance and parking spots, it’s becoming easier to simply rent a vehicle on-demand. These rising on-demand services are greatly complemented by the fact that when urban dwellers need a fast transportation option, GreenMobility offers a green and sustainable one ğŸ¥³

It’s also notable that whilst the company is best known for their Business-to-Consumer (B2C) services, they operate Business-to-Business (B2B) too, with offerings available to companies who wish to ensure green mobilization for their employees ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’¼ğŸ¤ Finally, it should be noted that the cars GreenMobility operate in their fleet are Renault’s Zoe and Kangoo models.

Sustainable Development Goals

GreenMobility themselves state in their annual report that they strive to directly impact three SDGs: Sustainable Cities and Communities, Responsible Consumption and Production, and Climate Action. With the effect of electric cars and carsharing in mind, these goals indeed seem plausibly impacted by the business ğŸ† Let’s delve into them individually:

SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

Decreasing carbon emissions in metropolitan areas ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ’¨  is essential to sustainable cities. GreenMobility’s vehicles being electric, the company contributes to reducing carbon emissions. Furthermore, there is a great green aspect in GreenMobility’s electric cars: it increases the demand for electric charging stations in cities. With increasing accessibility and numbers of chargers, the general consumer may also become more inclined to swap their fossil fuel-driven vehicle for an electric one ğŸ”‹ This would increase the demand for electric cars, leading to more sustainable cities! ğŸ™Œ 

Furthermore, GreenMobility stands out as particularly interesting in their participation in the LiRA project. It’s a collaboration between the Danish Road Directorate, the Technical University of Denmark, consulting firm SWECO, and GreenMobility ğŸ›£ğŸ¤ğŸ“± It seeks to, through sensors in GreenMobility’s cars, collect data from Danish roads to assess their physical condition and “revolutionize the way road infrastructure is maintained” to save money on road maintenance ğŸ¤© 

SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

The sharing economy revolves around responsible consumption – and, when we talk cars, carsharing reduces the amount of cars in circulation ğŸ˜‡ While results of research are broad, it’s estimated that one carsharing vehicle is capable of taking between 5-20 cars off the road! ğŸ‰ This is especially significant considering reports that cars are, on average, parked 96% of the time. With the average car only being used in 4% of its lifespan, the movement towards increased carsharing seems an important one to limit superfluous consumption and production ğŸ‘Œ

SDG 13: Climate Action

As already made clear from the discussion of GreenMobility’s electric cars reducing urban carbon emissions, it is evident that GreenMobility has a positive effect in combating climate change âœŠ In 2019, the Karlsruhe Institute for Technology conducted a study on carsharing across eleven European cities and found that carsharing had the potential to decrease their GHG emissions by, on average, 29% per driver â†˜ï¸ 

Furthermore, the studied fleets of various carsharing companies comprised mainly combustion-engines – but imagine the environmental impact if purely electrical fleets like those of GreenMobility were considered in that study! ğŸŒ± In GreenMobility’s own sustainability report, they note that whilst their fleet emitted 95.2 tonnes of CO2 in 2020, it saved 774.7 tonnes from being emitted by fossil-fueled cars ğŸ¥³ Finally, as more cars are taken out of circulation due to companies such as GreenMobility, less greenhouse gases are also emitted as less cars are produced!

ESG risks 

Environmental

If you hadn’t noticed by the exaggerated mention of it in this article so far, carsharing appears to be a great action for our climate. However, though GreenMobility’s carsharing service is good for carbon savings through promoting the use of electrical cars, there may be a cause for concern to be found in the production of these cars ğŸ˜’ 

For one, GreenMobility’s fleet vehicles, Renault’s Zoe and Kangoo models, generate carbon emissions when they are produced, contributing to atmospheric pollution ğŸ›°ğŸ’¨ Renault is working towards becoming a greener corporation, already operating a zero-emission production plant for cars in their Darcia brand, but for the models that GreenMobility operate with, GHG emissions are still an issue. 

Furthermore, the EV batteries installed in Renault’s cars are lithium-ion batteries that require lithium- and cobalt extraction ğŸ”‹ The mining processes of both of these chemical elements put surrounding environments at risk of toxic pollution, and, for lithium in particular, the extraction of one tonne of the element is estimated to consume, on average, 1.89 million litres of water ğŸ¤¯ğŸš°

Social

Firstly, GreenMobility’s services may appear pricy to many ğŸ’° At DKK 4 per minute at the standard fare, a trip does not seem immediately accessible to low-income drivers, especially considering the risk for inner city congestion that could prolong otherwise short trips and, hence, drain wallets ğŸ˜£ GreenMobility offers packages, prepaid minutes, and subscriptions to lower the per-minute fare price, but they require larger initial payments to be utilized. For the lower-income person with less money to spare, the opportunities to sustainably use the company’s green transport methods are therefore arguably sparse ğŸ§

Secondly, as a company whose services rely on consumers using an app to rent their vehicles, GreenMobility has risks in terms of data security ğŸ“³ According to their sustainability report, the company stores data on Google servers via Google Cloud. Whilst the data security of a conglomerate like Google is imaginably much better than what GreenMobility could ensure themselves, Google is not immune to security holes and data breaches ğŸ‘¾

Governance

Corporate governance-wise, one may first note that GreenMobility’s board appears well-balanced in terms of gender: males and females comprise a ratio of 40/60 according to GreenMobility’s 2020 annual report ğŸ‘« Moreover, following the recommendations of the Danish Committee on Corporate Governance that at least half of a company’s board should be independent, GreenMobility reports that four out of five of the company’s board members are independent ğŸ’… This is a positive trait, as it means the Board of Directors is better enabled to engage in decision-making without being biased by conflicts of interest.

Financials

To address the elephant in the room: GreenMobility’s numbers are not green ğŸ˜§ğŸš« Yet, at least! GreenMobility has been facing losses since its inception in 2016, with a recent EBIT (Earnings Before Income Taxes) of DKK -59 million from their 2020 operations. This is down from DKK -29 million in 2019 ğŸ“‰ However, the global COVID-19 pandemic is evidently much culpable for the losses, having caused less people to travel outside of their homes and, for those that have, a hesitance to share cars and devices that have been used by others before them ğŸ¤· 

Similar trends to that of the company’s EBIT is seen in GreenMobility’s negative Return on Assets (ROA) and Return on Equity (ROE) figures. Essentially, the company is not yet generating enough profits to compensate for the money invested into its success ğŸ‘€ 

Being a business that is in its growth phase, however, it is not unsensible that GreenMobility isn't yet making profits – instead of seeking to increase margins, resources are being invested into expanding their market ğŸ“ˆ Ample hope in the company can perhaps be gathered from knowing that the business division in Copenhagen is already running profitably âœ…  – for other locations, like Antwerp in Belgium where GreenMobility launched in 2020, the company expects operational profitability within three to four years. 

By 2025, GreenMobility aims to be "the leading mobility provider in Europe" ğŸ’ª powered by an expansion from the current 7 cities to a total of 35 and an increase from 950 electrical vehicles to more than 10,000 â—ï¸ With this growth, GreenMobility expects to reach an EBIT margin of 20%. In other words, the company expects their earnings before interests and taxes to exceed their business costs by a profitable margin ğŸ˜

Conclusion

GreenMobility are roaming the streets of major European cities – maybe you’ll want them to roam in your portfolio too? In the short-run, their financials appear in shades of red, but, in the long run, there’s a lot of potential for growth and green figures ğŸ¤— However, even though profits are prospected, the underlying financials are only part of the game – from a sustainable investing point of view, the impact of carsharing companies like GreenMobility are, as seen, powerful and interesting ğŸ§ âš¡ï¸ With the potential to reduce the amount of cars and their emissions in urban areas, their contributions may play a key role in the quest for a sustainable future! â™»ï¸ğŸ’¸

Have you ever stumbled upon the term NFT in a finance or business-related article and had no idea what the abbreviation meant? ğŸ¤” We know exactly how you feel, we’ve felt the same way!

NFT is an abbreviation for non-fungible token. ğŸ… Alright, but what does that mean? Let's break it down! 

A token, like any cryptocurrency, is a digitised asset. ğŸ’» A certain value is assigned to this token. Since the token is digital, it becomes tradable and therefore it’s able to fluctuate in value. ğŸ’¹

This is where the non-fungible part comes in. In economics, fungible basically means that the individual unit (here, the token) is exchangeable and indistinguishable. When I exchange one Bitcoin for another Bitcoin, I therefore still have the same value in my wallet. 

Non-fungible, however, means unique and recognisable. Since non-fungible tokens are tied to individual assets, they also have a unique value. ğŸ˜‡ğŸ’µ When I exchange them for each other, I receive a different value. 

A brief backstory

The first appearance of NFTs was back in 2012 when it was called Colored Coins. ğŸ¨ One drawback of these coins was that they only represented value if everyone agreed on it. 

At that time, they were still based on the Bitcoin blockchain. A few years later, it shifted more towards the Ethereum blockchain, allowing for unique tokens to be created and were named NFTs. ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸ In 2017, NFTs started entering the mainstream, partly due to CryptoKitties, a virtual blockchain game where virtual kittens could be raised, adopted and traded. ğŸˆ

NFTs originally aimed to give artists more power and control over their artwork. ğŸ–¼âœŠ Artists could sell their artwork very easily and even profit from each transaction and price increase. For buyers, it was a great way to support their favourite artist and acquire the rights to use and brag about owning the original. ğŸ—£

The market got bigger and bigger and experienced genuine hype. ğŸ”¥ In March 2021, the high-end auction house Christie’s put a collage by the artist Beeple up for sale. The work, containing 5,000 individual artworks, sold at the auction for $69.3 million! ğŸ˜²

Today many people hold NFTs to escape inflation and others buy and hold different NFT artworks and wait for a skyrocketing value to sell again. ğŸ¤‘

But tell me again – what exactly does an NFT mean in the world of cryptocurrency?

NFTs are based on a blockchain, a decentralised database ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’» All previous transaction details are stored in individual blocks which ultimately form a chain of blocks. â›“ For this reason, the ownership of a coin can easily be determined by reading the last block in its chain. Due to this identifiability, blockchain technology is very secure against fraud. ğŸ”’

In addition to a cryptocurrency, NFTs contain additional information that links them to a specific item. This digital token now has the value and ownership of that specific item. Because these tokens are unique, each token has its own specific asset value. ğŸ§®

Digital content is easy to send or trade on the internet, ğŸŒ but there are many tangible assets in the world that cannot be digitised, such as physical paintings. 

NFTs are used to convert these real assets into digital assets by assigning its value to a token. Both digital content and digitised content then can be sold and traded on platforms. ğŸ‘¾ğŸ–¼ As with any asset, the price is determined by the market.

Understood – but if I buy a digital file such as a JPEG image, can I just download it?! 

Yes, you can do that! ğŸ˜ However, the downloaded version is no longer part of the blockchain system and, therefore, does not have the same value as the original. â—ï¸ It is similar to the concept that there is only one original Mona Lisa, but many different copies. The one original NFT is the one that is ingrained in the blockchain and every download creates a new copy. ğŸ–¨

Can anyone just create and sell NFTs?

Of course, you can also create your own content and sell it on a platform ğŸ‰ The most well-known exchanges where you can buy NFTs are OpenSea, Rarible and Mintable. NFTs are bought with cryptocurrencies, which is why buyers and sellers need a cryptocurrency wallet. ğŸ‘›

So, why are they so popular?

It's impossible to say for sure why the popularity of NFTs have soared in recent months. ğŸ¤· The popularity and price is of course influenced by different artists, but the general hype around blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies has also driven up the prices of NFTs. ğŸ“ˆ Another reason might be the COVID-19 pandemic that’s forced us to live a more or less digital life. ğŸ“± Owning digital assets has become much more common and easier to get by!

Don’t jump into NFTs without a second thought, though! They comprise some important environmental problems. ğŸ§ğŸŒ± For example, today, most NFTs are based on Ethereum blockchain technology, which – true – has slightly better energy efficiency than Bitcoin. But still, on average, a NFT artwork requires 340 kWh of electricity, which is 10% of the total annual electricity demand of the average household in Germany! ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ‘§‍ğŸ‘§ğŸ ğŸ”Œ This is the equivalent of 211 kg of carbon emissions – similar to those of a two-hour flight.

Aaaand to sum it all up …

Living in a digital age, you may want to know about cryptocurrencies such as NFTs as an investor. ğŸ§ âš¡ï¸ They have benefits in its good resistance to inflation and in their ability to trade assets such as art. However, you should also be aware of their environmental footprint – which can actually be quite big. As always, do your research before you buy a new asset for your portfolio, and be the movement – make!mpact ğŸ‘ğŸ’•
