Today, we are going to talk about NVIDIA. If you consider yourself a bit more techy or have a gaming habit, you may already know them. But NVIDIA offers more than just their gaming gadgets. ğŸ‘¾ğŸ® It’s industry-leading graphic processing units (GPU) powers the world fastest AI supercomputer which possibly makes it one of the most important AI stocks available .ğŸ“ˆ

If this all sounds very technical to you, don’t worry! We picked this company because we believe that it is a great example of creating real impact through technology. ğŸ’¾ So let’s dive into the specifics on how they make an impact! ğŸŠğŸ»

Company introduction

The California-based company NVIDIA was founded in 1993 by Jen-Hsu Huang. The visual computing company and high-end chipmaker specializes in producing semiconductors that power AI-technologies ranging from high-performance gaming to autonomous vehicles. ğŸš™ They are mostly known for their brand GeForce, under which the company sells GPUs which may likely be built into your very own device. ğŸ’»ğŸ“±

Other than manufacturing GPUs, NVIDIA develops data center platforms and systems for AI and high-performance computing. Their products are applied in various industries from energy and healthcare to Gaming, Robotics to even Smart Cities and Transportation. Because of this, four large markets depend critically on NVIDIA expertise: gaming, professional visualisation, datacenter and automotive markets - crazy right?! ğŸ¤¯

Sustainable Development Goals

We now know who they are and what they do, so now let’s find out which SDGs they address!  

SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

Starting with one of their most impactful areas: ‘Clara’, their healthcare application framework, is key in helping scientists and clinicians use AI in order to innovate areas such as drug discovery and disease detection and contributed to the development of Covid-19 vaccines. ğŸ§¬ğŸ§ª Its increased diagnostic accuracy in medical imaging can drastically improve patient outcomes. ğŸ©º 

NVIDIA also built the UK's most powerful supercomputer, ‘Cambridge-1’. It has been made available to science, empowering researchers to collaborate and share knowledge in different fields. ğŸ¦ ğŸ¤–

Another milestone towards SDG 3 is NVIDIA’s advancement in the field of autonomous driving (AD). Despite being one of the leaders in autonomous software and hardware, there is controversy about how many human driving errors and, in turn, deaths can be avoided by safely functioning autonomous vehicles (AVs). There is no doubt that these numbers would reduce the death count. ğŸª¦ğŸš‘ More and more companies are partnering up with NVIDIA, including traditional car manufacturers such as Volvo and Mercedes-Benz, but also taxi companies such as Chinese AutoX. ğŸ¤

SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

NVIDIA is at the very forefront of providing decent, equal work. As such, they are included in Forbes’ list of America’s Best Employers for Diversity and are a Fortune-certified ‘Great Place to Work’ with an employee satisfaction rate of 96%! ğŸ˜ğŸ‘

So – which concrete measures have they taken? For example, in order to ensure an equal-opportunity hiring process, NVIDIA is tackling unconscious biases using an AI-based third-party tool. NVIDIA also tripled the amount of Black and African American employees in 2020 and provided complimentary conference passes and access to training resources particularly for female and underrepresented developers. ğŸ«

SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

With its efforts in autonomous driving (AD), NVIDIA is actively shaping the future of sustainable cities as it is expected to reduce transportation-related deaths and lead to space savings in cities. â™»ï¸ Also, it helps with the transformation of the transportation sector towards a shared economy. In turn, urban areas are made greener and available for purposes other than parking, as fewer cars are needed. ğŸ…¿ï¸ Additionally, ADs boost inclusive communities, as they become more accessible to the elderly and disabled who previously could not drive cars themselves. ğŸ§“ğŸ‘´ğŸ‘µ

SDG 13: Climate Action

In terms of energy efficiency, 26 of the top 30 ‘greenest’ supercomputers use NVIDIA GPUs. Additionally, the company claims that their GPUs are 42 times more energy efficient than traditional servers, making them ideal to serve challenging AI workloads. ğŸ‹ï¸ğŸ’ª

Furthermore, NVIDIA reports thoroughly on its emissions and with this contributes to SDG Target 13.3 of increasing knowledge and capacity to better cope with climate change. Through their accelerator program ‘NVIDIA Inception’, they provide support to startups to measure the global deforestation and the decreasing permafrost in the Arctics. â„ï¸ğŸŒ

Because of their combined efforts, NVIDIA is featured on Barron’s Top 100 Most Sustainable Companies and on Corporate Knights’ 2021 Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations.ğŸ“ğŸ‘

ESG risks

Environmental factors:

In line with the risks proposed by the SASB Materiality Map, NVIDIA is heavily exposed to Energy Management risks and hasn't performed so well lately, to say the least.ğŸ¥²ğŸ’¼ According to their CSR report, they used 244.760 MWh of energy in 2020 but rose to 325.899 MWh in 2021. ğŸ˜® Now, the naturally posed question is: how much of that energy is sourced renewably in order to reduce carbon emissions? 

The company aims to have 65% of electricity come from renewables by 2025. However, the actual share has been continuously decreasing over the last three years, from 49% in 2019 to only 25% in 2021. ğŸ¤” Accordingly, Scope 2 emissions, which consist of purchased electricity used for data centers, labs and offices, have sharply increased from approximately 65 tonnes of CO2e in 2019 to over 105 tonnes in 2021. ğŸ“ˆ

Also, NVIDIA does not own and manufacture crucial parts for its GPUs such as semiconductor wafers; instead, NVIDIA is dependent on external suppliers for production and delivery. While this outsourcing decision might have profound economic and strategic benefits, NVIDIA loses direct control of how much its products are emitting. ğŸ’¨ And, in fact, Scope 3 emissions, which capture, among others, emissions from purchased goods and services, make up more than 90% of NVIDIA’s total emissions! ğŸ†˜

Social factors:

One of the biggest social risks relates to data security, as also acknowledged by NVIDIA itself. The company refers to system attacks in the past and expects attempts to occur even more frequently in the future. ğŸ¤ºğŸ§¨ The consequences of such attacks are severe and range from disclosure of confidential intellectual property to extraction of customer and employee data. â˜ ï¸ Not only is the company itself subject to attacks its products may also have security holes that could be exploited. If you want to read more about recent security bugs, read here. ğŸ”’

Governance factors:

Being a leader in AI advancement comes with a natural responsibility of establishing trustworthiness, product safety and an ethical code of conduct towards this groundbreaking technology. To win over consumer and regulatory trust, but also implement company-wide AI principles, NVIDIA has already hired a Director of AI and Legal Ethics. ğŸ‘±‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ’¼ For the future, governance-related risks will depend to a large extent on NVIDIA’s overall success with AI. 

Financials

While other company spotlights in our series of articles focus on rather new companies, in this article, we are exploring a relatively mature one. ğŸ‘µğŸ‘´ NVIDIA Corporation has been profitable for a while, achieving constantly growing EBITs - with the exception of 2020. While its financial performance was indeed affected by the COVID-19 pandemic with lower revenues, EBIT and profit margin, the stock price development of NVIDIA has not suffered nearly as much as that of other industries, such as aviation or tourism. ğŸ” The same stock price persistence generally applied to the entire technology industry, including some of NVIDIA’s key competitors like Intel, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) or Hewlett Packard (HP).  ğŸ†—

Nevertheless, NVIDIA’s shares significantly outperformed their competitors, having increased by over 600% since 2017! ğŸ™†‍â™€ï¸ğŸ˜± This might be particularly attributed to NVIDIA’s industry- and technology leadership, driven by investor confidence in the groundbreaking AI technology in areas including health care and AD. âš•ï¸ğŸ¤–ğŸ¦¾ These high expectations are also incorporated into the company’s valuation, with the Price/Sales and EV/Revenue multiples both yielding values well above 20! 

NVIDIA has transitioned from serving the gaming market only, to applying its technology to advancing challenges and opportunities of global scale and importance. ğŸŒ With its market-leading role in AI, NVIDIA is likely to have a big impact on industries such as health care and transportation. ğŸ¥ğŸš—ğŸš• Investors celebrate this exciting outlook with a remarkably high share price and valuation.ğŸ¤© One should however not forget the fundamental ESG risks to NVIDIA’s business, which circle around humongous energy demands and the high dependency on external suppliers, as well as around the trustworthiness and security vulnerability of its products.â˜ï¸

Impact investing is becoming increasingly popular. ğŸ“ˆAnd that trend doesn’t halt with celebrity investors and founders. If you thought that these celebrities only generate income through their regular salaries or sponsorship deals, you have been mistaken! ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸In fact, there are quite a few famous personalities out there that grow their wealth while paving the way for a more sustainable and just future. â™»ï¸ğŸ›£

The companies that these celebrities invest in or found are often privately held and are therefore hard to access by us “everyday” investors. ğŸ’¼However, that should not be holding you back!

If the underlying purpose excites you, there is a high likelihood that you will find a publicly listed company that attempts to achieve similar goals! ğŸ¤©

So without further ado – we present to you some of the most exciting celebrity impact investors and founders. ğŸ¤© May their actions inspire you to take on the grand challenges yourself! 

List of celebrity impact investors and founders 

Leonardo DiCaprio

DiCaprio is likely among the most famous impact investors out there, with stakes in various change-making companies. Aside from creating his own Leonardo DiCaprio foundation to battle ocean preservation, wildlife conservation, and global warming, the “Wolf of Wall Street” holds stakes in Beyond Meat (read our analysis of the company here!). ğŸŒŠğŸ”¥ğŸŒ³ğŸ¥© He is also invested in the rainforest conservation-focused tea producer Runa and the sustainable tech company Rubicon. 

Beyoncé

Queen Bey cannot be missed on this list! As a mindful investor, she is particularly supportive of female entrepreneurs, such as the ones at WTRMLN WTR. ğŸ‘¯‍â™€ï¸ The company seeks to reduce food waste by making watermelon water out of watermelons that would otherwise have been discarded due to blemishes or bruises. ğŸ‰

Bono

The lead singer of U2 doesn’t only melt hearts with his voice, he is also deeply engaged in philanthropic efforts! â¤ï¸How? Back in 2016, he decided to create his very own fund, named The Rise Fund, which aims to drive measurable social and environmental impact in accordance with the SDGs alongside generating financial returns. ğŸ”¢ The company holds only 25 carefully selected and globally spread-out investments, including North America’s largest e-bike brand Rad Power and China’s largest art education platform Meishubao Education. ğŸš²ğŸ«

Oprah Winfrey

Female billionaire and philanthropist Oprah may be one of the world’s most successful female celebrity investors, with a net worth of $3.5 billion .ğŸ¤‘ğŸ’¸ She has a strong focus on food companies and is invested in, among other companies, the Swedish producer of oat-based dairy alternatives, Oatly (Find our company analysis on Oatly here!).ğŸ¥›ğŸŒ¾ And, if you’re looking for some investing advice from Oprah herself, check this out. 

Rihanna

Bad Girl Riri has recently taken a step back from music and has been focusing on her personal ventures and investments. In addition to incorporating a sustainability twist into her self-founded eco-friendly fashion line, Fenty ğŸ‘— and beauty brand Fenty Skin ğŸ’„, the Princess of R&B holds stakes in Partake Foods. The company produces vegan, gluten-free, non-GMO cookies. ğŸª

John Legend

All of me is also all of ours? This could very well have been the motto of Thrive Market, a company that John Legend has invested in. It provides a more inclusive, all-natural, and organic e-commerce grocery platform, which aims to better reward farmers and promote sustainable agricultural practices. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸŒ¾ğŸ¥’ğŸ… Moreover, Legend has put money into the biotech startup MycoWorks, which develops sustainable leather made from fungi. ğŸ„

Wrapping it up

Pretty cool stuff, right? ğŸ¤© Overall, we hope that more and more celebrities start joining this journey. But more importantly, we hope that these examples inspire you! ğŸ‘ŠWith impact investing, every voice counts – so go out there and create the change that you want to see in the world, maybe even inspired by your favorite celebrity? ğŸŒŸ

Be the movement, make impact.

You may have heard of interest rates and know how they can help you grow your money in the long run. ğŸ¤‘ğŸ’¸ In case you are new to this - this might be an important thing to learn. â˜ï¸ Either way, in this article, we will introduce you to all the main types of interest rates and why it is important for the interest. 

But since this is a lot to talk about, let's quickly start with what interest is. ğŸ˜¬ An interest refers to both the cost of borrowing money and the money you earn on your savings. ğŸ’° So, basically, when you take out a loan from a bank, the interest is the cost of the loan. Likewise, when you deposit money in a savings account, the interest is the return which your bank pays you on that deposit. ğŸ¦ğŸ’µ

Any interest is based on an interest rate – and there are actually different kinds of interest rates. ğŸ”¢ So, let’s first explain what they are and how they work! 

So, what’s an interest rate? ğŸ¤” 

An interest rate expresses the aforementioned cost or return as a percentage of the amount you borrow or lend. That’s why, when you want to take out a loan, you’re looking for the lowest interest rate and, when you want to deposit money, you’re looking for the highest interest rate. That makes sense! ğŸ˜

Slight subtlety: interest rates are set by commercial banks to match the day-to-day policy rate given by the central banks, due to the fact that commercial banks also take loans from central banks. ğŸ“† This means, that when a central bank increases its policy rates in order to control the money supply and regulate economic activity, the commercial banks of its jurisdiction– a country, or economic region like the EU– must also raise theirs. â†—ï¸

If you’re particularly observant, you may have noticed that if the interest rate changes from day to day, it would be almost impossible to determine the final cost or return you would get on a loan or deposit. ğŸ˜£ 

For that reason, interest payments are based on, primarily, these three principles:

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Fixed interest rates: This means that, from the beginning to the end, you will always have the same rate as when you sign the initial contract. This is safer, but can also be less profitable because banks deliberately set this rate high (on loans) to cover the risks of variating policy rates. ğŸ¥²

  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Variable interest rates: As the name suggests, your loan or deposit rate will be subject to change and is derived from above mentioned policy rates. This type of interest also has safety features that allow you to set a minimum or maximum limit of variation. These are what we call the floor and cap interest rates.

  • 3ï¸âƒ£ Mixed interest rates: This is a combination of the fixed and variable interest rates. For example, a mixed rate could comprise a fixed rate for the first five years and then a variable one until the end. ğŸ”€

So, now after having glimpsed at the basics of the functioning of interest rates, let’s take a look at the main types of interest rates.ğŸ¤ª

The nominal interest rate

This is the most basic type of interest rate. It’s the rate actually agreed upon and paid or earned. ğŸ¤ For example, consider the case where you deposit $100 into an account with a 10% annual interest rate (which isn’t representative of the current interest rates and only serves as an explanation). If you leave the money in your account for one year, by the end of that year you will have $110 – you have earned $10 in interest. For sitting back and doing nothing, that's pretty nice, right?! ğŸ˜

The real interest rate

Bad news: life is not so simple… ğŸ˜³ There is a factor that changes our initial predictions: inflation. ğŸ˜² That’s why the real interest rate has been invented: it takes inflation into account and will help you refine your predictions for the short, medium and long term. 

Let's illustrate the concept with our previous example. With a deposit of $100 and an interest profit of $10, now consider an inflation rate of 5%. As a consequence,  the real interest rate is actually only 5%, which means your real interest income isn't $10 but rather $5. ğŸ˜¬

The annual percentage rate (APR)

Bad news again: life is complicated! ğŸ˜± Now that we know our nominal interest rate and how to interpret it in relation to future inflation, we might be tempted to think that our estimate cannot get more accurate. ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ However, there is more: we haven’t yet considered the other fees generated by our loan or deposit:  application fees, insurance, additional banking services, you name it… ğŸ™„

That’s why we consider APR: it helps us to choose the most suitable and cheap bank offering for our needs. ğŸ˜¢ğŸ˜¡

With these three interest rates in your pocket, you’ve now acquired a good foundation. ğŸ¤© But as always, there is more to learn about this topic and we encourage you to explore various other interest rates and read more into how the real interest and annual percentage rate are calculated. ğŸ‘Š

Today, we are going to talk about something that affects all of us. Something so fixed in our daily lives that we hardly pay attention to it anymore. We’re talking about the fashion industry. ğŸ‘—ğŸ½ğŸ©³

The fashion industry in a few words 

The history of this industry is, surprisingly, a perfect reflection of the evolution of our societies. To understand both of them, there is nothing more telling than examining the evolution of pieces of cloth – styled, designed and hyper-popularized.ğŸ§µ

This industry is definitely at the center of our global economic system and even one of the most important parts of it. ğŸŒ Still not convinced? The global socks market alone was valued at USD 42.2 billion in 2018. ğŸ§¦ğŸ˜±

So, according to the Encyclopedia Britannica, the fashion industry should be understood as a four-level industry, because it encompasses:

  • The production of raw materials (fibres, textiles, etc.); ğŸª¡

  • The production of fashion goods (t-shirts, shoes, etc.); ğŸ‘—

  • Retail sales (stores, website, etc.); ğŸ¬

  • Advertising and promotion (TV, magazines, social networks, etc.). ğŸ“º

We can even add a fifth level for waste management, which is one of the most important issues in this industry with the work conditions. ğŸš®ğŸ—‘

With this in mind, you can perhaps easily understand how such an industry, at the crossroads between arts, business, and technology, has a global impact. ğŸ¨ğŸ—‚ğŸ’»

Unfortunately, the fashion industry is also responsible for 10% of global carbon emissions and is the second-largest industrial polluter after the oil industry. ğŸ¥´ It’s simple: we now buy two times more clothing than 20 years ago, which we wear almost half as much, on average (ARTE). ğŸ¥¶ This is what we call fast fashion. ğŸ‘–

To break it down, it’s a highly profitable business model built on the low-cost mass production of high-fashion designs and trends. This model is famously criticized due to its immense pollution and frequent poor labor conditions.ğŸ’¨ğŸ˜¤

But, as always, the industry is evolving, and a future of sustainable fashion seems to be taking shape. ğŸ˜

What are the future perspectives of the industry? ğŸ¤”

For the fashion industry, the COVID-19 pandemic changed a lot. Indeed, a report by McKinsey & Company found that “COVID-19 and the economic crisis is the top challenge for 2021 for 45% of fashion executives and stakeholders.” ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ Moreover, the report found that global fashion sales in 2021 could be below pre-pandemic levels by as much as 15%. ğŸ“‰ Furthermore, due to the many lockdowns, half of the European consumers have shopped less in physical stores and led to a considerable development in e-commerce. ğŸ’» This means we are at the dawn of a paradigm shift that will force sustainable fashion and circular business models where clothes are bought, used, and resold for someone else to wear (as especially seen in online marketplaces). â™»ï¸ğŸ‘ But as Macklemore puts it, one man’s trash, that’s another man’s come-up!”

These two solutions, the decrease in shopping in stores and the increase in circular business models, are highlighting new ways for people to consume. This also means that more and more people become attentive to end-to-end sustainable products. ğŸ‘€ As an example, a T-shirt made from organic fibres produced in relocalized production sites is a more sustainable alternative to fast fashion-produced clothing. ğŸ‘•ğŸ‘š Thus, with these new movements, people have, through their collective action, succeeded to inspire a new dynamic into one of the world's largest industries.ğŸ­ What a lesson! 

However the COVID-19 crisis has not only intensified pre-existing critiques of consumerism and heightened the importance of sustainability in purchasing decisions, but it also contributed to the rise of circular business models. â­•ï¸ Especially resale. If you are wondering what a circular business model could consist of, have a look at the picture below. 

With this new kind of model–now not only found in thrift shops but also online– a garment is no longer dumped but sold on so that another person can wear it. And that's how you turn a fashion victim into an eco-responsible clothes saviour. ğŸ™ŒğŸ˜

Beware of greenwashing! ğŸ˜©

As you may have gathered, brands are making great efforts to propose more sustainable products. However, there’s no doubt that some are simply greenwashing to sell more clothes (with companies selling e.g. a “T-shirt made of organic cotton” which are still produced in polluting factories and subcontracted to workshops that do not respect their workers). ğŸ˜¡ We should beware of this kind of practice, as it is, unfortunately, quite common. â˜ï¸

Finally, a part of the answer was already given to us more than 40 years ago in 1979 by US President Jimmy Carter when he warned us that “human identity is no longer defined by what one does, but by what one owns, [...] and that owning things and consuming things does not satisfy our longing for meaning.” ğŸ¤µ‍â™‚ï¸ Nowadays, these words resonate with even more force when we know how much our planet has suffered and is suffering from our overconsumption.ğŸ¤¯

That's why all of us should try to make a positive impact by buying sustainable clothes, making sustainable investments, recycling more, and, generally, engaging in the activities that make an impact! ğŸ¥°

What are the fundamental drivers of stock price return?ğŸ¤” This question has been robbing investors of sleep ever since the very emergence of stock markets. Maybe if you are currently trying to make mad bank by investing in sustainable firms, you are also wondering what things influence these values. ğŸ¤• We are here to help you with this question by introducing you to a very important investing strategy called ‘factor investing’, which tries to answer this question. ğŸ¤©

 

 

Over the last decades, but particularly within the last few years, the factor investing strategy has been massively growing. ğŸ“ˆ In 2019 alone, more than $1.9 trillion worth of assets were managed globally using factor-based strategies. So, what does this strategy really incorporate? And can factor investing be combined with impact investing, and if so, how? ğŸ§ Hang on here, some juicy stuff is comin’!

 

The Basics

With factor investing, you choose your investment based on specific criteria, called factors, which have historically been linked with higher returns, so you have more for your money! ğŸ“œ ğŸ’¸ Overall, there are two key types of factors: 1) macroeconomic factors and 2) style factors. 

If you cannot come up with plausible explanations of what belongs to those categories, let us help you. ğŸ˜ Macroeconomic factors capture the broader risks which can be applied to different asset classes. The most common macroeconomic factors are the inflation rate, GDP growth and unemployment rate. â˜ï¸ You might think now: “Nice, but what is the underlying idea of this?”. ğŸ™ƒ Well, take GDP growth as an example: if an economy is experiencing a period of higher growth, as an example because everybody is buying a lot of things, it is likely that most kinds of assets in that country will experience growth and have higher returns. ğŸ¤‘ğŸ›

On the contrary, style factors such as value, size, and quality, try to explain risks and returns within specific asset classes. If this sounded like you need to open google in order to understand this, don’t! We are here to help.ğŸ˜‰ From now on, we will focus on introducing you to the world of style factors for a very simple reason: they allow you to build a portfolio that has a chance to outperform the market based on your own active choices. ğŸ¯

For example, screening for the style factor Value means identifying companies who have low market values compared to their book values – such companies are expected to perform better in the future. ğŸ¥‡ This is because, in contrast to companies that are overhyped on the market (high market value compared to book value), companies with a relatively low market value may be under the radar and still have a huge potential to grow and catch up. ğŸ¤ª Gotta catch ‘em all…

Similarly, the factor Size explains that historically, stocks with smaller market capitalization have outperformed stocks with larger market capitalization. ğŸ“Š Market capitalization is the value of all of the firm's shares. The factor Quality is slightly harder to capture but basically refers to screening for companies who are expected to outperform others based on their Quality. ğŸ—‘ That can be measured, for example, through low debt levels, stable earnings growth and further metrics which indicate a high quality company.  ğŸ”

If you now pick a well-diversified portfolio with a focus on, let’s say, Value companies, you experience the active choice we talked about earlier. You, yourself, pick the selected companies that are expected to outperform the market, making it active. ğŸ‘Š The same would not apply with the macroeconomic factor GDP growth, since any company you pick would be more or less equally affected. 

Can we see some proof of this outperformance? ğŸ¤”

The performance of several portfolios which are compared based on specific factors can be seen below. â¬‡ï¸  This graph really shows how investing based on specific factors can outperform an equally weighted portfolio (aka. the market, indicated by the purple line).

However, the graph also reminds us that investing is not as easy as we may think. We cannot simply buy a portfolio of companies with, let’s say, a low book-to-market ratio (factor value) and just expect to gain a large return quickly. ğŸ¤¨ The point of factor investing is that outperformance based on a specific factor occurs with a diversified factor portfolio and over a much longer period of time. â¡ï¸ In the short-term, many factor strategies, such as the Minimum Volatility strategy (the green line), can perform worse than the market. ğŸ“‰

What are the benefits to us impact investors? 

As just explained, factor investing means you’re in it for the long run. ğŸƒ‍â™€ï¸ That perfectly aligns with the goals of impact investors – the incentive is not a short-term gain, but rather the creation of systematic and relevant change through your investment, alongside a financial return. 

Through factor investing, we can also get rid of human biases we would otherwise carry into our investment process. ğŸ­ For example, you might invest in a specific company simply because they recently started a new marketing campaign supporting animal welfare.ğŸ±ğŸ¶â¤ï¸ Here, factor investing can add objectivity to your investment criteria. We are not saying you should not invest in this company if it aligns with your values (we’re all about that!). We are saying that checking out some of the metrics which capture factors such as size and value contribute to more informed decisions based on the future prospects of your investments.ğŸ§‘‍ğŸ’»

And, even better, factor investing and impact investing can, in many ways, complement each other! ğŸ”€ For example, the factors Quality and Low Volatility are more strongly correlated with a better ESG profile than the market is, on average. ğŸ¤ This is because companies with more stable earnings and/or lower volatility tend to be larger companies with more experienced management and risk departments to mitigate ESG risks. Be aware, though, that this is not a free ride!ğŸ¢ Always do your own research and do not simply assume that a strong factor translates into a high ESG score or vice versa. ğŸ¤“

 

Overall, factor investing has become a huge topic in the investment world. ğŸŒ We hope this article sets the foundation for your knowledge of factor investing and has inspired you to delve deeper and maybe even incorporate this strategy into your own impact investments!

So, go ahead - be the movement and make impact! â¤ï¸

If you missed the article, go check it out here. ğŸ‘Š

Now, let’s delve into Part 2! May these examples inspire you to go out there and create the change that you want to see in the world. ğŸŒâ¤ï¸

List of celebrity impact investors and founders ğŸ’ƒğŸ•º

Drake

Recently, Champagne Papi invested in the eco-finance startup Aspiration. ğŸ¾ The company offers environmentally focused financial services and considers itself as a more sustainable alternative to other banks. ğŸ¦ğŸ’¸ Aside from investing in Aspiration, Drake also uses the company’s services to monitor and cut down his carbon footprint with the intention to make his private life carbon-neutral. ğŸ˜

Meghan Markle

Other than crushing lawyers in Suits or being more (or less) royal these days, the Duchess of Sussex is entering into the realms of sustainable investing by being the part-owner of plant-based company Clevr Blends. ğŸ‘¸ The company famously produced the world’s first instant oat milk latte and donates one percent of its profits to local organisations in order to fight food injustice. ğŸŒ¾ğŸ¥›ğŸ¥¦

We love being inspired by our favorite celebrities.ğŸ¤ª If you are curious about the companies and foundations we just mentioned, we encourage you to look them up and find out whether you want to support them with your penny. ğŸ’° But that is it for now.

We know that you have been waiting for it: more knowledge on interest rates! ğŸ˜ After acquiring a good foundation on what interest rates are and how they work in the previous article, it is now time to learn how to apply them with the different kinds of interest. ğŸ˜ğŸ¤ª

Let us quickly remember what interest is. ğŸ˜Š As we said at the beginning of part 1 of this series on interest: An interest refers to both the cost of borrowing money and the money you earn on your savings. Rings a bell? If not, feel free to go back and read all about it.  ğŸ‘Š

But how does interest work? ğŸ¤”

As you now know, there are different kinds of interest rates and it’s finally quiet similar with interests, which are mostly subdivided into two types: simple interest and compound interest. ğŸ§

The simple interest

When you have money deposited in your bank account, the bank pays you a small fraction of your deposit at regular intervals (for example, quarterly or yearly). These small fractions are what we call interests.ğŸ’µğŸ’°

It’s exactly this principle of simple interest that we applied to the nominal interest rate example. ğŸ¤™So for example, consider the case where you deposit $100 into an account with a 10% annual interest rate (which isn’t representative of the current interest rates and only serves as an explanation). If you leave the money in your account for one year, by the end of that year you will have $110 – you have earned $10 in interest. ğŸ¥°

Nice, isn’t it? ğŸ˜ƒYes, but, hey – with compound interest, we can see even greater results!ğŸ¤©

The compound interest 

Compound interest is not the simplest concept, but we will try to introduce it as easily as possible.ğŸ˜µ‍ğŸ’« That’s why we will not approach all its subtleties, but only its basic functioning. 

Basically, compound interest is the accumulation of interest to the principal capital and all additional deposits that were made to it. ğŸ¢ Whew, that sounds very technical! Let’s break it down to make it all more digestible. Principal capital is simply the money you have in your account at the beginning of period 0. ğŸ’° Just like with the simple interest, you will earn interest each period. ğŸ’µBut, of course, if you keep depositing money throughout the period, this money will also earn interest from the moment it is paid into your account. ğŸ’¸At the end of the first period, the interest of the principal capital is calculated and paid to you. For the next period, you will now receive interest payments on your principal capital and the interest paid from the previous period. ğŸ’°ğŸ’µğŸ’¡

In other words, compound interest is a way to make interests on interest! ğŸ“ˆ

If this still sounds a bit confusing, don't worry! ğŸ˜ Here’s a simple example to show you how it works:

Consider a scenario where you’re still investing $100, but now monthly (i.e.$1,200/year) in a deposit with a 10% annual interest and a monthly compound interval over 20 years. ğŸ‘Œ

That means :

  • You’ve deposited $24,000 over 20 years.

  • After 20 years, you have earned $52,569.69 in interest.

  • Finally, you are left with $76,569.69 in your deposit account.  ğŸ™€

That’s nice, right? Yes, but the interesting thing about compound interest is that it follows an exponential curve. ğŸ‘€ In our example, this means that if we increase the investment period to 40 years, you’ll deposit double the previous amount ($48,000), but have much more than double the interest. In this case, that’s more than 11 times the previous interest! ğŸ˜²

  • You’ll deposit $48,000 over 40 years.

  • After 40 years, you have  earned $589,678.02 in interest

  • Finally, you will have $637,678.02 in your deposit account. 

So, in this example, you turn $48,000 into over half a million dollars. That’s the power of compound interest! ğŸ˜


Now, you learned the basics about interest rates and interest, about how it can help you increase your money. ğŸ™Œ Of course, we encourage you to learn more about this subject, which is finally a very interesting one – at least, we hope that's what you think now – and to start investing. ğŸ˜‰ Sorry, we mean to start impact investing obviously!ğŸ˜‚

Whether you are lactose intolerant or downing milk like water, the likelihood that a Danone product landed in your fridge before is very high. ğŸ¥› If it had a negative impact on you because it helped you find out that you are lactose intolerant, we want to replace your negative memory of this firm with some nice ones, by telling you about Danone's positive impact! ğŸ˜‡ğŸ‘

Company introduction

Danone supplies over 120 countries with products ranging from Essential Dairy ğŸ® & Plant-Based Products ğŸŒ±, Specialised Nutrition ğŸ¼  to Waters ğŸš° and even enjoy market-leading positions throughout all categories. Still does not ring a bell? Brands like Activia, Alpro or Evian all belong to Danone! ğŸ˜®

“Let us conduct our businesses with both the heart and the head.” â¤ï¸ğŸ§  These were the wholesome words of Danone’s founder and former CEO Antoine Riboud in his groundbreaking 1972 Marseille speech which gave birth to the food company’s famous dual economic and social approach to doing business. But what does the dual approach stand for? ğŸ¤” You're right, their approach aims to achieve profitable yet sustainable growth. â˜ï¸ And even better: it has been a part of the company's objectives ever since! ğŸ˜

So, what does that mean in practice? ğŸ§ Let’s look at an example, over 20 Danone subsidiaries are certified B Corporations, which is an industry-leading third-party certification demonstrating high standards of environmental, social, and governance performance. ğŸ¥‡ One of them even being the world’s largest B Corp, Danone NA! Further, Danone claims to be the first company to adopt a carbon-adjusted Earnings Per Share (EPS) metric which is supposed to expose the financial costs of carbon emissions on the entire value chain. ğŸ’¨

Sustainable Development Goals ğŸ¤©

With the vision “One Planet, One Health”, the company wants to “Bring health through food to as many people as possible”. This also means that SDGs 2, 3 and 6 are the most important ones for Danone: 

 

SDG 2: Zero Hunger ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸

Danone does not only make sure babies and yoghurt-lovers have access to food, they also want to ensure that there is access to safe and nutritious food while also maintaining a sustainable food production system. ğŸ¥¦ğŸ… For this, their specific actions in 2019 included signing a Memorandum of Understanding with the UN’s Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) to improve global nutrition. ğŸŒ Moreover, through its own venture capital fund Danone Communities, which empowers innovative social enterprises to develop sustainable social impact, the company reached over 300,000 beneficiaries in the fight against malnutrition and poverty. ğŸ’ª

SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

Danone wants to ensure the best possible nutrition for infants, young children and mothers.ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ¼ğŸ¼  Particularly in 2019, the company was able to have 90% of its total sales volumes come from healthy products. Also, Danone co-chairs the working group Collaboration for Healthier Lives, which aims at encouraging consumers to live healthier lives. âœ…

SDG 6: Clean Water and Sanitation 

Danone promotes SDG 6 by participating in projects which provide access to drinking water for as many people as possible by improving water quality and safeguarding water-related ecosystems. ğŸ’¦ Danone Communities recently also invested in several businesses that provide innovative solutions for water supplies, so-called water kiosks. ğŸ› In total, the fund reached over 5 million beneficiaries with access to safe drinking water through the companies in its portfolio. ğŸ¢

SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth ğŸ“ˆ

Above all, Danone wants to provide decent work through its close protection of employee interests rather than milking its employees. For example, the company joined the Consumer Goods Forum (CGF) in 2016, aiming to stop forced labor from all global supply chains. Furthermore, Danone implemented the employee participation initiative One Person One Voice, and a unique, employee-focused board committee labelled the Engagement Committee. 

ESG risks

Frankly, Danone is doing quite well in terms of ESG risks. Accordingly, they have received the rare Triple-A ESG score from MSCI. ğŸ˜Œ The international non-profit organization CDP also ranked Danone as only one out of 10 from 5800+ companies on the A-List for the three environmental areas climate change, forest preservation and water security. In comparison to key competitors such as Nestlé and Unilever, Sustainalytics ranks Danone’s ESG risks as low, while both competitors’ risks are considered medium. ğŸ˜

The most relevant risks emerge from a governance perspective. ğŸ˜Ÿ With its dual business approach, Danone creates value through a stakeholder model, incorporating the interests of not only shareholders but also suppliers, consumers, employees and the operational impact on the environment. ğŸ‘ This is even more reinforced by the company’s executive variable compensation, which rewards not only financial but also social and economic targets. ğŸ¯ For example, the remuneration depends on fulfilling certain climate ambitions and employee participation rates. 

Plus, the Board of Directors, as previously mentioned, strongly safeguards employee interests through the aforementioned Engagement Committee. ğŸ˜ The B Corp certifications act as an additional governance mechanism, as they commit and enforce certified companies to meet certain social and environmental standards. Overall, all these mechanisms suggest a functioning governance system, in which everyone is incentivised to create shared and inclusive growth. Right? ğŸ¤¨

Not quite, as recent scandals point out. ğŸ™ƒ One piece didn’t quite fit the puzzle: the company’s scattered ownership structure, composed of many minority institutional investors, typically owning stakes for a few years and focusing on maximising their return on investment in that shorter span of time. ğŸ˜” These investors were unhappy about the company’s financial performance, publicly raising their concerns and allegedly influencing the firing of CEO Emmanuel Faber (the person who arguably embodied the stakeholder value creation model like no one else in the company). ğŸ’¸ğŸ’°

The overall point is, that there seems to be a slight mismatch between the company’s ownership structure demanding superior returns and the remaining governance mechanisms promoting stakeholder value creation at the potential expense of precisely said shareholder return. ğŸ”€ Think about it like this: a specific employee or biodiversity initiative may be desirable, but also costly and lengthy to materialize and thus not in the interest of shorter-term institutional investors. ğŸ¥² Striking a good balance between the interests of the company’s most important stakeholders will be a key challenge for the new CEO.

Financials

Through its stakeholder model and dual approach to doing business, Danone prioritizes long-term value growth over short-term gains. ğŸ¥° However, the success of this mission remains questionable and the above-mentioned shareholder activism seemingly justified, as Danone’s current share price is not much higher than 10 years ago and continuous historic EBIT growth has hardly existed…. ğŸ˜²

In contrast, competitors such as Unilever, Nestlé, Coca-Cola and Mondelez have more than doubled or tripled their respective share prices. Similarly, Danone’s recent profitability measures (ROA, ROE, profit margin) are lower than the same measures of the key competitors Nestlé and Unilever. ğŸ˜¥ This underperformance can also be seen in the multiple comparisons, where Danone performs worse than all competitors across three different multiple measures. 

Besides creating yummy foods and drinks, through its company mission and dual approach to doing business, Danone does not only act as an industry leader and impactor towards crucial global challenges.ğŸ˜‹ It also serves as a great example of a company that has implemented a relatively consistent stakeholder value creation model. ğŸ˜Š However, this may have hampered financial returns in recent years and led to clashes with a return-focused and rather short-term oriented ownership structure.

There are many different routes and actions companies and organizations individually are taking in order to contribute to a more sustainable future. ğŸ˜ However, you might have been wondering what other players like governments are doing? Or maybe even the EU? ğŸ¤” We are going to update your political knowledge and help you be up-to-date by presenting to you the SFDR, the new sustainability regulations from the EU! ğŸ™ŒğŸ¥³

SFD-what?

SFDR. It’s an abbreviation for the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation. â˜ï¸ It was drafted by the European Union in 2019 and finally came into effect on March 10th 2021. The SFDRs goal is to fight greenwashing from institutional investors and asset managers, a.k.a the “heavy” investors in the market. ğŸ’ªğŸª´ğŸ¢ To do so, it requires these financial market participants to transparently report on their sustainability risks and impacts, meaning that they openly have to state their influence on the environment. âœï¸In this way, retail investors (i.e. the “normal” investors) will better be able to tell which funds are sustainable and which are not. 

How so? - Fifty shades of Green

By introducing common standards for financial firms. ğŸ˜ By outlining the requirements for all financial institutions who wish to operate within the European Union, rules are universal for everyone and ensure that all the companies must behave in the same way to meet the same objectives – sustainability. ğŸ”ƒğŸ™†‍â™€ï¸ The regulation consists of 20 different articles that direct the future of corporate sustainability, but there are only three that are most widely known as the most important ones: Article 6, dealing with general transparency; Article 8, which classifies what is called “Light Green” funds; and 9) which labels “Dark Green” funds. ğŸ¤©

I am intrigued. Tell me more about these mythical articles...

Well, it gets kind of technical here, but we’ve got you! We’ll list them for easier understanding:

Article 6 states that all financial markets participants (institutional investors and asset managers) must provide information on how ESG factors have been considered in their investment decisions and their sustainable impact.ğŸ§ğŸ“– In this way, we can say that firms must create transparency on their sustainable efforts (or lack thereof).ğŸ˜

Article 8 is a “level-up” from Article 6 and marks the requirements for “Light Green” funds, which label ESG factors as one of their focus points. To meet Article 8, these funds must meet the Article 6 directives and, on top of that, provide clear information on how they meet the advertised ESG characteristics.ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ğŸ¤Œ Furthermore, if they use an index as a reference benchmark, it must be shown how the fund’s ESG factors and the index align. In this case, it must also be disclosed how the fund calculates such indexes. Funds that meet Article 8’s requirements are labelled “Light Green'' funds by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). ğŸ˜

Article 9 marks a “super-level-up” and is reserved for funds and financial products focused solely on sustainability – we call these “Dark Green” funds. ğŸ˜² According to the SFDR, it applies where the company behind the investments provides a clear explanation on how they promote sustainability or, alternatively, where they include a relevant benchmark index that can demonstrate the investments’ positive sustainable impact compared to the broad market. ğŸ˜› Only the funds that are consistent with Article 9 can label themselves as “Dark Green” funds. (Spoiler alert: That’s our favorite green!)

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

So, in detail, it pretty much means that companies who seek the shades-of-green labels must disclose their sustainability risks and, from 2022, their principal adverse impacts. ğŸ‘Š Of these, sustainability risks refer to the risks that sustainability factors have on a fund’s financial return. Principal adverse impacts, on the other hand, refers to the impacts that the fund has on, as the SFDR states, “environmental, social and employee matters, respect for human rights, antiâ€corruption and antiâ€bribery matters.” ğŸ‘€

Thus, with the new SFDR, we, the investors interested in green investment funds, will know much more about whether these funds are actually green and sustainable, and also how their financials might be influenced by sustainability risks. ğŸ¤¤

Who does this apply to? 

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care?

Because with the increased transparency of green funds it seems that making sustainable investments will be a lot easier! ğŸ“ˆâœ… One no longer has to thoroughly research the funds’ impacts on their own, but can instead trust their labels due to the new EU regulations. ğŸ“„ This saves more time for crucial activities like eating ice cream and binging Friends. ğŸ˜ It seems the SFDR and its fifty two shades of green are great news for sustainable portfolio diversification and, if we may say so, every impact investor’s wet dream! ğŸ¤­

As you might have realized, finding a sustainable company to invest in is not the easiest thing to do. ğŸ˜Ÿ How far is a firm involved in environmental, social and governance (ESG) issues? What is its approach and how will this have a future sustainable impact? ğŸ§ğŸ¤¯These are questions one could ask. Once again, we are here to guide you and give you as much substance as possible to help you invest sustainably. ğŸ˜ To do so, we’re going to talk about the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB), which might help you figure out which questions you should ask before investing in a company. ğŸ¤ªğŸ“

What is the SASB? ğŸ¤“

SASB is a non-profit organization that offers ways for investors to align their investments with sustainable values. ğŸ¥°â™»ï¸ The board takes a very innovative investment approach, based on the notion that sustainability issues are business issues. For example, it is not unthinkable that less sustainable companies (like conventional oil producers) will face more problems on the business side of things due to increasing regulations. ğŸ˜® So, what has the SASB done? For one, they have developed standards to provide a new common language between companies and investors to take up sustainability issues. ğŸ˜ğŸ’ª

These standards, available for 77 industries–from the pulp and paper industry to telecommunication services–identify the sustainable issues most relevant to financial performance. ğŸ“ˆ

But why? And how does it work?

There is no doubt that sustainability issues can impact a company’s financial performance. However, not all sustainability issues have the same impact on every industry. ğŸ“Š A quick example: greenhouse gas emissions do not have the same impact on a firm in the consumer goods industry as they do on a firm in the extractives and minerals processing industry. â˜ï¸

That’s why SASB standards are subdivided by industry sectors (financials, health care, etc.), where each relates to the five dimensions of sustainability, namely: 

  • Environment; 

  • Social capital;

  • Human capital;

  • Business model and innovation;

  • Leadership and governance. 

Moreover, each of these sustainability dimensions are then further divided into more detailed subsets. ğŸ”¨ And, from all of these intricacies, we get the SASB Materiality Map which shows the importance (materiality)  between the different dimensions and sectors. If you want to look more into this, click here. ğŸ™Œ

Simple, clear and interactive, this map gives a perfectly accurate representation of today’s and tomorrow's challenges at a glance. ğŸ—’ According to the SASB, this accuracy is achieved through their “rigorous due process which includes evidence-based research, broad and balanced stakeholder participation, public transparency, and independent oversight and direction from the Standards Board”. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’¼ğŸ§‘‍ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’¼

Let’s explain that with an example!

You’ve discovered an interesting sportswear brand that seeks to combat fast fashion.ğŸ‘Œ It’s name? Sweat!mpact. ğŸ¥¸ Now, you want to be sure of the real impact area of this brand as part of the fashion industry, especially if it affects social and human capital and if it has a serious environmental impact. ğŸ˜‡Well, you want to invest with purpose and are aware of the importance of ESG issues when estimating the company’s future financial performance. ğŸ“‰ You recently learned about the SASB materiality map and know how it can help you identify the alignment of the firm with sustainability issues. ğŸ—º So, first, you decide to read the SASB report of the sector’s standards.

Thanks to these detailed descriptions of the impact companies like Sweat!mpact could incur on sustainability goals, you’ll learn more about what to look for in the specific brand’s influences, be they environmental, social or governmental, by having the benefit of rigorous research on the industry and the sustainable standards the company should follow based on its sector. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’»âœ… You are now able to make an investment decision with a better understanding of the brand’s potential performances in the future and especially the possible impact that your investment could have on the values you care about. ğŸ†™

 

The Sustainability Accounting Standards Board offers, to anyone who wants to invest sustainably, the key tools to analyse a company or a sector in terms of environmental, social and governance issues. ğŸ¤ It can definitely help you to invest with more purpose and allows you to make a better impact. ğŸ’—

As you might have experienced yourself, during 2020 remote work was the norm for most people. For some, remote work has meant dealing with their children’s online education, laundry, cooking, and walking the dog while still being expected to be productive during daytime working hours. ğŸ“šğŸ‘©‍ğŸ³ğŸ‘¶ For others, it has meant loneliness and exclusion. ğŸ˜¢  Today, we’re digging into the future of work – and, of course, what it means to you as an investor! ğŸ¤©

There are a few stats and insights that might make it clearer just how big the move to remote work has been and what it means for most businesses. ğŸ“ˆ

ğŸ‘‰ 72% of companies with remote work policies believe that remote work makes workers more productive

ğŸ‘‰ To the question: “Would you like to work remotely, at least some of the time, for the rest of your career?”, 99% of those companies’ employees, said YES!

ğŸ‘‰ 43% of US employers plan to allow their employees more remote work in the next year 

Yet, this doesn’t mean that remote work is all that matters. CEOs and employees alike still think that working from the office is valuable. ğŸ¤ Here are some reasons as to why:

ğŸ‘‰ 87% of employees believe that being in the office is important for team collaboration

ğŸ‘‰ 68% of executives say a typical employee should be in the office a minimum of 3 days a week to maintain a distinct company culture and team spirit

ğŸ‘‰ 29% of executives believe that 3 days a week in-office and 2 days working remotely is the ideal model for the future of work

But how might this be relevant to me as an investor? ğŸ¤”

If the future of work is based on more remote work opportunities, the workforce will need advanced tech tools to help them control their productivity, communication, cloud storage, identity providers, HR, and much more. ğŸ’»ğŸ“Ÿ These are trends to look out for! ğŸ¤“

By normalizing remote work, it’s also clear that there will be less demand for downtown office spaces and the surrounding restaurant and café chains where employees would usually head for their business lunches or get-go shot of caffeine. ğŸ¢â˜•ï¸ Due to both time efficiency, money, and businesses going green, it might also lead to less business travel. ğŸš˜â° It also seems that many businesses are investing in AI and automation so as to bring fewer people into everyday work-functions. ğŸ¤– Finally, e-commerce is also booming 4-5 times faster as compared to our pre-pandemic world – sending the message that people are starting to prefer shopping from their desks rather than on the commute home from work. ğŸ›ğŸ›’

Moreover, business models are likely to change after the pandemic; the classic example being sectors that require high levels of physical proximity. For example, sectors such as health care or leisure and travel have meant higher COVID infection rates, and therefore they are expected to experience a greater transformation post-pandemic. ğŸ¥âœˆï¸

On another note, in advanced economies, it’s estimated that between 20-25% of the workforce could work from home 3-5 days a week without a loss in productivity. ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ğŸ“‰ In the big picture, this might mean that more people move away from cities and settle in less-urban areas since they won’t have to rely on their physical proximity to work. The possible move away from cities goes against the trend towards the urban that we’ve covered in our company spotlight on Donkey Republic. ğŸš² So, perhaps, the future of remote work is something to consider when you research investment opportunities in companies that rely on urban futures. ğŸ™

The future of work – the future of investing? ğŸ¤¨

There’s a lot of popular tech companies out there that have benefitted from the development of remote work during the pandemic. You might know some of them! ğŸ‘Š If it’s because you’ve worked with them directly or if you’ve seen some of them in ESG index funds, it’s because they’re already quite well-known. ğŸ˜ 

Here’s then a few examples of tech companies relating to remote work that are or have recently gone public: ğŸ¤©

ğŸ‘‰ Slack

ğŸ‘‰ Zoom

ğŸ‘‰ Microsoft

ğŸ‘‰ Google

ğŸ‘‰ Dropbox

ğŸ‘‰ Adobe

ğŸ‘‰ Cisco

ğŸ‘‰ DocuSign

But remember: While these companies are now public and show great promise in the popularity of remote work, that does not necessitate that they are sustainable and worthy to invest into. ğŸ¤¥ As always, you should do your own research before you invest to make sure that a company has more than just its financials in order, but also that it matches your values.ğŸ™Œ With that being said: Be the movement – make!mpact! â¤ï¸

When discussing how to make an impact with your friend, this sentence was probably mentioned: “Corporation Actions refer to literally any action that a corporation is taking, right?!” ğŸ—£ Unfortunately we have to tell you, no, not really!ğŸ™‡‍â™€ï¸ 

Within the investment universe, Corporate Actions (CA) are actually a quite specific term that incorporates a number of select actions. Particularly, CA refers to any activity that will greatly affect a company’s issued shares and thereby its shareholders. ğŸ§ Chances are, one of these shareholders could be you! â˜ï¸ This is why you should know which CAs there are and how they will actually affect you so that you are not taken by surprise. So – let’s jump into it! ğŸ¤¾

 

These activities, which usually have to be approved by a company’s Board of Directors, range from the not-so-nice matters, such as bankruptcy, to potentially more exciting topics such as acquisitions and spinoffs. ğŸš«ğŸ’°ğŸ”ƒ While mandatory CA are automatically applied to the investments,  there’s a chance that shareholders like yourself have to respond to these important matters in so-called voluntary CA. 

Important Corporate Actions ğŸ˜®

Dividends

Dividends are mandatory CA that are automatically distributed to you. ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ Basically, it means that you as a shareholder sometimes receive a little gift for your ownership, most commonly paid in cash.ğŸ’¸ At the same time, however, the share price is expected – at least in theory – to decrease by the same amount as the dividend payment to reflect that potential new shareholders after the dividend payout date do not get that same extra gift that you did. ğŸ§ Here, you can read more about dividends and how they work. ğŸ¤©

Stock Splits

Stock splits are another common mandatory CA. Let us quickly introduce how it works with a little example: Imagine you own a 100€ bill. ğŸ’¶ Now, you trade this one bill with one of your friends who offers you two 50€ bills in return.ğŸ’µğŸ’µ Not much has changed, right? ğŸ¤¨ Not entirely true. While your absolute wealth has not changed a dime, you now hold two bills that are easier to trade and simply more liquid. ğŸ˜¯ We’ve probably all come across a place that does not accept larger bills, right?

Similar to this analogy, stock splits are often performed in order to make an individual stock more affordable and liquid.ğŸ˜‹ It works like this: a company splits up its outstanding shares by a specific factor, most commonly by a 2-to-1 or 3-to-1 factor. An example?  Sure! If you currently hold 10 shares of company X, you would hold 20 after a 2-to-1 stock split. ğŸ¤¯

It’s important to understand, however, that a stock split, in theory, has no impact on the company’s market capitalization nor your wealth. ğŸ™Œ If a company doubles the number of outstanding shares, the price per share drops to half the initial price, for example, from 100€/share to 50 €/share and the total value of shares outstanding remains the same.ğŸ¤— In reality, a stock split is often interpreted in a good way and can pave the way for further company growth, as it attracts more investors, and in turn, increases stock prices. ğŸ¤¥

Reverse Split

The opposite of a stock split, a reverse split is a mandatory CA often implemented by a company to artificially increase the price per share. ğŸ˜Œ For example, if you currently held 10 shares of X at 50€ each, you would hold one share at 500€ after a reverse split of 10-to-1.

Mergers and Acquisitions

Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) are another form of mandatory CA. In a merger, usually two (but sometimes even more) companies come together and merge into one larger, new company. ğŸ™†‍â™€ï¸ If the company that you are holding shares of merges, you usually, remain a shareholder after the merge. ğŸ‘ The value of your share will, however, largely depend on the financial prospects of the other company in the merger. 

In contrast, an acquisition means that the acquired company ceases to exist as a stand-alone entity. 1ï¸âƒ£  If a company you hold shares in is acquired, you will be compensated for your shares and no longer hold any ownership of it afterwards. ğŸ˜” If your company is the acquirer, you will typically keep your shares, but, similar to a merger, the value of your share will depend on the financial prospects of the acquired company. ğŸ˜›

Tender Offer

A very important voluntary CA! ğŸ˜ In a tender offer, an investor is trying to acquire parts or even all equity ownership of a company. ğŸ˜² As a potential shareholder, you are then invited to sell your shares to the bidder for a specified price within a given time frame. So, ultimately, it’s up to you if you want to sell your shares or not. ğŸ¤¯  Tender offers are rather attractive to existing shareholders because the offered price is usually above the current market price, but, for impact investors, one should consider who they are selling to! ğŸ¤” If you care deeply for the company, you may want to avoid it falling into the wrong hands! ğŸ™ƒ

There are plenty of other Corporate Actions out there such as rights issues, spin-offs, optional dividends, and more that you continue to explore on your own. ğŸ¤ª We hope to have left you enlightened about some of the most important ones and the basic understanding that every CA substantially affects the value of shares that you are holding. ğŸ˜‡

With that, there is nothing left to say, other than: Be the movement, make!mpact! ğŸ’—

You might have heard lots of people talk about Crypto. ğŸ“° If the first thought that comes to your mind is the letters originated in Egypt, we are here to introduce you to what they are really talking about: Cryptocurrency. ğŸ’¸ğŸ…

How does it actually work? ğŸ¤”

The first attempts at alternative electronic currencies started with the beginning of the internet around 1998. ğŸ”™ These early versions of cryptocurrencies failed for various reasons but mainly because the systems were centralized (e.g. run just by the government). ğŸ¥´ This could have been avoided if the system had been decentralized. In 2009 – a time when trust in banks was very fragile – Bitcoin was born as the first cryptocurrency, defined by its nature as a decentralized electronic currency. ğŸ’»ğŸ’°

Decentralized means that a network is not controlled by a single entity like just by the government. ğŸ¢ Nowadays, most cryptocurrencies are decentralized and untouchable by governments. They also use a peer-to-peer system. ğŸ¤ This system relies on the control of the payments by the users themselves, also called miners, and by computer algorithms, the blockchain. â›ğŸ¤–

In a nutshell, the blockchain is like a public ledger, a collection of financial accounts. ğŸ¦ The transactions are arranged to be carried out chronologically. ğŸ”ƒ The blockchain consists of several blocks that each contains a certain number of transactions. These blocks are verified by miners before being added to the blockchain. â›“â˜‘ï¸ The purpose of these checks is to avoid double-spending. Double-spending means using the same money to pay for two different transactions. ğŸ§¾ğŸ’µ The ledger is public, but user data is encrypted to protect anonymity. ğŸ”’

Thus, the "miners" must solve mathematical calculations, and the first one who succeeds validates the transaction and gets a transaction fee as remuneration. ğŸ”¢

What does this mean for the environment? ğŸ¤”

However, all these calculations demand many computers who must be working at all times, and, additionally, use energy-intensive cooling systems to cool the computers. ğŸ˜” Generally, these mining computers are grouped together in mining farms. ğŸ’»â›The level of CO2 emissions generated by mining practices depends amongst other things on the source of the electricity. ğŸ’¥ To be more profitable, miners look for the cheapest electricity. ğŸ¥² 

For example, during the rainy season in China, where about half of the world's mining farms are concentrated, there is plenty of cheap electricity from hydroelectric dams. ğŸŒ§ In some provinces, it is even sold 30-40% cheaper than the average electricity price. âš¡ï¸ The concentration of miners in this area is, therefore, higher at these rainy times of the year. ğŸ“ˆ In the dry season, when the cost of hydropower rises, miners will switch to coal-fired power, which is cheaper but more environmentally damaging. ğŸ˜­ğŸ¤¬

Hmm…are there solutions for this? ğŸ¤¨

Some stakeholders who are conscious of their ecological impact (or who wish to reduce their electricity bills) bet on green energy. ğŸ’šğŸ”Œ

This is the intention of the Moonlight Project in Iceland. ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¸ The idea is to create a huge mining farm that relies solely on renewable energy. ğŸ’¨â˜€ï¸ Indeed, Iceland has the advantage of having hydroelectric and geothermal power stations, but also a cold climate, which means that the need for cooling infrastructure is reduced. ğŸ¥¶â„ï¸

For this reason, several stakeholders have chosen to establish mining farms in Iceland. However, it is estimated that 4.5% of the country's total energy consumption comes from cryptocurrency mining. ğŸ˜¯ This is equivalent to the electricity consumption of all Icelandic households combined, and the mining farms bring almost no economic or social value to the country, which makes it less attractive for the country. ğŸ¥µ 

Eco-friendly cryptocurrencies? ğŸ˜

There are a few eco-friendly cryptocurrencies. Sounds great? ğŸ˜ Well, unfortunately, they are not really intended to replace bitcoin and are not yet hugely developed. ğŸ¤• But since it still might be interesting for you to look into them, here are some of the most important ones: 

Peercoin uses a system called "proof-of-stake" which avoids the centralization of calculations on a single computer by distributing the calculation among all the users of the currency. ğŸ’¾ This technique aims to reduce the energy impact that the currency needs for its operation. ğŸ“‰ğŸ‘

SolarCoin uses blockchain technology to encourage the production of solar electricity. ğŸ”†ğŸ”Œ

ECO coins are earned through sustainable actions. In other words, you can now do good and get paid for it! ğŸ¤©

Also the second biggest cryptocurrency Ethereum just implemented a big update, not only did it reduce transaction fees but it switched from the Proof-of-Stake method to the Proof-of-Work concept, significantly reducing energy consumption by up to 99.5%. ğŸ‘€

On your journey to be an impactful investor, you might have struggled to identify what is really impactful and what is not. ğŸ¤”ğŸ¤¯ Exactly for that reason, the European Union has put together the EU Sustainable Finance Taxonomy, a guideline and classification system that makes it easier for investors to identify which activities are sustainable and which are not. ğŸ˜ğŸ‘ Curious now? Us too, so let's explore those new guidelines! ğŸ¤“ 

Okay, I’m listening… 

Well, the taxonomy (i.e. classification) establishes four core requirements that economic activities must meet to be considered sustainable.â™»ï¸ğŸ“— The four conditions to be met, are the following: 

  1. Contribute substantially to one or more of the environmental objectives identified in the Taxonomy regulation ğŸ’ª

  2. Not do significant harm to any of the EU environmental objectives ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸

  3. Meet minimum social safeguards to ensure its sustainability ğŸ¯

  4. Comply with technical screening criteria established by the EU ğŸ–¥

The fourth requirement refers to a huge document of specific criteria that the EU has set out for each specific industry to align with the taxonomy. ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ It’s a very in-depth and hyper-advanced manual for sustainability – if you want to explore it, you can read more about it here. ğŸ“– The other points of the taxonomy are less advanced, but still remain of interest and aim at clarifying what the EU actually means by “environmental objectives” and “safeguards”. ğŸŒ³â›‘ Can’t come up with a good explanation of what this means? Well then let’s start with the former! 

Environmental objectives

The six environmental objectives are listed as follows: ğŸ‘€

  1. Climate change mitigation

  2. Climate change adaptation

  3. The sustainable use and protection of water and marine resources

  4. The transition to a circular economy

  5. Pollution prevention and control

  6. The protection and restoration of biodiversity and ecosystems

In order for a business to make a “substantial contribution” to one of the objectives, it has to fulfill at least one of the following three conditions:  

1ï¸âƒ£ making a direct contribution (e.g. solar energy producers make a  positive impact on the environment by providing a sustainable energy alternative); 

2ï¸âƒ£ enabling other activities to make sustainable contributions through their own activities (such as providing electric buses for public transportation) or;

3ï¸âƒ£ being involved in transition activities, where a company may not be able to operate at low carbon levels, but still maintains to be among the most sustainable for industry's standards  ( e.g. a plastic producer using recycled materials). 

So, in order for an activity to be sustainable according to the EU taxonomy, it must contribute to at least 1 of the three environmental objectives and do no harm to any of the other objectives. ğŸ˜Œ In addition to this, it must meet the minimum safeguards. ğŸ˜

So, now what are the minimum safeguards? ğŸ¤¨

The safeguards refer to guidelines set out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (the OECD) and the United Nations (the UN). Specifically, a business must follow the OECD’s Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.â˜ï¸ These two sets of recommendations are in place to promote responsible business conduct and human rights. ğŸ™Œâ¤ï¸ 

If this all seems very technical, that’s because it is! ğŸ˜” Luckily, though, we as “normal” retail investors don’t have to worry too much about the laws and definitions – that’s on the companies! ğŸ™†‍â™€ï¸ For us, it becomes identifiable if a large EU-based company is sustainable or not simply by whether or not they identify their activities as sustainable. Why is that? Well, if they advertised themselves as sustainable but didn’t meet the EU conditions to do so, they’d be doing so illegally! ğŸ¥³ğŸ¤© Therefore, with the EU Taxonomy, we are at less risk of being tricked by greenwashing. ğŸ¤¥ In other words, it is much easier for us to invest with impact and avoid scams! ğŸ¥´

Now you know everything you need to know about the EU Taxonomy. We hope that this way you will not be tricked and have the chance to make the most impactful decisions. ğŸ¥° Be the movement - make!impact! â¤ï¸
