Maybe, after reading a lot on our website about different stocks, you went and bought some yourself. ğŸ’¸ You also heard that as a shareholder you have certain rights within the company. But you have no idea how this works? ğŸ¤” We are once again here to help you, and teach you about shareholder activism! ğŸ¤©

What is shareholder activism?ğŸ§

Shareholder activism refers to the practices of a "raider".ğŸ¤¨ A raider is an investor who seeks to brutally influence a company's governance to generate a short-term profit by buying or selling capital of the company. ğŸ˜¤ğŸ¤›If you don't know what a stock share is (or you simply do not remember), then you can read this article. The term shareholder activism has a negative connotation among investors, hence the term shareholder engagement is preferred. â˜ï¸

Active shareholders are also those that during  general meetings question the management on non-transparent or ethically questionable practices.ğŸ—£â“ It is generally minority shareholders who demonstrate shareholder engagement at the general meetings of the companies in which they hold shares. Thus, shareholders can push companies to improve their practices in the field of Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG)! â™»ï¸

Shareholder activism became increasingly popular in Europe in recent years, especially with American activist funds, which have different corporate interests than their minority shareholders and where the shareholder actions can potentially destabilise the company. ğŸ¢ğŸ¤• These funds are often seen as a threat because they are perceived as seeking profits at the expense of long-term value creation. On the other hand, not all the funds are like this, but some are rather driven by non-financial motives (e.g. environmental, social, governance, etc.). ğŸ‘€

Shareholder activism is today one of the factors that influence stock prices. ğŸ“ˆğŸ“‰ Its methods and aims differ and can be driven by either  individual or collective interest. ğŸ‘±ğŸ‘¯ There are different tactics that shareholders use in order to become Active shareholders - from media pressure to litigation threats to forcing a conversation and bringing about change.ğŸ“ºğŸ“° One specific and commonly used way to gain decisional power by acquiring voting rights in a listed company is short-selling. ğŸ’° But let’s look a little bit closer at that!

Short-selling 

Short-selling campaigns are characterised by activist funds or activist investors taking a short position on a target company. ğŸ¯ Taking a short position simply means that the investors first borrows and then sells the shares of the company, with the goal of buying the shares later at a lower price to make more profit.ğŸ¤‘ğŸ’² They basically bet on a decrease of the share price in the hopes of earning a lot of money. Some countries like Malaysia see this practice as speculative and therefore do not allow it. ğŸ™… Those funds take huge risks when selling a stock short, because they can lose a huge amount of money!ğŸ¤§ We know that this sounds very theoretical and complex, but don't frown. We will give you an example so you can impress your crush with this knowledge the next time.

Let’s explain this with an example!

When selling a stock-short, you sell shares that you don't own but that you have borrowed. A share is like any other object priced and traded in a market, just like shirts! ğŸ‘šğŸ‘• Imagine that you think the price of a make!mpact shirt is going to fall, so you want to bet on the possible fall. ğŸ¤” Because of this you ask a friend of yours who owns one of the shirts to lend them to you. ğŸ¤ You then sell the shirt at the current price -  let’s say at €200 - then when the price has actually fallen, you buy them back - let’s say at €150 - and give them back to your friend. In the end, you will have earned €50.ğŸ’µ  Easy right?

Don’t be fooled by active funds

Likewise, active funds bet on the fall of the stock price of a target company so as to either to change its management or gain a profit. ğŸ“‰ Funds that have the latter purpose will choose dubious listed companies - e.g. suspected of fraud, financial malpractice, misrepresentation or deficient business models - as their targets and conduct an in-depth investigation of the companies’ financials and operations before selling short. ğŸ•µï¸‍â™€ï¸ Once the stock’s overvaluation is detected and well  documented - e.g. by publishing a report - the fund will short-sell shares in the company and seek to convince other investors to do the same. ğŸ“° If the fund is convincing enough and everyone ends up selling the stock, the share price has fallen . The activist fund has “won” because it has bet on the share price falling and therefore made a profit. ğŸ˜ˆ

An example for such an activist fund would be Muddy Waters Research. It is best known for publishing a report on Sino-Forest Corp, a Chinese company listed in Canada. ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ The report claimed that Sino-Forest had fraudulently inflated its assets and earnings, and that the company's shares were essentially worthless.ğŸ˜µâŒ Sino-Forest's shares fell 82% after the Muddy Waters’ report was published and the company went bankrupt. It is unclear whether Muddy Waters is a whistleblower or illegally manipulating prices. ğŸ¤¥âœï¸ The financial authorities have not ruled on the issue despite strong suspicions about the hedge fund.

As we have mentioned already in  the beginning, there is another growing practice to improve companies' ESG practices: shareholder engagement. ğŸ¤©

Shareholder engagement or campaigns to raise the extra-financial value of an issuer

Through their engagement, shareholders seek to promote greater corporate transparency and/or the application of more honorable policies. ğŸ¥°

The investor practicing shareholder engagement can use one or more levers of influence to induce a company's transformation over the long term. ğŸ”ƒ Here are some of the tactics: 

  • Direct dialogue with the company's management 

  • Voting at annual general meetings (AGMs) that bring together managers, employees, partners and shareholders

  • Public communication with the media on the inadequacies in the governance and operation of a company

  • Legal action with the help of shareholder advocacy groups

  • Informal lobbying of board members, employees, partners and/or other shareholders to build coalitions

  • Impact on management, ranging from freezing positions to divestment

Even if  things are changing, resolutions that try to respond to the current ecological and ethical issues do not get enough favourable votes in most cases. ğŸ˜”

Shareholder engagement could become a real tool to deeply transform the economic model of large companies, but this practice would require minority shareholders to come together and push those changes forward for their common interest. ğŸ™ğŸ¼âœŠ Let this inspire you and go make the most out of your voting rights and become and active shareholder. ğŸ˜› Till next time - Be the movement. Whether you have been using it to find the true love of your life or just as a hot-or-not game, many people nowadays use dating apps to meet new people. â¤ï¸ğŸ”¥ğŸš« However, dating apps are often also associated with catfishes, bad pick-up lines, and even gender inequality. ğŸ¥´ If you are trying to avoid the last aspect, then maybe Bumble would be an option for you. ğŸ‘Š And even if you are not looking to meet people, Bumble might be a buzzing investment option to look into. ğŸ“ˆ

Okay… but what exactly is Bumble? ğŸ

Bumble is a dating app where only women can make the first move and start a conversation with male matches within the first 24 hours from the match. ğŸ™‹‍â™€ï¸1ï¸âƒ£ It was founded by Whitney Wolfe Herd, a former employee and co-founder of Tinder, who wanted to prioritize women’s needs after a sexual harassment case. ğŸ¤¯ğŸ™…

If you have been single during the pandemic, you might have realized that it forced many people to use online platforms to meet new people and possibly find a fling. ğŸ˜ With more than 12.3 million monthly active users worldwide and 700 employees in three continents, Bumble has a market share of 19% among US dating apps in 2020, making it the second-largest dating app after Tinder. ğŸŒğŸ˜® People usually associate it with dating, however, Bumble also offers options for finding friends and job networking - all accessible from the same account.

Overall, the app design and features are intended for users to create detailed profiles, since the more detailed information users share, the more likely the algorithm will match users successfully.  ğŸ’‘

The company makes its revenue with Premium features. ğŸ’¸ğŸ¤‘ With a similar model to rival apps, users join and use the core functions for free but can pay for additional perks and features. The bulk of the company’s revenue comes from in-app purchases and different subscription offerings which e.g. make the profile more prominent and therefore can lead to more matches. ğŸ”¥â˜‘ï¸

 

Sustainable Development Goals

Now, you might have been asking yourself what a dating app like Bumble has to do with SDGs? ğŸ¤” Well, they focus on contributing to SDG 5: Gender Equality! 

 

SDG 5: Gender Equality 

In many cultures worldwide, it is still expected of the man to make the first move. But as we all know, this can be just as disappointing for both parties. ğŸ˜ğŸ™„ Bumble flips this norm around by making “woman-first” the new normal. ğŸ¤©ğŸ‘© We might wonder: Is this approach effective to achieve more balanced dating dynamics in men and women relationships? ğŸ¤¨

Well, if Bumble' mission is to empower women’s awareness by starting-up conversations with partners who they believe live up to their ambitions as well as protecting them from potential harassment, men should also benefit from this as they would be saved from catchy pickup lines and desperate attempts to demonstrate true interests when starting a conversation. ğŸ—£ğŸ“²

Wait! - How does Bumble deal with gender fluidity? ğŸ§‘

On Bumble you are allowed to select among more than 50 gender-identity options as well as to which sex(es) to be visible. Users can also “suggest another option”. ğŸ˜ Matches of the same gender can both be first-movers. ğŸ˜ It is less clear how it works for non-binary individuals and who can be first-movers. Although the concept behind Bumble does not make it the most effective platform for the LGBTQ community, the Gender Identity Option is a significant feature of inclusivity.  ğŸ¥³ğŸ³ï¸‍ğŸŒˆ

Supporting victims of sexual harassment ğŸ˜£

Did you know that women are about twice as likely as their male counterparts to be victims of some form of sexual harassment? ğŸ˜¢ Of 224 dating app users, 84% claimed to have experienced assault or harassment after using a dating app or have been matched with a sex offender/inappropriate person, according to an investigation by ProPublica, while one third has reported a sexual assault to a platform and almost half of those users have never heard back! ğŸ¤¬

After reported cases of sexual harassment and verbal violence among users, Bumble has decided to partner up with Bloom - a survivor-led nonprofit that creates resources to support the healing of survivors of gender-based violence - and offer up to six therapy sessions, access to a library of resources by trauma-focused therapists as well as one-to-one chat support. ğŸ˜‡ğŸ‘ One could cynically argue the action being simply a marketing strategy move and that Bumble creators could come up with better technology that attempts to prevent harassment from happening at all. ğŸ˜¬ However, it is remarkable that no other competitor has taken action to provide psychological support to the victims yet. â˜ï¸ If not enough is done to prevent the phenomenon of sexual harassment, the firms’ reputation might suffer as victims might delete their accounts permanently. 

ESG risks

Very little can be found about sustainability efforts and hopefully, more will be disclosed by the end-of-the-year annual report. Nonetheless, a Code of Conduct with values and principles for doing business with integrity is already in place. ğŸ“š

Environmental factors: 

The company is already outsourcing most of its data and cloud provision services to companies prioritizing renewable energy, including wind and solar power. Bumble pledges to achieve carbon neutrality by 2025. ğŸ’¨â˜€ï¸ They do so with partnerships with organizations committed to fighting climate change like the nonprofit Amazon Watch. ğŸ¤

Social factors:

In the Code of Conduct, the refusal of “human trafficking, slavery, child labor, etc.” as well as “providing proper working conditions, hours, and compensation to all Bumble employees” are mentioned. Employees can visit an intranet policy page where there is a contact person for help in case of violations or abuses. ğŸ“‘

Customer Data Protection

The app matching algorithm exploits users’ data analytics to create successful matches. ğŸ¤– Therefore, earning and keeping the users’ trust and stakeholders is essential for maintaining its reputation and sustaining growth. ğŸ“ˆğŸ’¸ Cookies are used for different purposes: For example, basic/mandatory ones ensure smooth functionality of the app while analytical cookies store insights are used to improve Bumble’s business strategy – e.g. the one that tracks ad campaigns used on the site. 

Governance factors:

If Bumble tries to overturn the standards of patriarchal dating dynamics, this is also coherent with the composition of its Board. Out of 11 Directors, only 3 are male members. ğŸ’ª Three is also the number of independent directors - i.e. all the members of the Audit & Risk Committee. 

Financials 

 

 

 

Bumble Inc. is the parent company of both the Bumble and the Badoo app. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ‘§‍ğŸ‘¦ The latter accounted for 38% of Bumble Group´s total revenues, while the rest came from Bumble’s App in 2020. The group only went public in February 2021. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’» As only a few months have passed since the IPO, the stock price trend tells us very little and seems to hover around its average of $50. âš–ï¸

The company had a negative EBIT (loss) of $105.76 million in 2020. â¬‡ï¸ğŸ™ƒ This equals a year-to-year decrease of 53% despite a growth in total revenues of 11% to the previous year. ğŸ§ Even though the introduction of new premium features and a new pricing strategy including different pricing tiers have driven revenue growth, the loss can be explained by a significant acquisition and due-diligence costs due to the acquisition of Worldwide Vision Limited, owner of several dating apps. â˜ï¸ The main reason for the acquisition is the company’s attempt to fight competition by buying and shutting down competitors while using data insights to strengthen its own apps Bumble and Badoo. ğŸ¤º

Furthermore, in 2020 and Q1-Q2 2021 the expansion into new geographies entailed higher costs relating to marketing efforts and features development. ğŸŒğŸ“ˆ These investments are expected to continue for the rest of 2021. 

The P/E multiple for Bumble is extremely high compared to Match Group and combined with Bumble’s EPS of $0.11 versus Match Group’s $1.93, reflects Bumble being a young company in which investors see very high growth potential. ğŸ˜ğŸ‘ Investors are willing to pay a price equivalent to 465x its current earnings. ğŸ˜² We compare Bumble to the Match Group, its main competitor and the company behind popular dating apps like Tinder, Hinge, and others. The Match Group, on the other hand, is more mature, listed since 2015, and trades at 73x multiples. ğŸ‘€ But a significant difference is Bumble’s profit margin, which is almost double to Match Group’s profit margin and implies that operations and resources are spent much more efficiently and that costs are well-minimized. ğŸ˜ Overall, one needs to be aware that the Dating App industry is very easy-to-enter and highly competitive. ğŸ¤•

While empowering women is embroidered into Bumble’s mission and set-up, it is questionable if this can effectively lead to more equal outcomes in heterosexual relationships. ğŸ˜¬ The company's actions seem to live up to the values of integrity and respect that it aims to promote through its platforms and services - focusing on the support of women victims of sexual harassment and committing to achieving carbon neutrality by 2025. ğŸ‘â¤ï¸ Financially, the company has not reached maturity yet. Despite its sustained revenue growth and focus on expanding heavily, Bumble belongs to the Dating Apps Industry with many players and whose competitive landscape is hard to predict. ğŸ“Š

Who knows what the Dating App industry will look like 10 years from now? ğŸ¤· We will support Bumble's effort and swipe right on this investment. ğŸ‘‰ Of course, don’t forget to do your own research and build your own opinion. Be the movement – make!mpact!

Once upon a time in the 1960’s, an idea changed humanity forever.ğŸ’¡ An idea that helped us connect computers to each other. Today, you might know this as the Internet. ğŸ–¥ğŸ’¾

By only mentioning the word Internet, we allude to a little known world with such a rich history. And in this huge world the search engines take one of the most important places. ğŸ”ğŸ¤–Whether you use them at your job, at home or even on your smartphone, search engines are inevitable for almost all internet users to find to the numerous websites you use on a daily basis. But do you know about the impact search engines can have? ğŸ¤” Then let us find out…

 

 

So, what is a search engine? ğŸ¤—

You probably use a search engine, sometimes even several, and you probably have just used one to arrive at this article, but maybe it never occurred to you to know what it actually is. ğŸ˜¬

To break it down, a search engine is a software developed to execute search on the web. This means that before search engines, the only way to access a website was to type its URL. âœï¸ğŸ˜« Well yes, you know that thing: www.iamanexample.com/a_complex_one/. But if you did not know the exact URL, there was no chance to arrive at your desired destination….ğŸ¤¯ So, fortunately now we only need to search Iamanexample on a search engine as Google, Yahoo, Bing, Qwant, Baidu…  and it suggests options which include this text (or alike texts) and help you access the wanted website. ğŸ˜ğŸ‰ Simple, efficient: perfect!

 

 

Got it.. but how do they make money? ğŸ’¸

There are a few ways a search engine can make money. The Search engines mainly make money with advertisements.ğŸ’²ğŸš© For search results, this entails that certain websites will be shown higher in peoples results either by showing the websites as specifically labelled advertisement or as belonging to your results. #ï¸âƒ£ However, they also make money from selling the Data they collect from marketing and consumer habits. ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ You were probably asked before to enable certain “Cookies”. ğŸªCookies are data files which are supposed to improve your online experience by saving information of your browsing experience to tailor the content better to you.ğŸ’¾ Often, this data is analyzed and will be sold to third parties.ğŸ“² This can be problematic, because if not done safely enough it can be a real harm to the customers privacy. ğŸ˜³

 

 

Big technologies require lots of energy ğŸ“ˆ

As you can probably assume, the computers needed for those search engines are very complex and running the processes at the data centers requires lots of energy.ğŸ”‹ To make it more visual to you, did you know that every time you look something up on google, the same energy could be used to light up a 60 watt light bulb for 17 seconds?! ğŸ’¡Just imagine, how many searches you conduct on a daily basis. We bet that your lightbulb would be shining all day...ğŸ”†âš ï¸However, also a big difference in energy consumption depends on the time spent on one single search. The longer the search - a.k.a. the inquiry - takes, the more energy is consumed and the bigger is the carbondixodie consumption! ğŸ“ˆ Therefore, it is best to use a quick search engine or even better: simply type in the URL by yourself without using a search engine.â˜ï¸

 

 

Alternative Search Engines ğŸ‘€

After reading all of this, you might be traumatised and not able to use a search engine ever again. ğŸ˜¨We have some good news for you. There are some search engines which focus on solving those issues and try to contribute to society and the environment. ğŸ¤©ğŸ¥³ Here are some of our favorites:

Ecosia 

Ecosia uses renewable sources to power its data centers. â™»ï¸ For this, they even build their own solar plants instead of using external sources to provide them.ğŸ”† On top of that: they use their profits to plant trees and reduce the carbon impact created with their searches due to their browser. ğŸŒ³ğŸŒ²

 

 

Qwant

If you are very concerned about the storage of your data, then Qwant might be an option to try for you. ğŸ•µï¸‍â™€ï¸ They do not track your data and therefore do not sell it to third-parties. ğŸ™Œ They make their money from advertisements which are generated with the help of the Microsoft Bing ad network. 

Ekoru

Ekoru donates 60% of their income to different charities. Those charities aim at different goals like reforestation, climate action, animal welfare etc. ğŸ¤ Just like Ecosia, they use renewable resources to power its searches. â˜€ï¸ğŸ’¨ ğŸŒŠ And even better - they do not save any search related data on their servers to protect privacy. The only pitfall is that this search engine is currently not available all over the world. ğŸŒğŸ˜”

 

 

GiveWater

GiveWater aims at improving water situations and sanitation all over the world. ğŸ’§ Just like Ekoru, search results are powered through Bing and they make money from advertisements. It is a non-profit company and considers  themselves a social impact search engine.ğŸ’ª

How efficient are competitors? 

If you are still not convinced of switching in the fear that all your comfort of using your current search engine will be gone, let us give you another reason.ğŸ—£ As we mentioned earlier, most alternative search engines use the Microsoft Bing ad network for their searches. Studies have shown that people perceive the relevance of the results as about the same compared to the biggest competitor google.ğŸ¤™ So, this means that there will be no significant loss in comfort and additionally by switching you do good for the world! ğŸ¥°

 

 

Have you changed your search engine yet?ğŸ¤ª If not, it is time to find a search engine that fights those world problems that keep you up at night and use it.ğŸ˜ It is a simple way  to contribute to a better world. That is it from us. Be the movement - make!mpact! â¤ï¸

The first thing that you associate with the term Doughnut is very likely a sugary.. delicious..pastry. ğŸ© Yum!ğŸ˜‹ However, we will introduce your neurons to another association: Doughnut Economies! ğŸ¤©This one might not make your mouth water, but it sure is worth knowing. ğŸ¤¤

 

 

The foundation of the theory 

Doughnut economics is based on the observation that the current economic model is not a right fit for the world in which we live in today. This means that the current way of living is not sustainable.ğŸ˜± Firstly, because it has a high negative impact on the environment and secondly, because it does not meet the objectives of social justice. ğŸ“‰ğŸ¥´

Now you might ask yourself: how can we combine social justice with environmental issues in order to direct the economy towards sustainable and inclusive  development for all? ğŸ˜Ÿ And this is exactly where Kate Raworth comes in. ğŸšªIn 2008, during a presentation on the challenges for  countries to develop,  a diagram showing  the "planet boundaries or limits" and the ongoing overshoot  in the use of planetary resources, gave her the inspiration for a new theoretical model. ğŸ’¡Her model includes the natural sciences to show the economy how far it can or cannot go. ğŸ˜² Thus, it will develop a new vision of the economy that will take into account the 9 planet boundaries. ğŸ”›

Planetary… what?

The “boundaries” or “ecological ceilings” refer to nine natural processes that together allow and regulate the stability of the biosphere.ğŸ¤“ A biosphere is the collection of all ecosystems. ğŸ”ƒ Scientists have managed to quantify 7 of them, with 4 of them already crossed! ğŸ¥µ The planetary boundaries are:

â¡ï¸ climate change

â¡ï¸ biodiversity loss

â¡ï¸ biogeochemical

â¡ï¸ ocean acidification

â¡ï¸ land use

â¡ï¸ freshwater

â¡ï¸ ozone depletion

â¡ï¸ atmospheric aerosols

â¡ï¸ chemical pollution

 

 

But what about social justice? How does the Doughnut model take it into account? ğŸ¤¨ Raworth introduces internal limits ("social floor"), corresponding to essential human needs for a decent life.ğŸ‘Š It lists 11 “necessities” or “dimensions of life”, forming the "social foundation" which strongly resembles the UN SDGs. ğŸ˜

Thus, the area between the environmental ceiling and the social foundation represents a safe space for humanity, in which an inclusive and sustainable economy can thrive. ğŸ¥³ This takes the shape of a doughnut, hence the name Doughnut Economy. If you still can not grasp what it looks like, then we have a picture for you:

 

The principles of change

To fight those planetary boundaries, Raworth created 7 principles for a change from the classical economic theory to a more relevant and suitable one. ğŸ’ª But let’s look a little bit closer at them!

Principle 1: Change the goal from GDP to the Doughnut

GDP measures the economic output i.e. production activity of a country, but this indicator  does not respond to current environmental and social challenges.ğŸ’¸â™»ï¸

 

 

Principle 2: See the big picture, from self-contained market to embedded economy

Self-contained markets are narrow-minded and only take the big actors such as businesses, governments and households into account. âœï¸ However, It is not possible to think of an economy that is disconnected from nature and society. â›”ï¸ Therefore, we need to shift towards an embedded economy, which includes the earth and everyone who lives in it. Therefore, the shift has to go from a self-contained market. â†ªï¸

….. to an embedded market: 

 

Principle 3: nurture human nature, from rational economic man to social adaptable humans

Classical economics presents the individual as rational, selfish and attracted to money. ğŸ‘¹ Rather, this view should take into account empathy, mutual aid, cooperation but also the fact that desires and values fluctuate in time. It should take into account our environment and the idea that we are dependent on nature and not that we dominate it. ğŸŒ³ğŸ

 

 

 

Principle 4: Get savvy with systems from mechanical equilibrium to dynamic complexity

We wanted to make economics a science, and we ended up with economic models that are not flexible but biased. ğŸ¤¯ Economic thinking must not remain static but must integrate the permanent evolutions of our world. ğŸŒ

Principle 5: Design to distribute from growth 

The Kuznets curve models, developed in the 50s, suggests that inequality would "mechanically" reduce as a country's economic activity grows. This theory is now criticized: it is observed that the rich keep getting richer and the poor keep getting poorer. Raworth invites us now, not to perceive inequalities as normal but as a failure of the current economic model. âš–ï¸

Figure Kuznets curve

Principle 6: Create to regenerate 

There is nothing that justifies that growth would lead to an improvement in the quality of the environment. Growth requires more and more resources and infrastructure that harm the environment. ğŸ§ªğŸ’€ Therefore, we need to think of processes that are circular in place of the produce, consume and throw-away norm.ğŸ”ƒ

Principle 7: Be agnostic about growth 

While the focus of countries should be on remaining inside the safe area of the Doughnuts and therefore the respect of the social and environmental limits should remain the priority, the countries should be indifferent about growth in terms of GDP.  ğŸ“Š

 

 

Doughnut economics is already an inspiration for policies for cities like  Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Brussels, Nanaimo, Philadelphia and Portland but we are still far from seeing this sustainable economic framework as the new norm. ğŸ™ We hope that this inspired you to change your perspective of current economic models. Don’t forget, be the movement - makeImpact!  â¤ï¸

From Düsseldorf to Zagreb for just 8€! Cheap Airlines like Ryanair or Eurowings offer prices, which might even be cheaper than buying a pizza. âœˆï¸ğŸ• Sounds like a great way to get the most out of your money! ğŸ¤‘ But now you might be asking yourself what the catch is here? Well, the costs do not reflect the true price of the product or service. ğŸ¤• But, let us better explain what true pricing means!

 

 

True prices are based on true costs

Before starting to look at true prices, we have to understand the concept of true costs. The true cost of a product entails not only the “conventional” costs - see transport or materials - but shall also take into account  social and environmental costs  such as underpayment of labour, greenhouse emissions, and declining biodiversity.ğŸ› ğŸ“¦ğŸ’¨ Those not accounted-for costs are also referred to as negative-externalities. ğŸ¤­

You might be wondering what the problem with those negative-externalities is? Right, the problem with true costs is that the current consumers or producers do not pay them, but they are being pushed onto future generations, taxpayers or even other individuals among the value chain.ğŸ”œ So, they are not accounted for in the product! ğŸ¤¥

 

 

Okay… but what is the true price of a product now?!

The true price of a product includes the true costs and the market price.ğŸ™Œ This means that not only internal factors for the product are considered but also external factors. So, imagine that when you buy a banana, the price consists of the price you would usually pay and additional costs to improve negative externalities. ğŸ“ˆ

To help you understand this a little bit better, let us look at an example. So, you buy a make!mpact pen for 5€ in the store. ğŸ’µ But that is not the true price for the pen because it does not take into account the CO2 emission, the water pollution and  accident insurance for the workers that occur during the production process. ğŸš±â˜ ï¸â›½ï¸ To balance out the negative externalities caused by this pen, you have to pay 1€ for the CO2 emission compensation, 0,5€ for the water pollution and 0,5 € for workers’ insurance. ğŸ’ª Overall, the true price for this pen would now be 7€, instead of just 5€. The difference between those prices, the 2 € for external costs, is also known as the true-price gap. ğŸ˜ Seems simple!

 

 

And how do you determine the true price of a product?

There are several different methods on how to determine the true price of a product. ğŸ“ğŸ”„ One of them is the right-based approach which takes into account a set of commonly used laws and regulations like the Declaration of human rights.âš–ï¸ğŸ“” The organization behind the true price, the true price foundation, states that all companies should follow those set rules even when they legally do not have to. â˜ï¸ Then, it should be considered which negative externalities take place due to the purchase of this product and how to quantify the prices for those externalities.ğŸ“Š For this purpose, methods such as life-cycle assessment can be used. ğŸ¢ And after we know the extent of the negative externality, we can value and convert the negative externality into a monetary value. ğŸ’´ This then should include both restoration and compensation costs for the negative externality.

 

 

Why is this not the norm?

If you are now wondering why we do not already do this for all products, you have to know that there are problems in our current market according to the true price foundation. ğŸ˜¬ Firstly, the market does not give any incentives to include those costs. ğŸ›’ Secondly, remediation, giving back to the hurt causes, is on our market not done often and often hard to do. And lastly, there is no transparency on the true costs.ğŸ¥¸ This means that the true costs have to be identified and where they come from, which many companies do not want to disclose. ğŸ“ƒ More stringent regulation for example when it comes to greenhouse emissions ceilings, is already spurting companies to cut on those externalities or compensate for those. However, supply chains are so globally widespread that some externalities risk not being priced in, especially in countries where labour rights are not legally enforced. ğŸš“ğŸš¨ Therefore, it is up to us consumers to be critical about ESGs-impact of the products and services we purchase while not getting hyped suspiciously low-priced products.â˜ï¸ And also, the acceptance to pay the true price amongst the consumers is not there yet, as most customers prefer to pay less, rather than the true costs. 

 

 

Is there anyone who actually uses it?

Yes! There are some companies which already use the true costs to price their products. ğŸ˜ An example of this is the german supermarket chain Penny which for an assortment of products increased their prices and showed the difference in conventional and true prices. ğŸ‘ Also, there are some firms which are transparent about their production and show how they calculate the true price of their products. ğŸ§®

 Now you know what the true price of a product is! Maybe you can consider all those influences on the product next time you think about buying something. Be the movement! MakeImpact.  â¤ï¸

You might have experienced the thrill of completing the last assignment of that online course that you needed for a university project. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ“âœ… Or maybe you just completed a course about that newly trending topic everyone talks about on social media.ğŸ“² Coursera probably sounds familiar then! Today, we will introduce you to the world of Coursera, which could be an option for your education and portfolio! ğŸ“š

 

Course… who? ğŸ§

Founded in 2012 by Stanford University computer science professors Andrew Ng and Daphne Koller, Coursera Inc. is an American Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) provider. On their online platform, one can find more than 4000 contents among online courses, certifications, and degrees in a variety of subjects organized in partnership with more than 200 partners among top-universities and other organizations! ğŸ˜³ğŸ”

FYI: On Coursera most of the online courses can be accessed for free while the company raises about 61% of its revenue for certificates of completion; 28% from training contents for enterprises and 12% from Degrees courses. ğŸ’¸

Okay, but why do more people learn online?

Recently, growth in online learning can be explained mainly by three factors: 

1. The pandemic has created irreversible changes not only to enterprises but also to educational institutions.ğŸ”€ From 2020 the e-learning market is expected to grow at a compound annual rate of 21% percent until 2027 and hit 1 trillion dollars! ğŸ“ˆ

2. Economic disruption and the need to develop skills for a digital future lead people to learn online.ğŸ–¥ Skills that were valued just three years ago may no longer be relevant and therefore there is a need for constant training and updating of knowledge. ğŸ‹ï¸‍â™€ï¸

3. And there is a shift in employers' demand.  Employers no longer just look at degrees but skills - e.g. see the case of Google hiring criteria - and this is exactly where platforms like Coursera play in, though offering new professional career certificates. ğŸ‘€ğŸ«  

Sustainable Development Goals 

Coursera’s Impact Report 2020 gives a good overview of their contribution towards the SDGs. So let us have a look at how they want to contribute to a better world! ğŸŒâ¤ï¸

 

SDG 4: Quality Education

Coursera wants to Provide universal access to world-class learning.ğŸ¤“ To do so, they partner up with over 150 globally acknowledged top-universities worldwide as well as offer training programs to employees and management for universal corporations such as Microsoft, L’Oreal, PayPal, just to name a few. ğŸ˜²ğŸ¥‡ We believe that this can be a quite good signal of the quality and relevance of its contents. ğŸ’¯ In particular, offering a wide range of courses aimed at developing practical skills, Coursera helps students and young professionals to meet the gap between employers’ ever-growing demand for new skills and the more traditionally academic knowledge provided by Universities. ğŸ’¼

SDG 8: Decent work and Economic growth 

Coursera's surveys show more than positive feedback meaning that many claims to have reported career benefits including a promotion pay increase or a new job.ğŸ¤© It is also significant to see that in 2020, the top 5 countries for learner growth are all from South East Asia or Latin America with rates from 107% (Philippines)  to 192% (Bangladesh). 

SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities 

We all know how much education is critical for social change. The course offer is for free and therefore you only need an internet connection to build up your skills on Coursera.ğŸ”Œ Its Impact Report 2020 shows an outpour of  $300 m in scholarships, equivalent to costs saved through free access to content on Coursera, for people lacking financial resources. ğŸ˜³ In addition, since 2016 Coursera has fostered an initiative across 140 countries to provide learning for tens of thousands of refugees through partnerships with no-profits. Other partnerships with no-profits involve formerly incarcerated and justice-involved individuals by delivering free skills training needed to prepare for employment opportunities and re-entry into the community. ğŸ“

SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

In addition, along with its multi-stakeholder partners, Coursera mobilizes and shares knowledge and expertise to support the achievement of sustainable development goals, in particular developing countries (see all the contents tackling SDG-related challenges).  ğŸ™Œ

 

ESG Overview

Coursera is B Corp-certified, which is awarded to businesses that meet the highest standards of verified social and environmental performance, public transparency, and legal accountability to balance profit and purpose.ğŸ†ğŸ’ª Coursera’s overall score is 84.9 - with 80 being the minimum score to qualify as B Corp. The B Impact Assessment is divided into five stakeholder-focused "Impact Areas" - Governance, Workers, Community, Environment, and Customers - which refer to the impact of a company’s day-to-day operations. â›‘ğŸ§¾ğŸ› Coursera's impact of their Business Model is also evaluated which can add additional credit to the score. 

Environmental factors:

When it comes to the Impact Area “Environment”, Coursera scores pretty poorly, to say the least. ğŸ‘The score of 3.1 out of 20 points is obtained by adding up the scores of four sub-areas - Environmental Management (0% of full score!), Air & Climate (11%) , Water (15%), Land & Life (50%).ğŸ¤¬ On the company’s website, there is no mention of their environmental sustainability strategy and probably this confirms that it is lagging behind on these matters.ğŸ¤¨ Like other Internet Services companies, Coursera should make sure that the energy used to maintain data and cloud centers comes from renewables. ğŸ’¨â˜€ï¸

 

Social factors: Workers, Community, Customers:

Coursera scored the highest among the area of workers’ treatment. Especially, when it comes to the sub-areas of Financial Security of its employees and Career Development. ğŸ¦ğŸ““ Furthermore, Coursera gains additional credits in the Customer grading: from the Impact of its Business Model (a.k.a. IBMs), in particular with respect to the Quality and Continuous Improvement, Educational Outcomes, Privacy and Consumer Protection of its Business Model. ğŸ˜Differently, when it comes to Community factors, the overall score is only 25%, with particularly low rates in Diversity, Equity & Inclusion, Economic Impact (6%), Civic Engagement & Giving, Supply Chain Management (4%, the lowest). ğŸ˜

Governance factors:

This Impact Area includes Mission & Engagement  and Ethics & Transparency - both relating to the company’s operations. They also gained extra points for Mission Locked - which is intended as an alignment of the company’s Governance structure to its Mission or in other words, that takes decisions considering both shareholders and stakeholders' interests i.e. the students and enterprises. ğŸ¥³ğŸ¥³

Financials

Coursera has just recently gone public, in March 2021. Since the IPO, its market price seems to have trended downwards. ğŸ“‰

In the last four years,  EBIT has resulted in a loss over and this has continued for the first and second quarter in 2021.1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£ In 2020, Coursera has registered an unprecedented growth in revenues and customers. The exceptional growth was mainly caused by the pandemic-induced mega trend of online education.ğŸ’¥ Coursera expects to continue growing, however, at a much lower rate than 2020. The company's 2021 full-year outlook calls for about a 26% growth in revenue, which is good, but a far cry from 2020’s 58% growth.ğŸ“Š The company will continue to “incur significant expense in technology and content development to launch a new offering or program” as a strategy to increase customer retention and expansion. In this regard, the company has spent 69% of its gross profit in marketing operations in 2020. ğŸ’²ğŸ’²

Currently, most of the company's revenue and gross profit come from the people buying certificates.ğŸ”– Coursera's degree segment, where they collaborate with universities, is all profit since course content is provided by the educational institutionğŸ‘©‍ğŸ“ğŸ«. The expansion of the degree offer may attract brand-new customers and be a compelling source of revenue growth for the future.

Coursera classifies as a Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs). When it comes to competitors we find that: some are still currently privately-owned (see Udemy, Udacity etc.), some are no-profit (see EdX, Khan Academy) while some belong to major listed groups (see LinkedIn Learning, delisted and acquired by Microsoft in 2016). ğŸ“œğŸ˜µ‍ğŸ’«Therefore, as a comparison, we choose the only somewhat closely listed company Duolingo, an e-learning platform focusing on the learning of languages and also just gone public in July 2021. ğŸ¤“

When compared with the latter, Coursera's multiples don’t give evidence of over-valuation if compared as well as it shows a relatively low D/E ratio, 3.05 (vs Duolingo’s 9.50).  

Conclusion

All right, to sum up, all of this information: Coursera is among the market leaders in the MOOC industry and through free-access to quality content worldwide allows people from all backgrounds to build relevant skills and knowledge to unlock new opportunities leading to a better life, especially in the least developed countries. ğŸ†ğŸ¤ Some SDGs easily fit into the company's mission, especially regarding social and governance factors. Its environmental factors need some severe improvement. ğŸ˜± Especially, as there is no information about the source of energies used to run its operations. Despite the lack of profitability, the company is financially sound. ğŸ¤Œ Growth in revenues is to stabilize after the pandemic but might still benefit from the 2-digit growth of the e-learning sector, forecasted  for the next 5 years. ğŸ“ˆ

The challenge for the company will be to invest in new content and programs relevant to users and for which the latter are willing to pay for as well as cope with a densely competitive market.  

We hope that you gained some helpful insights about Coursera and its position on the market. Hopefully, this inspired you to learn more and support some good projects. ğŸ“•Remember, to always do your own research. Till then, be the movement - make!mpact â¤ï¸

You have probably heard of Bill Gates before. He did not only found Microsoft, which among other things helped him become the 4th richest man in 2021 with an estimated fortune of 124 billion US dollars, he is also an investor.ğŸ˜³ğŸ’¸ With his investments he earned 16 billion dollars in 2020!ğŸ˜± Now you are probably curious how he did that because you want to achieve similar results… Well, we will present to you today how Bill Gates invests! ğŸ˜

 

 

Computer scientist, entrepreneur but also philanthropist, Bill Gates has also dedicated himself to his and his ex-wife Melinda Gates’ foundation, The Bill-and-Melinda-Gates’s Foundation. They are helped by Warren Buffett who is none other than his friend and mentor but who also happens to be the 6th largest fortune in the world. ğŸ¤µ‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ’ª

Bill Gates privately invests through his holding company Cascade Investment.  Unfortunately, we do not have access to his entire personal portfolio, however, Bill Gates' fortune via (Cascade Investment) and the Bill & Melinda Gates Trust are managed by the same person, Michael Larson.ğŸ¤“ The investment strategies employed in both companies are broadly the same.ğŸ‘ And good news, the foundation's portfolio is public! So, let's roll and look at the first few stocks of Bill & Melinda Gates Trust's portfolio. ğŸ²

 

 

What Strategy do they use in their portfolio now? ğŸ˜¬

The investment strategy of the Bill & Melinda Gates fund seems to follow a defensive and long-term logic. It is easy to understand that Bill Gates wants to preserve his wealth and even more so the financial assets of his foundation.ğŸ’°ğŸ¤‘ The companies are carefully chosen: They are leaders in their field, difficult to compete with, and globally little affected by the economic booms and busts situation. ğŸ¢ğŸŒ

They are also companies that distribute attractive dividends without compromising their self-financing, compared to others (some which distribute generous dividends without having sufficient cash).

 

 

Give us some insights into Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation portfolio!

 

 

 

Berkshire Hathaway (50% of the Portfolio's capital)

Berkshire Hathaway is none other than the investment company founded by Warren Buffett - yes! ğŸ¢ Bill's friend which was mentioned before - recognized by many as one of the greatest investors. ğŸ¥³ The fund is very diversified: the companies are carefully selected. They represent a good sample of American companies. We find Apple, Coca-Cola, American Express...ğŸğŸ¥ƒğŸ’³ Thanks to its diversification, this part of the portfolio can be considered safe.

Waste Management (10%) 

This is the largest waste collection and recycling company in North America.ğŸ—‘ğŸš® Waste Management is another secure investment because regardless of the economic climate, people continue to produce waste that must be treated and collected. ğŸ›¢

Caterpillar (9%)

They are the leading manufacturer of construction machinery.ğŸšœ Its activity is more cyclical, meaning that: when economic activity is good, infrastructure construction booms, but when the economy is suffering, the construction industry suffers very much along. ğŸ”ƒ Nevertheless, over the long term, Caterpillar has a good financial performance and pays generous dividends. 

Canadian National Railway (6%)

As its name suggests, it is one of Canada's largest railroads specializing in freight transportation.ğŸš… After the acquisition of various American companies, the company extended to the United States. It has strategic axes that connect the Pacific coast to the Atlantic coast and another axis that goes to the Gulf of Mexico.ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ This network is perfect for transporting goods from the ports to the land and vice versa. ğŸ›³ The company's financial performance is good and the dividends paid are constantly increasing. ğŸ“ˆ

Walmart (4.5%)

Walmart is one of the largest retail chains in the world. ğŸ›’ğŸ› Thanks to its size, the company can make economies of scale and is less impacted by e-commerce (like Amazon) than other companies in the sector. Its stock price is constantly increasing.

 

Okay, but what do we know now about his personal portfolio (Cascade investment)?

On top of the companies part of the Foundation’s portfolio, Gates adds the following to his personal portfolio:  

Microsoft 

Being the founder of Microsoft, he naturally has shares in the company. However, not wishing to put all his eggs in one basket, he gradually reallocates his investments to the investments of his holding cascade investment. ğŸ“Š Currently he has 103.4 million shares, valued at $26 billion, or 1.3 % of Microsoft's outstanding shares.ğŸ¤ª

 

Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts

World leader in luxury hotels. ğŸ¨ğŸ An agreement is underway for Bill Gates' holding company to take control of the group. If all goes well, Cascades will own 71.25% of Four Seasons in January. ğŸ™Œ

 

 

Farmland 

In recent years, the billionaire has invested heavily in farmland, becoming the largest landowner in the USA. ğŸŒ¾ğŸ‘©‍ğŸŒ¾ He is said to own about 100,000 hectares spread across the country.ğŸ

Cascade Investments' advisors believe that farmland is a good and relatively stable investment. At the end of March, an Internet user asked Bill Gates directly, during a forum organized on Reddit to promote his new book on climate change: "Hey Bill, why invest so much in agriculture?". The billionaire's answer was: "No, it's not climate related, it's just a good investment". âœï¸

 

Plant-based meat: Impossible Foods and Beyond Meat

Both companies produce meat and cheese substitutes made entirely from plants. ğŸ¥©ğŸ§€ Beyond Meat is best known for its chicken substitute. Impossible Food is best known for its "impossible burger" made entirely from plants. ğŸ” When you know the pollution emitted by beef farming, it is easy to understand why Bill Gates invested in these companies !ğŸ˜

 

TerraPower 

Bill Gates is a co-founder of TerraPower. They are designing advanced nuclear reactors called traveling wave reactors, which are composed of an enriched uranium core. ğŸ”‹

 

Breakthrough Energy Ventures

Founded by Bill Gates in 2015, this is an investment fund that aims to accelerate innovation in sustainable energy and other technologies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. â™»ï¸ğŸ’¨â˜€ï¸ It invests in a variety of startups that are trying to commercialize new concepts such as nuclear fusion, high-capacity batteries to store renewable energy and biofuels generated by microbes. 

 

So what is the bottom line of Bill Gates strategy?ğŸ¤” He prioritizes American companies with a focus on investing over the long term. He has a rather defensive profile: he chooses rather safe companies and does not hesitate to invest in technology, AI and anything that represents the future for the tech industry.ğŸ¤–ğŸ“Ÿ Now you have the chance to invest like bill gates and maybe become the next Billionaire. ğŸ¤‘ğŸ’² See you next time. When you hear Bulls and Bears you might start thinking about your last trip to the Zoo and how you admired those big animals. Or maybe you hope to never have to face those animals in the wilderness.ğŸ˜± But let us bring in another perspective: the Bulls and Bears of the financial world - so you can talk like a real finance bro!ğŸ˜

 

The terms Bull and Bear are often used to describe movements within the financial markets, stocks or anything like that. You might now wonder why people specifically use the terms Bull and Bear?ğŸ¤” Well, we do not know that either. ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸ There are some hypotheses about this, like linking it to the animal’s natural movements or referring it to the purchases of the animal's skins, but nobody really knows this for a fact.ğŸ˜¬

What does the Bull represent? ğŸ®

A bull market, or when a market is bullish, generally means that there is growth within the market in terms of an increase or that you see growth potential. ğŸ“ˆ There are no specific metrics for a bullish market, however, the rule of thumb is, that a market can be considered a bull market when there is a 20% increase from the lowest point. â˜ï¸ Not only can a market be a bull market, but you can also use this term to explain stocks, charts, or anything that your heart desires. ğŸ¤“

 

An example of a bull market would be the boom of the post-war economy in the 1950s. Due to this, the S&P 500, the index containing the 500 largest listed companies in the USA, increased by almost 85% in 50 months! ğŸ¤ª

Sooo… Bears bring it down? ğŸ»

Conversely, a market is considered to be a bear market when there is a decrease or a fall. ğŸ“‰ Just like for the bear market, the bear metaphor can be extended to different concepts than  stocks! Additionally, the 20% decrease rule of thumb usually applies from the peak moment. When you see a drop coming, you can also say that the market will be bearish. ğŸ‘Œ

After a boom, there usually comes a phase of recession. This was the case in the early 1960s in the US, when the market slowed down and even decreased by almost 30%. ğŸ¤¯This period can be considered a Bear market. 

Food for Bulls and Bears

The Bulls and Bears are both fed by the same ingredients, they are just jargon names for two opposite stock market’s outcomes. ğŸ´The performance of the stock  market is highly influenced by macroeconomic factors such as unemployment, purchases, trade but also domestic interest rates or investors’  risk appetite. ğŸ¤” Also, it is very usual  that after a Bull Market, a Bear market follows and the other way around. ğŸ”

Now you know what the finance bros are talking about when they talk about bulls and bears and you can impress them with your knowledge. ğŸ˜Maybe you will become just like them but always remember to be part of the movement and makeimpact! ğŸ’š

You have probably heard an older person complain about how bread used to cost a few cents and how everything has gotten so expensive. ğŸ¥º The reason for this is inflation. But let us find out what inflation really is! ğŸ™‚

 

Say your Grandma gives you 100€ cash for your birthday. ğŸğŸ‘µ You put it in your piggy bank and forget about it for the next 10 years. When you go to spend that money, 10 years later, while you would still have 100€ in cash, it would be worth a lot less than it was 10 years ago. ğŸ˜– Meaning, you could buy less with that 100€ now than you could have 10 years ago.

The reason for this?ğŸ¤¨ Inflation.

Simply put, inflation describes the general trend that, over time, the cost of goods and services goes up, making the value of cash go down. The opposite is called deflation.

Why it happens

There are three causes of inflation.

1. When demand for goods and services is higher than supply, suppliers will increase their prices, and if buyers are willing to pay more, it’s known as demand-pull inflation.ğŸ¤‘ğŸ’²

2. When the costs to produce a good or service increase, in order to cover their costs suppliers will increase their prices, known as cost-push inflation. ğŸ‘†

3. When the price of goods and services goes up, wages accordingly go up, and the cost to a business goes up which means the prices must go up enough to cover this additional increase, like a loop. ğŸ” This is referred to as built-in inflation.

Overall, stable and steady inflation is a sign of a healthy economy, since markets are growing and wages are increasing. ğŸ’ª It is when the economy grows rapidly and excessively (hyperinflation), or when the prices of goods and services decrease (deflation) that may cause concerns.ğŸ‘€

How it affects your investment

As a new investor, you need to be aware of inflation for a couple of reasons.

Firstly, since the value of cash and money in the bank decreases when it’s just sitting there, over time you can buy less for the same amount of money. ğŸ˜° This is a good reason to invest your money. ğŸ˜ Money in the stock market tends to follow the trends of inflation, although returns on investment are never guaranteed so it depends on your personal financial strategy.

Secondly, if you invest in industries and markets that are on the rise, and things continue to increase, your investment will likely benefit from inflation. ğŸ¥°

For example…

Person X is passionate about reducing carbon emissions, so they invest in the renewable energy industry. â™»ï¸ If more people continue to become aware of the benefits of switching from coal to green energy, there will be more demand for these services. â˜ï¸ As demand increases, suppliers will increase their costs (demand-pull inflation) so as the cost of renewable energy will go up, businesses in the industry will increase their profits and over time, the value of Person X’s investments will also increase.ğŸ“ˆğŸ’µ

Since you start investing with just 100€, the next time your Grandma gives you birthday money, you could consider investing it rather than keeping it in the bank. ğŸ¦ğŸ This is it from us for now. Be the movement - make!mpact. â¤ï¸

Did you know that the average French persons’ money in the bank is the reason that 11 tons of CO2 are emitted per year?ğŸ˜³ğŸ’¨ This is the same as the CO2 amount emitted by all of that persons’ other activities. You might now ask yourself: So, is 11 tons of CO2 a lot? ğŸ¤” To give you an idea of what 11 tons stand for, think of the weight of 2 elephants, 33 m² of melted Arctic ice pack, or 1 world tour by plane! ğŸ˜ğŸ§ŠğŸŒğŸ˜² If you do not know what impact your money can have on the environment, we are here to introduce you to it!

The problem with the average carbon footprint

The average carbon footprint only takes the direct carbon footprint into account like housing, consumption, or transportation.ğŸ ğŸ›’âœˆï¸ This means that Bank accounts are not included. ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸However, the carbon footprint of our money should be added to the annual average individual footprint to have proper results. â˜ï¸

To draw a better picture of this, let’s look into the impact of some sustainable actions compared to the impact of an individual's bank account.ğŸ’³ Say, you try to live more sustainable, so you try to reduce your CO2 emission by:

  • Becoming vegetarian = -1,1 tons ğŸ¥¬ğŸ¥’

  • Favouring cycling for short journeys = - 0.32 tons ğŸš²

  • Not taking the plane anymore = - 0,27 tons ğŸš«âœˆï¸

But then it all goes to waste with the Impact of your bank being + 11 tons. ğŸ¦

So, does money in the bank pollute?

The problem for the planet is not the banking activity itself. In fact, only a small amount of CO2 is emitted by the banking activities. ğŸ˜Œ

As you might know, your money in the bank does not sleep.ğŸ˜´ The Bank reinvests the money.ğŸ”ƒ The problem is not the reinvestment. It is that banks finance economic actors who pollute enormously through their activities, especially the ones linked to fossil energies (gas, coal, oil). ğŸ›¢ğŸ’¨

Since 1988, only 100 companies have been responsible for more than 70% of global greenhouse gas emissions. But fossil fuel companies can't destroy the planet without outside help since they need financing.ğŸ’° And they need a lot of it. In 2019 alone, Banks invested $63 Billion in fossil fuels. ğŸ¤¯

But why do banks invest in fossil fuels?

Banks invest in fossil fuels because it's more profitable in the short term. As you might know, you must be able to get the money back from your current account at any time. ğŸ‘€ But it is not interesting for your bank to let this money sleep, it is more attractive for it to invest it to remunerate itself. Thus, your bank can only invest the money in your checking account in the very short term, and therefore in fossil fuels. ğŸ¥´

And this is a pity because our money is a very important lever for the ecological transition. â—ï¸There should be more pressure on banks to disinvest in fossil fuels and reallocate their capital to more impactful projects. For people like you and us, this means that we should think about the impact our money can have on the real and local economy. ğŸ§

Ok, what can I do?

There are very easy, but fundamental things you can do, to minimize the carbon emitted by your money:

  • Find out what is financed through your savings and what is the impact of that

  • Act by choosing to align your  savings with your  values. ğŸ’ª You can send a message to your banker to ask for transparency on what your savings are financing or change to banks that invest in ecological and social projects â™»ï¸

  • Learn about finance and understand its influence on the economy and society

 

For the last point you can also keep reading our articles and dive into the different topics we introduce you to! ğŸ˜We now hope that you understand what the money in your bank can have. So invest with a purpose. Don't forget, be the movement - makeImpact! ğŸ’š

You have probably heard that the whole world is going crazy about the GameStop stock and how much it has influenced the stock market. ğŸŒğŸ¤ª But if you have not heard about it or even if you did, it might still be a question to you what happened there. ğŸ¤” The whole GameStop case was based on shorting stocks. But let us find out more about what shorting stocks is and what happened.ğŸ‘ Ready, set - go! ğŸ¤©

How did the GameStop case get started?

GameStop is an American company that owns physical stores, selling video games around the world. ğŸ®ğŸ‘¾ But as you might have guessed: people nowadays rather buy their games online leaving the stores abandoned. ğŸ™ƒ

Because of that, its business is no longer profitable - with losses of 673bn in 2018, 470 in 2019, and 215 in 2020.  ğŸ˜®

 

So, the beginning of the famous GameStop Short selling story starts something like this: on the one hand, we have a company that accumulates losses and that has a rather dark future. ğŸ¢ğŸ˜¨ On the other hand, we have Wall Street financiers who think that this company has no future and decide to bet on the fact that the company will fail.ğŸ’¼ If GameStop’s stock price actually falls, those financiers have won their bet and therefore make money out of it. ğŸ’¸They can do this by short selling. 

Come to the point… what is short selling now? ğŸ™„

Okay, imagine that you think the price of a stock is going to fall, so you want to bet on this possible fall. ğŸ¤ For this reason, you ask one of your friends who owns one of these stocks to lend it to you for a fee of let’s say $2. So, you tell your friend not to worry, that you will return it to him in a few months. â˜ï¸ You then sell the stock at the current price - let's say 200€. 3 months later, the price of the stock is only worth 150€, and as promised, you decide to give it back to your buddy. ğŸ˜Œ You buy another at the current price of 150€. So, after giving it back you won 48€ (=200€-2€-150€)! ğŸ˜ Easy, isn't it?

Ok and now imagine, that you have made a mistake in your bet and that the stock after 3 months is not worth the expected 150€ but instead 500€. Meaning, that what you sold for i.e. 200€, you now have to buy back for 500€ because you need to give it back to your friend. ğŸ¥² Ouch, it hurts, because you lose 302€. ğŸ˜¤

You might now wonder: “But as long as I haven’t bought the stock back, I haven't lost any money yet, right?  I can always wait for the price to go down and return it to him later.” ğŸ¤¥

If the stock increases in value, you must pay “margin call”, it’s the difference between the current price and the price when you have shorted.ğŸ“Š It’s just to adjust the price for the broker (your friends) and to prove you have enough money. And the more often you have a limit date in your contract.ğŸ“…

Back to the GameStop story, this is where it gets juicy

It all starts a chat called REDDIT, which is mostly known for memes and jokes - so pretty much almost like us.ğŸ¥³ In the middle of January 2021, a bunch of REDDIT users learned that GameStop's stock is enormously short. ğŸ¤« At the same time, on the 14th of January, a hedge fund called Citron Research which is  known for its downside bets (shorted stocks), publicly announced that it will short GameStop's stock and that It will take it for $20 a share. ğŸ—£ So many REDDIT users decided to  collectively buy GameStop stocks to make the stock price go up and make the hedge funds lose a lot of money. ğŸ«‚

7 days later, on January 21 , when the stock price reached $40, Citron Research stopped offering the  shorting after losing twice its gamble, while Melvin Capital, another hedge fund that bet on the drop, had to receive nearly $3 billion from its parent company after also suffering losses. ğŸ˜³ğŸ“‰

The moral of the story is: short selling can be very dangerous. ğŸ‘¹ The gains are limited because whether you borrow a stock for €4 or €100 you can never buy it back below €0. ğŸ˜”However, the losses are unlimited, meaning the stock can very well take a lot of value. ğŸ˜

Overall, the REDDIT's users’ goal was to create a “short squeeze”. Basically, when a stock unexpectedly rises in price, the short-sellers may have to act fast to limit their losses.ğŸ˜¶‍ğŸŒ«ï¸ And if there are many short-sellers in the same position, the price will increase very fast. And long-term investors can bring interest to buy the stock, so the price continues to increase.ğŸ”º

Thus, a real tug-of-war took place between REDDIT's retail investors and the hedge funds. ğŸ¤› Although the share price reached more than $300 at the end of January - which is completely overvalued for a company that is breaking up like GameStop - the majority of the retail investors stayed in their positions and decided not to sell in order to make the hedge funds lose money. ğŸ˜ˆ

Thus, in a short squeeze, the hedge funds that are in a short position are fighting each other to buy a quantity of stock that is not enough for everyone. ğŸ¤’

If they can't get their hands on shares to unwind their positions, they have to pay excessive margin calls.

 

Note that we don't know if there was really a short squeeze, it's very difficult to determine but in any case, it was REDDIT's will.

Now you know more about short selling and the GameStop story! ğŸ“• However, the story here is a summary, and we did not talk about the link between REDDIT's retail investment platform and the parent company of Melvin Capital. Nor of some of the actors who played in the story and who participated to make the price rise.â˜ï¸ As always, do not forget to read more about this story to understand all the actors who played into this. Be the movement - makeimpact! â¤ï¸

Do you know which company was recognized by Corporate Knights as the most sustainable company out of more than 8000 companies in 2021?ğŸ¤” If not, we will introduce you to it: it is Schneider Electric. ğŸ¤© But, which strategy helped them be this good?

 

What is Schneider Electric?

Schneider Electric is a French multinational company founded in 1836. ğŸ¥–ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· It is known for its Digital Transformation of Energy Management and Automation in Residences, Buildings, Data Centers, Infrastructures, and Industries with a presence in more than 115 countries. ğŸ”ŒğŸ¤–In particular, the company is a leader in electrical management - medium voltage, low voltage, and secure energy, but also automation systems. 

As you can tell they provide a variety of empowerment and energy management solutions with energy efficiency at its core. â¤ï¸

 

Sustainable Development Goals

One of the reasons Schneider Electric is so successful with sustainability is its commitment to aligning its strategies and solutions with the UN's sustainability goals.ğŸ˜â™»ï¸

Now, let’s look into the sustainability strategies that Schneider Electric adopts. ğŸ˜

From their impact report, we learn that the company focuses on six extra-financial objectives, namely : "climate", "resources", "trust", "equality", "generations" and "local". With this, the company has programs that aim to contribute to all the 17 SDGs. ğŸ˜± Since covering all of them would be very complex, let’s look at some of the most important ones! ğŸ‘‡

 

SDG 7: AFFORDABLE AND CLEAN ENERGY ğŸ’¡ğŸ’¸

Schneider Electric develops products and solutions that address a wide range of individual needs. For example, for off-grid communities, i.e. communities that do not have access to city electricity.ğŸ™ Schneider Electric offers products that enable individuals to benefit from sufficient electricity for their homes and small income-generating activities.ğŸ¡âš’ï¸

SDG 13: CLIMATE CHANGE â˜€ï¸ğŸŒ§

Schneider Electric serves industries that account for the majority of the world's energy consumption.ğŸŒ This energy consumption is not always optimized and is, therefore, one of the largest sources of CO2 emissions.ğŸ’¨ğŸ˜³ Schneider Electric can provide solutions that optimize energy consumption and avoid losses. Due to this, in 2020, thanks to some of Schneider Electric's complementary services, 120 million tons of CO2 were saved. ğŸ”’

SDG 8: DECENT WORK AND ECONOMIC GROWTH ğŸ‘·‍â™€ï¸ğŸ“ˆ

More than 10 years ago, Schneider Electric launched an international program to support professional training in the energy sector.ğŸ’¼ Schneider's ambition is to train 1 million people by 2025. By 2020, 400,000 disadvantaged people have already been trained in energy management. ğŸ‘

ESG risks 

The main risks that could harm Schneider Electric's functioning are cybersecurity and data privacy.ğŸ’¾ These risks are natural to any company operating in the digital world. However, in the case of industrial infrastructures such as those of Schneider Electric's customers, the physical and financial damage can be particularly severe and, in some cases, have security and privacy impacts. ğŸ¤¨ğŸ˜«

Environmental factors:

Schneider Electric's main environmental risk is their greenhouse gases output: luckily their situation is stable.ğŸ¤‘ Also, thanks to the introduction of their new sulfur hexafluoride minimizing offering (which, btw is the most polluting GHG), is about to mitigate the current risk significantly! ğŸ¥°

Social factors:

The group behind Schneider Electric regularly checks if its suppliers are acting according to their standards and ask to correct them if there are rule breaks. A large proportion of these problems in 2020 are related to health and safety, the management system, or working conditions.ğŸ˜¬ An analysis of the 133 "top priority" nonconformities identified in 2020 reveals that the following issues are the most common:

Labor standardsğŸ’ª: They noted their suppliers not following rules regarding working hours and rest days (but also their time measurement systems are often inadequate), problems in recording and paying overtime, and lack of formalization of labor contracts.

Health and safetyğŸ˜·ğŸ¥: Additionally, the mentioned emergency procedures in need of improvement, inadequate crisis preparedness training and drills, inadequate fire alarms and protection systems, and lack of emergency equipment and training.

 

Governance factors:

The group is focusing on anti-corruption, leading Schneider Electric to constantly interact with all its stakeholders around the world.ğŸŒ‡ Due to this, their responsibilities are increasing.

Financials

Schneider Electric's share price has risen by +131.41% in 5 years, compared with only +47.93% for the CAC 40, its benchmark index. Also, it has outperformed its main competitors! ğŸ¤¤

 

Earnings per share (EPS) are estimated at €5.80 for 2021, an increase of 52% in one year, and are expected to continue to grow in 2022.â¬†ï¸

Schneider Electric uses little leverage compared to its competitor Legrand, meaning that it gets lower returns on equity. Also, Schneider Electric is less efficient at using its asset base to generate good returns compared to Legrand.ğŸ¥µ

Note that General Electric's earnings per share are negative (-0.42). This leads to a negative P/E (=share price/EPS). For a better representation of the situation, the P/E of General Electric is not shown on the chart below. 

SE multiples don’t show any alarming warning since those are all in the range drawn by its comparables.

A relatively high P/E ratio within its industry is generally a sign of investors being confident about the company's medium- and long-term growth prospects.ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ In addition, high-quality companies historically have a high P/E. If you want to know more about multiples like P/E, check out our article on it. ğŸ¤—

EBIT suffered a decline in 2020 with the Covid-19 crisis. Its first 2 quarters were strongly impacted by the uncertainty, but its activities were able to recover in the 3rd quarter of 2020.ğŸ˜ The year 2021 started very well, Schneider Electric took the opportunity to revise its targets upwards. All in all, Schneider Electric seems to have a good financial performance from the analyzed factors.ğŸ˜

Conclusion

In conclusion, we can say that Schneider does not only have a good environmental and social performance, but their financial performance also seems to be solid! ğŸ˜» This is our 50 cent - but remember to make your own analysis and research before investing. ğŸ¤“ğŸ“š Hasta la proxima vez!
