Would you have ever guessed that an energy company could be the most sustainable in the World?ğŸ¤” To us it sounded very conflicting. But in 2020 and 2019 this has been the case.ğŸ˜³ The name of the company is Ørsted, a Danish multinational power company that was ranked second in 2021 by Corporate Knight soon after Schneider Electric. ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡°ğŸ”Œ

 

Company introduction 

Ørsted was founded in 1972 as a state-owned company. 12 years ago when fossil fuel companies’ income statements were rosy and chubby, Ørsted pinned down to science-based data and started to revolutionize its business model.ğŸ“ŠğŸ”ƒ Despite struggling with its finances in the beginning, the company has lived up to its vision and it is a leader for the energy industry and the sustainability agenda.ğŸ’ª In 2020, Ørsted produced 88% of its energy from renewable sources. The company develops, constructs, and operates offshore and onshore wind and solar farms, energy storage facilities, and bioenergy plants around the world.ğŸ’¨ğŸŒŠâ˜€ï¸ In particular, the company is the global leader in offshore wind. ğŸ†

Sustainable Development Goals â™»ï¸

First of all, when it comes to Sustainability and disclosure, the company makes its strategy very clear and detailed via not one but two reports, their Sustainability Report, and their ESG performance Report.ğŸ“šâœï¸ As a renewable energy company, Ørsted focuses its transformative impact mostly on SDGs 7 and 13, while also contributing to several SDGs through more than 20 Sustainability programs. 

SDG 7: Affordable and Clean Energy

Ørsted is the world's largest developer of offshore wind power, accounting for 29% of global installed capacity.ğŸ’¨ In the 90s/00s the company pioneered offshore wind technology by building the first farms as demonstration projects in Europe. From then onwards, they have kept investing and innovating to push for cost downwards, and with a 60% cost reduction in six years (2012-2017), offshore wind energy is now cheaper than coal, gas, and nuclear-based power generation. ğŸ˜

SDG 13: Climate Action

To fight climate change, Ørsted has two special goals: 1ï¸âƒ£ Their first goal is to become carbon neutral in terms of energy generation and operations by 2025. To achieve this, they aim to increase the double capacity of offshore wind, the triple capacity of onshore renewables (wind and solar power), phase out coal plants by replacing coal with certified sustainable biomass, and closing down coal-fired capacity.ğŸ˜¯ 2ï¸âƒ£ Second, they want to achieve carbon neutrality of its supply chain by 2040. Ørsted has already established dialogues with its strategic suppliers and laid out solutions and science-based targets for emissions disclosure and other things to implement in order to become carbon neutral. âš–ï¸â™»ï¸

The company also supports the green energy transition on a wider scale, by innovation and development of green hydrogen technologies as well as pursuing storage projects. Those projects can help balance the supply and demand of green energy and financing green whose target is the exclusive use of green financing instruments.  ğŸ’šâœ…


ESG Risks 

As already mentioned, in 2019 Ørsted was recognized as number one of the Corporate Knights Global 100 index as the most sustainable company.ğŸ… This record was justified by the combination of a high percentage of revenues being earned from renewable energy, outstanding results in carbon emissions and water use reduction, investments made exclusively in green energy, and good performance in terms of social and governance. ğŸ¤© However, plans of scaling up offshore capacity bring along some challenges. ğŸ¤¯

Environmental ğŸŒ³

Supply chains are complex and long, i.e. those involve many different players. ğŸ‘¥ The main challenges come from the fact that just a few suppliers disclose their carbon footprint emissions and some are particularly hard at improving their impact as they are linked to heavy manufacturing and shipping.ğŸ—ğŸ›³ Reducing them requires significant technological innovations that are not mature yet.ğŸ¥´ 

Also, despite wind turbines having a high recyclability rate, they are still difficult to recycle and current solutions are very expensive.ğŸ’¸ In the coming decade, Ørsted along with the energy sector plays an important role to facilitate the development of the right solutions to recover or recycle turbine blade materials. And lastly, constructing renewable energy at sea and on land inevitably impacts local habitats and ecosystems.ğŸ¾ğŸŸ As they accelerate the build-out of green energy and therefore work with a greater number of as well as more diverse ecosystems, the company will need a stronger and more programmatic approach to manage our biodiversity impacts.â˜ï¸

Social 

When it comes to gender diversity, it is a little bit painful to read statistics from the 2020 ESGs Report. In terms of Gender Equality, female representation across hierarchy levels, averages around 30%, with no significant improvements since 2018.ğŸ¥µ On top of that, the decreasing share of women towards higher management levels explains the salary and bonus pay gap between women and men.ğŸ¤¢ When it comes to job creation and workers’ safety, results are more positive instead. And for the social factor, the green energy transformation will require significant amounts of minerals and metals. A significant share of those materials comes from countries with a higher risk of negative social, human rights, and environmental impacts. ğŸ˜± Ørsted will need to work carefully with suppliers to ensure traceability and mitigation of those risks through its supply chains. ğŸ˜‘

 

Governance

Ørsted’s majority shareholder is the Danish State (50.1% ownership) although the company’s ambition goes well beyond the Danish borders. ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡° Indeed, in 2019 the company decided to divest from the Danish power distribution for residential customers and City Light businesses by selling that part of its business and using proceeds for global investments in green energy. ğŸŒ

Transparency 

Writing a company spotlight article has never been easier.ğŸ¤¤ The company is fully transparent on its website and with the ambition to lead the way towards the fight against climate change. With this purpose of being a guide for other companies, they have made a booklet about the learnings from their successful and brave transition story.ğŸ‘ Ørsted is a showcase and part of Harvard Business Review's top business transformations of the decade.

Financials

Over the last 5 years, the company has shown strong financial results. In 2020, its operating margins have all outpaced its 5-year historical margins with an ROE of 20.95%.ğŸ†™ 2017 and 2018 have been exceptional in terms of EBIT as a result of proceeds from large projects’ disinvestments. In 2020, EBIT has spiked up as a result of the cashing-in of the proceeds from divestment from  Danish power retail distribution. ğŸ“ˆ

Although, in the first half of 2021 there’s been a decrease in earnings from off-shore operations due to lower-wind speed.ğŸ’¨ The decrease in earnings due to lower-wind speed has been already foreseen by the market at the beginning of January 2021, when the stock price has registered a fall from its peak.â¬‡ï¸ Although the company has managed to compensate for such loss by new disinvestment that has increased EBIT Ørsted’s operational leverage in the last twelve months has been very high, especially compared to competitors. This suggests that the company’s net income and ROA is much more dependent on changes in energy sales volume with respect to its comparable companies.ğŸ™ƒ

Ørsted’s multiples are all in the range between the minimum and the maximum drawn by its comparables while its stock price seems to have remained pretty stable after January 2021.  

Conclusion

Ørsted has been a pioneer in the development of alternative solutions to fossil fuels. ğŸ” The expansion of its operations across the world comes along with the challenge of reaching carbon neutrality within both its operations and supply chain by due deadlines. In terms of social factors, internally the company could focus more on increasing female gender representation across all the management hierarchy. ğŸ¤” Externally, attention must be paid to the higher risk of negative social, human rights, and environmental impacts in certain countries. Financially, the company seems to have a good portfolio diversification, allowing it to compensate for the loss in earnings from lower wind speed with income from project disinvestment. ğŸ¢ 

The take-aways of Ørsted’s bold story are offered in a booklet and can be seen as guidance for the green transition and more in general regarded as a “long-term with a view” approach to business.â™»ï¸ This was our 50 cent - but remember to make your own analysis and research before investing. Be the movement - makeImpact! ğŸ’š

If you have been keeping up with the news or had to select among energy solutions for your house, you might have realized that the renewable energy sector is in the spotlight. ğŸ”¦ğŸ‘€ The market for renewable resources is changing and this also means that there are opportunities for investors coming in. ğŸ’ª So, let us have a look and figure out together what impact you can make through investing in renewable energy stocks and power supply contracts. â˜€ï¸ğŸŒŠğŸ’¨

Did you know that the cost of producing renewable energy is constantly falling, making it not only cheaper but also an even more attractive solution compared to coal-fired power plants in many countries? ğŸ’ğŸ’¸

 

This is due to the fact, that renewable energies developments depend only on the available technological improvements and not on the stock.ğŸ–¥ In fact, while we have to dig further down to the ground through more expensive processes to find oil, the technologies used to exploit Renewable Energy (RE) are becoming more efficient and sophisticated.ğŸ‘ğŸ¤‘ This generates a more profitable industry over time. ğŸ’°

The figures proposed by IRENA (International Renewable Energy Agency) illustrate this very in the picture below: if we look at the production capacity (in kW) that it was possible to achieve for the same investment in  2010 with respect to  2019, we can see that both for onshore wind and for solar energy, the output is more efficient. ğŸŒ¬ğŸŒğŸ’¸

In the COVID period, Renewables have shown their full potential ğŸ’ª 

In the first half of 2020, RE produced more electricity than fossil fuels in Europe: 40% of total electricity production versus 34% from fossil fuels (and 26% from nuclear). ğŸ“ˆ

Lockdowns and reduced economic activity have reduced the demand for electricity. ğŸ¡ In the event of a sharp drop in electricity consumption, priority is given to renewable power plants whose production is said to be "intermittent". ğŸ“‰

This means that their availability varies greatly, without any possibility of control and stockage. This applies particularly to solar energy (available only during the day ğŸŒ¤) as well as to wind energy (available only when the wind blows ğŸƒğŸƒ). March and April 2020 have been particularly windy and sunny. Therefore, weather conditions have largely favored wind and solar electricity production. 

This increase in RE has led to a decrease in the production from nuclear, gas, oil, and coal-fired power plants throughout Europe during those months (because as these energies are controllable, renewable energies are preferred).ğŸ¥°ğŸŒ± Finally, the covid period has shown that even if they are intermittent, renewable energies are capable of making up for a larger share of electricity demand in Europe. Yay! ğŸ‰

A look into the future of renewable energy 

Over the next 5 years, the production costs of photovoltaic and wind energy (onshore) are expected to decrease by 36% and 15%, respectively while the electricity production capacity from wind and photovoltaic is expected to double by 2025.â¬‡ï¸ Off-shore wind currently represents a small share of the wind-production capacity but that also has very promising prospects. ğŸŒŠğŸŒŠ

More globally, the IEA (International Energy Agency) estimates that 95% of the increase in total global energy capacity by 2025 will come from renewable sources.  Renewables are the future of the energy sector! ğŸ™Œ

Overcoming obstacles with energy storage

As said before, the main problem with renewable energies is their intermittency. ğŸ˜° The solution would be to store this energy in order to have a reserve when demand increases. While it used to be a major obstacle for the expansion of renewables a few years ago, today energy storage is becoming one of the fastest-growing asset classes in the energy industry. ğŸ“ˆ

New batteries and technologies are being developed, such as thermodynamic solar power plants.ğŸ§‘‍ğŸ”¬ Here, the sun's energy is highly concentrated and then stored as heat by a special liquid. This is then easy to manipulate: that heat can be used to generate electricity at any time, even at night in the middle of winter. â›„

There is also a lot of R&D  at the moment about hydrogen as a means to store surplus energy from renewables. ğŸ”œ Researchers are even working on hydrogen-based solutions to power airplanes.

Is investing in renewable energy a good ideaâ“

Renewable energy companies, which include wind, biomass, solar, thermal, hydrogen, and hydro, are constantly growing. “Green” electricity is therefore becoming a buoyant sector and above all a very dynamic market, which could find a place of choice in your investor's portfolio. ğŸ’°

A few years ago, investments in renewable energy companies were considered rather risky... but today, this is no longer the case. Green energy investment products have become increasingly profitable! â™»ï¸ğŸ˜

As governments and corporations recognize the need for a transition to renewable energy, the opportunities for investing in renewables stocks grow along. ğŸ’ª Renewable energy investments are characterized by long-term contracts and are meant to last for decades. This means for investors a longer horizon for attractive returns! ğŸ“†

In addition to giving purpose to your savings by actively participating in the ecological transition, you will likely also benefit from the financial opportunities of a growing market! ğŸ˜ Remember -  be the movement and makeimpact! â¤ï¸

When you hear the expression "circular economy", do you immediately think of recycling bottles? ğŸ”ƒğŸ§ƒ Or buying second-hand clothes? ğŸ‘—ğŸ‘• Well, then you are not totally wrong, but let us tell you how many more circular economy options are out there. â™»ï¸ No child left behind! 

What is the circular economy?

The circular economy is a model that aims to limit the consumption and waste of resources and products as well as the production of waste. It is about creating, prolonging, or slowing down a recurring loop: Waste is now a raw material to be reused. ğŸš± So, you try to make the most out of your already existing products! ğŸ˜

It is the opposite of the linear economy, also known as "extract, produce, consume, throw away", which is also the model used in most societies. ğŸ™

What kind of ways are there to push forward the circular economy? ğŸ¤”

The idea of circularity can kick in throughout the different stages of a product's lifecycle. ğŸ”µ Let’s see how:

 

Design & Manufacture 

At the product design stage, it is all about facilitating the repairing, the disassembling, and the recycling. The goal is to extend the object's life and facilitate the recovery of materials. ğŸª¡ğŸ§¶

The choice of raw materials is also essential. Some raw materials require a lot of resources to be extracted. ğŸ˜¨ In addition, some production inputs such as rare minerals are extracted in conflict zones or countries that do not respect human rights (dangerous working conditions, child labor, poverty wages, etc.). ğŸ¥´ Therefore, the reuse of extracted materials comes as a strategy to reduce both environmental damage and the risk of modern slavery. ğŸŒ³ğŸ› 

Distribution & Retailer 

Which means of transportation to use? ğŸššğŸ›³ Home delivery or store delivery? Which container? Which packaging? ğŸ“¦ There is no universal answer while each company should think of the most sustainable solutions among the viable options.

For example: Imagine a company that sells cosmetic oils and wonders which shipping container is the most ecological. You might think they should use glass bottles since glass can be reused and recycled for an infinite amount of time. ğŸ¥›ğŸ˜ But look, when using glass containers the shipment will be heavier and require more fuel than if plastic containers are used. ğŸ˜®‍ğŸ’¨ On the other hand, when choosing plastic containers, concerns may arise about their lifespan and chance to recycle the material at the end of their lives. Depending on the parameters, the environmental impact of plastic can be better than glass and vice versa.ğŸ¥´ Through life-cycle assessment analysis and tools, the company can calculate the environmental impact of each solution and adopt the most eco-friendly. ğŸ¤™

Consumption ğŸ´

On the buyer's side, we consumers shall consume responsibly. You certainly don't need to change your phone every time a new model comes out! ğŸ“µ

Maximize Use - Repair & Reuse

Extending the lifetime of a product entails repairing it as much as possible or selling it if it is not used. ğŸª›ğŸ”¨

We can also think about an economic model based on use over possession: the sharing economy. ğŸ«‚

Here an example could be that if you don't need to use a car every day, instead of buying one, you can just rent one or carpool. ğŸš— This maximizes the use of existing products and spares resources from producing one for every single user. This concept can apply to other less conventional categories too like a lawn mower or a raclette machine jointly bought with your neighbors! ğŸ¥¸

Recycling & Reprocessor 

The aim here is to look for alternatives to landfills or incineration. â™»ï¸ Circular economy companies process their waste according to the following scheme: If the first solution is not possible, they consider the next and so on. Here are some questions to ask yourself when trying to extend a product's life âœ…:

1) Reuse: Is it possible to reuse the object as is?

2) Upcycling: Is it possible to transform the object into a new product, adding a strong added value? 

3) Composting & Recycling: If there are organic materials they will be composted. And if they are not, is it also possible to recycle them?

4) Energy recovery: As the last resort, they will turn to incineration, which generates heat by burning the non-reusable materials. So, is it possible to use the product for energy?

Are there problems with the circular economy? ğŸ¤”

However, not everything that shines is gold. ğŸ† Lucie Domingo warns us against the too-easy solutions that the circular economy can present. ğŸ˜³

Indeed, the surplus of waste and the depletion of resources are two major problems of our century, but they are not the only ones! The risk with the circular economy is that we forget about the other less visible challenges of our century such as global warming and the loss of biodiversity, which cannot be solved with this type of economic model. ğŸ¥µ Moreover, she found, we only partially question the use of the eco-designed objects. ğŸ˜¯ We often forget their maintenance, their transport, or their usefulness for the society and the individuals who compose it. â˜¹ï¸

Let's take the example of water bottles: Does consuming recycled plastic water bottles on a daily basis really address the issues surrounding plastic? Shouldn't we question the utility of plastic bottles in general? Can't we drink tap water directly and get a water bottle for our trips? ğŸ¤¯

Essentially, Domingo says that the urgency of the environmental crisis needs a fundamental change in our industrial activities and our daily lives. ğŸ­ğŸš« The risk is to act too quickly! The focus on immediate and less effective solutions may mislead the realizations of the solutions on the long term. ğŸ˜¶‍ğŸŒ«ï¸ 

As you might have realized circularity and sustainability matters at large are complex but remember, always strive to be the movement and make!mpact! ğŸ’š

You have been following make!mpact for a while and learned from our Company Spotlights about stocks KPIs (Key Performance Indicators). ğŸ¤“ Now, you are ready and want to start investing! ğŸ™Œ But as you have learned: you should always go deeper and draw your own picture. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ¨ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ¨ You might have googled the first few stocks to read about them and landed on Google Finance. But now you feel a little bit overwhelmed by all the information. ğŸ˜± Don’t worry we will get you out through stocks KPIs and their meaning step-by-step, so you can make informed decisions! ğŸ˜

On most financial platforms, you can find the financial information of a company either by typing in the company’s name or by searching for the company’s ticker, which is the stock’s unique identifier for that company (e.g. TWTR stands for Twitter). ğŸ—’ğŸ‘Œ Some stocks may be listed in more than one financial marketplace (or Stock Exchange) and in that case, you can select one specifically (e.g. NYSE stands for New York Stock Exchange).  ğŸ™Œ

How to read stock information 

 

As you can see, Twitter is currently trading at $61.98 per share. ğŸ’° We can see that over the chosen period of 1 Year, the share price has increased by 31.01%. ğŸ“ˆ This represents an increase in share of +14.67$ within this time period. You can change the reference period from 1D (i.e 1 day) to MAX (i.e. the entire lifetime of the stock). ğŸ“Š

This type of stock market graph is called a continuous curve. It is quite easy to understand! ğŸ˜» The x-curve represents time, the y-curve represents the closing price of the stock. Thus, the curve symbolizes the price at which the stock was trading at the end of the trading day (closing price) at each point in time for a given period. ğŸ’µğŸ’µğŸ’µ

The graph can be used to show the history of a financial product (a.k.a security) like a stock but also a stock market index, over a relatively long period. ğŸ‘ It has the advantage of giving a general idea of the security without having to pay too much attention to the details. ğŸ˜†

The KPIs explained 

On the right hand side of the graph, you will see a table like the one in the picture below. â¬‡ï¸  That shows the most relevant metrics or KPIs about the stock. 

 Let’s take a look at what each of these means: ğŸ”

  • Previous close shows the prior day's final stock price when the market officially closes for the day. ğŸ•“
  • The day range shows the highest and lowest price during that trading day. The difference between the two indicates the level of volatility that a particular security is experiencing, so how much the stock fluctuates within the day. ğŸ“ˆ
  • The year range shows the highest and lowest price during one trading year. This is much more informative instead. The higher the range, the riskier the stock is. This is so because if you buy the stock and want to sell it at any point in time, and it is quite likely its stock price will fall in the future then you wait for the price to rise up again or do not wait and sell it at a loss. ğŸ“Š
  • Market cap stands for market capitalization and refers to how much a company is worth as determined by the stock market. It is defined as the total market value of all outstanding shares. The company's market cap is calculated by multiplying the number of outstanding shares with the current market value of one share. ğŸ’°
  • Volume refers to the 30-days average number of shares traded each. ğŸ“†
  • P/E ratio can be very interesting! This stands for the price-to-earnings ratio, which some investors may use to decide if a stock is undervalued, overvalued, or fairly valued. Alone might be boring while being more informative when compared to the P/E of comparable corporations. If a company has a P/E above the market or sector average, it means that the market has high expectations about the value generation of the company in the coming months and years. A stock with a high P/E will have to meet the market's expectations by increasing its earnings, or else the price will have to fall. ğŸ“‰
  • Dividend yield, expressed as a percentage, is a financial ratio (= $ amount of the dividend/ share price) that shows how much a company pays out in dividends each year relative to its stock price. It's important for investors to keep in mind that higher dividend yields do not always indicate attractive investment opportunities. Indeed, for example, the dividend yield of a stock may be elevated as the result of a declining stock price. ğŸ“Š

The Financial Performance indicators of a stock 

  • Revenue is the total amount of income generated by the sale of goods or services related to the company's primary operations. So it is pretty much the money the company makes. ğŸ’¶ğŸ’¶ğŸ’¶
  • Net income is calculated as revenues minus expenses, interest, and taxes. Investors should review the numbers used to calculate Net Income because expenses can be hidden in the accounting methods, or revenues can be inflated. Net income can either be partially or fully reinvested into the company’s operations while whatever does not go there, it is distributed to shareholders through dividend payments ğŸ’°
  • Diluted earnings per share, also called diluted EPS, is a profitability calculation that measures the amount of income each share will receive if all of the dilutive securities are realized. ğŸ’¸
  • Net profit margin measures how much net income is generated as a percentage of revenues received. It helps investors assess if a company's management is generating enough profit from its sales and whether operating costs and overhead costs are being contained. It is considered one of the most important indicators of a company's overall operational and performance health.â—ï¸
  • Operating income reports the amount of profit realized from a business's ongoing operations. Analyzing operating income is helpful to investors because it doesn't include taxes and other one-off items that may skew a company's profit in a given year. ğŸ‘
  • Net cash figure is commonly used when evaluating a company's cash flows. Companies rely on cash to keep the wheels of their operations turning. ğŸš—ğŸ’¨ They use cash for payroll, asset purchases, and many other purposes. The net change in cash is the amount by which a company’s cash balance increases or decreases in an accounting period. ğŸ“Š When you own or consider buying stock in a company, it is important to monitor its net change in cash to make sure it doesn’t run out. You can use information from the three sections of a company’s cash flow statement to calculate its net change in cash. ğŸ’°
  • Cash on hand refers to the amount of money that your business has immediately available on the last day of the reporting period. Companies with a healthy amount of cash and cash equivalents can reflect positively in their ability to meet their short-term debt obligations. ğŸ“†ğŸ’°
  • Cost of revenue is the total cost of manufacturing and delivering a product or service to consumers, including labor cost etc. In other words, it is the operational expenses. âš™ï¸âš™ï¸âš™ï¸

This might be a lot of new information ğŸ˜± but you can come back here and refresh what you need whenever looking into a stock’s financials. ğŸ¤“ğŸ˜ And remember, invest with purpose. Be the movement - makeimpact! â¤ï¸

Maybe you have seen in the financial news the word “hedge funds” but you don’t know what it is. Generally, hedge funds don’t get good press. They are often associated with the speculative excess money of financiers. 

So what is a Hedge Fund?

A hedge fund is an alternative investment fund. Hedge funds are less regulated than traditional funds and they are often argued to be speculative. ğŸ˜³ In other words, hedge funds seek to make a lot of profit and they use risky strategies to make the profit. So, Investors can expect high returns (and also high risk). ğŸ“ˆğŸ“‰ Since, hedge funds are less regulated than traditional funds, they can use more aggressive investment strategies. Some of these strategies include derivatives, hedging, and leverage. The strategies will be explained later on. 

Investors engaging in hedge funds are mainly wealthier investors. Hedge funds are typically expensive to invest through since they have high fees. Furthermore, investors investing in hedge funds also need to be able to afford high risks. ğŸ’°ğŸ’¸ 

Why are hedge funds called hedge funds? 

The name hedge fund comes from hedging, a practice used by hedge funds. ğŸŒ³ Hedging means investing in opposite positions. â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ This practice can be very sophisticated. It is important to understand that its purpose is to reduce risk, like a form of insurance. As an example, to make it more simple, it can consist of investing in a company’s stock while hedging the risk by taking short positions on the very same stock. This way the hedge fund bets in one direction while still limiting potential losses if the market should move in the opposite direction. It should be noted that hedging is never perfect and there is always a considerable amount of exposure to risk. âš¡ï¸

Hedging is a form of derivative. Derivatives are a way to speculate in the future value of an underlying asset. They are a complex trading practice and are reserved for experienced traders. ğŸ¤“ğŸ“š Derivatives are viewed as having asymmetric risk where the maximum loss is much smaller than the potential gain. 

To earn more, hedge funds use leverage 

The technique of leverage means that hedge funds buy assets using debt more or less combined with their own capital (the higher the debt used as a percentage of the paying price for the asset, the higher the leverage). Indeed, the use of leverage can magnify returns. With an example, it is easier to understand. ğŸ’¡ Imagine a company that needs a new machine to produce. The machine costs 1000€ and makes it possible to gain a yearly 10% of its initial value in revenues. So, the company earns 100€ per year. ğŸ’¸ 

  • If the company chooses to finance the entire paying price of the machine through its own capital (i.e. a company's own money or equity ). The profitability is 10% (=100€ /1000€). ğŸ’¶

  • If the company chooses to finance half of the price via debt, e.g. borrowing  500€ at a 3% annual interest, the company must pay 15€ to the bank (= 500€ x 3%) while 85€ go to the company's shareholders. Therefore, the profitability is now 17% (=85€/500€). ğŸ’¶ ğŸ’¶ ğŸ’¶

The same applies to stocks. You can think of a stock as the production machine in the example. âš™ï¸

Hedge funds use a lot of leverage (several times the size of the fund). If with leverage you can have much higher returns, you can also have much lower returns than without using leverage at all. Indeed, leverage multiplies the risk. The structure of these funds is complex and can be vulnerable (exposure to accounting failure) and impact many financial actors negatively. ğŸ˜¢

Hedge funds are often put forth as being responsible for the financial crisis in 2008. ğŸ˜• If you have seen the movie “The Big Short”, you will know that global banks and fund managers had subprime (a financial word for “risky”) loans mortgage-backed securities (MBSs) which have been bundled together and sold as new financial products to different financial individuals and institutions. These financial products are also called CDOs (collateralized debt obligations). The subprime crisis caused the CDOs to collapse in value. ğŸ’¥ CDOs became worthless and the hedge funds wanted to get rid of them but had a hard time selling those in the market. Having very high leverage, the funds suffered huge losses. ğŸ‘ğŸ¼

All in all, hedge funds can earn returns well above the market’s when they bet right as well as incur huge losses when markets go down. Sometimes, they can bring down with them many other financial actors, like in 2008. That's not really what we mean by sustainable finance. âŒ

We hope this gives you a good understanding of what hedge funds are and how they operate. ğŸ˜Œ Remember, always strive to be the movement and makeimpact! â¤ï¸

So far we have been discussing the EU Taxonomy and the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (the SFDR). ğŸ¤“ Today we will tackle another brick within EU regulation on sustainability: the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (the CSRD). ğŸ¤—

Why one more piece of legislation? ğŸ˜…

As urgency for climate actions intensifies in order to limit global warming to 1.5°C, new regulation like the CSRD has the scope to accelerate the transition towards sustainable business models. ğŸš€ The acceleration needed across industries is pretty dramatic to remain within target. ğŸ˜³ Here are some examples of the pace we need: the phasing out of coal in electricity generation should be 5.2 times faster and the ramp-up of public and private climate finance should be 13 times faster. ğŸ˜± Numbers are not rosier for other sectors. ğŸ˜¢ It can therefore be argued that more regulation is needed to reach the goals the international community has put forth. 

How does the CSRD differ from the EU Taxonomy and the SFDR? ğŸ¤”

Let’s take a look at the picture below and break it down. â¬‡ï¸ğŸ™Œ

At the top, the EU Taxonomy defines and classifies what sustainable activities are. ğŸ‘

Below the EU Taxonomy, we have two directives that define which mandatory indicators companies have to disclose as a way to measure sustainability within the EU Taxonomy: 

ğŸ‘‰ The SFDR (Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation) 

It governs how financial market participants should disclose sustainability information to end-investors and asset owners. ğŸ“‘ The directive aims to ensure that EU investors have the disclosures they need to make investment choices in line with their sustainability goals as well as prevent green-washing strategies by asset managers. ğŸ’»

ğŸ‘‰ The NFDR (Non-financial Reporting Directive) 

The NFDR sets the requirements on what companies must report and how including specific indicators about the impact of their activities on people and the environment and to what extent their activities are environmentally sustainable according to the taxonomy. ğŸŒ±

As an extension of the NFDR, we then have the CSRD (Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive). ğŸ˜ The CSRD builds on the NFDR and will eventually amend the reporting requirements put forth in the NFDR. The NFDR addresses all large and listed companies (about 11,700), the CSRD extends sustainability regulation to non-listed large companies as well as listed Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) for a total number of about 49,000 companies across the EU. ğŸ¢ The CSRD introduces more detailed reporting requirements. It is no longer enough to report policies and processes with respect to ESG, a strategy and specific targets have to be included in the business model and governance structure. Targets have to be measurable, tracked, and mandatorily disclosed. ğŸ¯

Let’s jump further into the CSRD! ğŸ˜œ

On top of extending the number of companies addressed, the CSRD entails: 

  • Third-party audit (assurance) of reported information (i.e. external audit agency has to verify that the disclaimed information is correct and not manipulated). ğŸ’¼

  • Reporting has to be done according to mandatory EU sustainability reporting standards and with more detailed reporting requirements. ğŸ“„ SMEs will have fewer requirements than the larger corporations. ğŸ˜‡

  • Requires companies to digitally ‘tag’ the reported information, so it is machine-readable. ğŸ–¥ 

  • Furthermore, a top management report about the company's ESGs has to be included. ğŸ¤—

Overall, the CSRD has the scope to bring sustainability reporting to an equal footing of financial reporting. ğŸ™Œ

When will the CSRD become effective? ğŸ“£

So far, the CSRD has been approved by the European Commission in the form of a proposal. The European Commission plans to adopt the CSRD in late 2022. ğŸ“† A preliminary set of standards will most likely be adopted in October 2022. A second set of complementary standards will be adopted by October 2023, which will include sector-specific information. ğŸ” 

Stay tuned and remember - be the movement, make impact!  â¤ï¸ğŸ’š

Who doesn’t know Nike? The footwear and sportswear brand probably doesn’t need much introduction, so here is a fun fact instead. ğŸ¤£  The famous logo was designed by a student. But you know what? The founder didn’t end up liking it. However, he still accepted it since he wouldn’t pay for another prototype. ğŸ¤·ğŸ¼‍â™‚ï¸

Founded in 1971 by Philip Knight and Bill Bowerman in Oregon, the company's name Nike was inspired by the Greek goddess of Victory Niké, who had the ability of moving very fast. ğŸƒğŸ½‍â™€ï¸ Back then, the market was dominated by Adidas and Puma. The founders wanted to create a brand of footwear that could sell cheaper than Adidas. Nike has since then taken hold of large parts of the market. ğŸ¤

Sustainable Development Goals 

In Nike’s Impact Report 2020, Nike has identified the areas where it has the biggest potential to contribute to the SDGs given the nature and scale of the business. 

SDG 3: Good health and well-being 

As a sportswear brand, Nike is committed to sports and encourages people to engage in a healthy lifestyle. ğŸŒ¿  Nike also focuses on supporting communities to get more children into sports. Nike would like to engage children in sports as it can have positive long-term effects such as higher educational attainment, healthy relationships, and stronger life skills. ğŸ¤¸ğŸ½‍â™€ï¸ğŸ¤¾ğŸ¼‍â™‚ï¸ 

SDG 5: Gender equality

Nike’s mission is to make the culture around sports more inclusive for girls and has a goal to get 50% girl participation in Nike’s projects by 2025. ğŸ‘¸ğŸ¼ To reach this goal, Nike has started partnerships with NPOs that work with girls and young women in order to create communities where sport is the catalyst for bringing women together. ğŸ’«

SDG 12: Responsible consumption and production 

Here are some of Nike’s 2025 targets for improving its environmental impact: ğŸ¯ğŸ¯ 

  • 0.5M tons of GHG emissions reduced through increasing their use of environmentally preferred materials to 50% of all key materials

  • 10% waste reduction per unit in manufacturing, distribution, headquarters and packaging through improved design and operational efficiency

  • 100% waste diverted from landfill in their extended supply chain with at least 80% recycled back into Nike products and other goods

  • 10 times the amount of finished product waste refurbished, recycled or donated 

  • 25% reduction in fresh water usage per kg in textile dyeing and finishing

  • Adoption of clean chemistry alternatives for their 10 priority chemistries across the  supply chain 

The next step is then for Nike to reach the targets within the selected time frame. â°âŒ› It will be interesting to follow the progress! 

ESG risks 

As a company operating in the apparel, accessories, and sports equipment industry, the following ESG factors pose a risk for Nike:â—ï¸

Environmental factors:

The principal environmental risk is Nike’s sourcing of raw materials and wastewater. ğŸ’¦

Polyester is one of the most heavily used materials in Nike’s products across both apparel and footwear. Polyester is a synthetic chemical fiber derived from petroleum. It can be argued that polyester is a material to avoid, as products derived from petroleum degrade with great difficulty in the environment. âŒ It is therefore necessary to avoid throwing them away, and try to extend their lifespan as much as possible by recycling the material. Note that recycled polyester as well as conventional polyester release microparticles that contaminate the water. But at least Nike is using more and more recycled polyester instead of the conventional one. âœ…

Social factors:

The principal risk is labor conditions within the supply chain. ğŸ™ğŸ¼‍â™€ï¸ğŸ™ğŸ½‍â™‚ï¸

Like many other companies, Nike has production in Asia. In March 2020, an Australian Strategic Policy Institute’s report "Uyghurs for sale" revealed that Uyghur slave laborers were working in factories supplying 83 well-known global brands with technology, apparel, footwear and automotive sectors, including Nike. Uyghurs are minority people with a Muslim majority living in the Xinjiang Uyghur autonomous region of China and Central Asia and persecuted by the Chinese Regime. Several companies have announced to cut off all relations with subcontractors suspected of exploiting Uyghurs. âš¡ï¸ Whether or not Nike has cut off all its relations as well is still uncertain. It is argued that Nike still needs to provide the public with proof that it has stopped its relations to subcontractors exploiting Uyghurs. ğŸ˜Ÿ

Governance factors:

Nike has put in its priority issues: Ethical and transparent corporate behavior. â¬†ï¸

That is, fighting against dishonest or fraudulent behavior of people in power, usually involving bribes, corruption and intellectual property infringement. â˜ğŸ¼

Financial information

Nike's share price has risen by +117.8% in 4 years, well outpacing most of its competitors: +26.1% Adidas, +152.6% Puma, and 29.0% Under Armour. ğŸ‘ğŸ¼ While Adidas’ stock is still worth a lot more in absolute terms with a price of around $250, Nike has by far the larger market capitalization of about a quarter of a TRILLION dollars! ğŸ¤¯

Nike is also handling the Covid-19 crisis very well. After a drop in its EBIT in 2020, Nike came back even stronger in 2021 with record-high earnings and the highest EBIT margin in its recent history! ğŸ¤¯ The extraordinary growth was strongly driven by Nike’s digital sales. ğŸ‘Ÿ The European soccer tournament is also part of the equation, as Nike is the supplier of several national teams and therefore receives a good part of the profits on the jerseys sold. ğŸ’µ The 2021 performance translates into several other financial measures: Nike has a better ROA and ROE than its peers, meaning that it is better at providing value to its shareholders (ROE), effectively using their money, and using all its assets (ROA). âœ…

For the upcoming year Nike’s management is confident about the company’s growth prospects, and it seems like the market and investors are as well when looking at Nike’s valuation multiples. Nike has high ratios, generally higher than most of its competitors, which means that it is valued higher. ğŸ’ The market believes that Nike will perform better than its peers. ğŸ“Š This might have something to do with Nike’s recent performance, but of course this does not guarantee this will be the case for the future. What will certainly be very important is how Nike handles its ESG risks as sustainability issues are receiving more attention than ever! ğŸŒ³ğŸ’š

To summarize, Nike engages in communities and focuses on getting more children into sports as well as making sports more inclusive for girls. However, when looking at labor and production, Nike has room for improvement. The financial performance of Nike is good. ğŸ˜ But remember to do your own analysis and research! ğŸ™Œ And most importantly be the movement - make!mpact! â¤ï¸

Your 20s are the best time to start investing. ğŸ‰ Maybe you think you don't have enough money and investing is reserved for wealthy people but that's not true! ğŸ™€ In fact, if you don’t have much money, you have little to lose! ğŸ˜œ

Something magical happens when you invest: it’s the compound interest. ğŸ¤‘

  • If you invest 1 000€ at 20 years old with an interest of 7%, you will have 15 000€ at 60 years old. ğŸ’°

  • If you invest 10 000€ at 55 years with an interest of 7%, you will only have 14 000€  at 60 years old. ğŸ’µ

Do you see the difference? ğŸ˜†

Imagine now you invest 1 000€ at 20 years old and after that, you only invest 10€ per month for 40 years, always with the interest of 7%, then you will have almost 39 000€ at 60 years old (you will only invest 5 800€ and you win 33 000€ with interest compound). ğŸ˜» 

Go check by yourself: Compound interest calculator ğŸ“² 

So the success of compound interest is to begin early and let your money work for you. ğŸ‰ The longer you leave your money invested, the greater the effect of compound interest. ğŸ™Œ 

Another advantage of investing for the long term in the stock market is if the stock market flops, your investments have time to go up again. ğŸ¢ As you may know, the market stock works like a yo-yo. The prices go up and down all the time, this is called volatility. However, historically, in the long term, the curves are rising. ğŸ“ˆ

Finally, if you think that investing 1 000€ isn’t possible for you, it’s not a problem if you invest less. ğŸ’ª Having more capital doesn’t make you a better investor. If you can't grow a portfolio of 100€ or 500€, you won't be able to grow a capital of 1 000 000€. ğŸ˜

So even if you invest only 100€ or 500€, you will still learn how to manage your capital without ruining your assets. ğŸ¤“

“You don't need to be a rocket scientist. Investing is not a game where the guy with the 160 IQ beats the guy with 130 IQ.” - Warren Buffet. ğŸš€

The most important thing is to start investing and to be patient and consistent. ğŸ’µ This is your time, join us now and be the movement and make!mpact! â¤ï¸

If you haven’t read our What is a Mutual Fund and an ETF, please, go have a look at it. It will give you a nice introduction to ETFs. ğŸ˜ 

Now let’s have a more in-depth look at what an ETF (Exchange Traded Fund) is and how you can see what’s in your ETF. An ETF also called “a tracker” is an index fund. ğŸ¦ This means an ETF follows an index, sector, commodity, bond, or another asset. ğŸ“Š While traditional funds seek to beat the benchmark, ETFs replicate the benchmark. ğŸ¤“ 

ETFs have many advantages: ğŸ™Œ 

1ï¸âƒ£ Low expense ratios and fewer broker commissions
Building a stock portfolio is often expensive because for every stock you buy, you must pay fees. This is not the case with ETFs. So, if you want to invest only a small amount of money, ETFs may be a good choice for you! ğŸ™Œ 

2ï¸âƒ£ Risk management through diversification
One of the most important rules in investment is “to not put all your eggs in the same basket”. ğŸ¥š An ETF allows you to diversify your investments. You don’t invest in one company but several. Note that some ETFs are less diversified than others. â˜ï¸ 

3ï¸âƒ£ Passively managed 
Generally, when funds try to beat the market, they lose in the long run so if you want to invest for the long term, ETFs usually win.ğŸ† However, there are also actively managed ETFs with higher costs. It is important to differentiate between them. ğŸ‘ˆ 

4ï¸âƒ£ Access to many stocks across various industries
You can choose ETFs that focus on targeted industries. ğŸ¯ Or you can find ETFs that focus on ESG investing. ğŸ˜» 

However, it’s impossible to know exactly what’s in most ETFs without doing some research! ğŸ”

How to know what an ETF is investing in? ğŸ¤”

Each ETF follows a specific index. For example, in the American market, there are 3 big indexes: 

Nasdaq
This is an index with a high concentration of technology firms listed in the Nasdaq stock exchange. It is therefore not very diversified. ğŸ’» ğŸ“±

Dow Jones
This index is even more limited as it includes only 30 companies. ğŸ¢

S&P 500
The S&P 500 index includes the 500 biggest companies listed in the United States. This index is therefore to a certain degree well diversified. However, it is worth noting that 30% of its companies are in the technology sector. ğŸ’»

There are also World ETFs. ğŸŒğŸŒğŸŒ Contrary to what the name may indicate, they don’t allow you to invest in the whole world. The MSCI World only includes countries considered as “developed” (e.g. Europe, United States, Japan, Australia, and Canada). 

If you would like an index with more countries included there’s MSCI ACWI (All Country World Index), which is a broader index that also includes emerging economies. ğŸ“Š

The first step when choosing an ETF ğŸ’ƒ

When you choose an ETF, you may want to decide what exposure you’re looking for. ğŸ¤“ When choosing what exposure you are looking for, you can use these criteria and ask yourself the following questions: ğŸ‘‡

1ï¸âƒ£ Asset classes
Do you want exposure to stocks via equity ETFs or exposure to fixed-income investments through bond ETFs? 

2ï¸âƒ£ Geographical area
Do you prefer only European countries? Or maybe you would like to invest in emerging economies? 

3ï¸âƒ£ Company size
Do you prefer established companies or fast-growing smaller companies? 

4ï¸âƒ£ Sector
Do you prefer a few specific industries or a wide range of industries? 

When answering these questions, remember to take into account what exposure you already have in your portfolio. It is a good idea to choose ETFs that complement your initial investments. ğŸ˜Š If you already have a well-diversified investment portfolio, you could choose to complement it with an ETF focusing on specific industries. ğŸ’ If you are a beginner, then maybe you want to start by choosing a more diversified ETF. ğŸ’‍â™‚ï¸ It is also important to know what you want to limit your exposure to. For example if you own several properties, it may be a good idea to limit your exposure to real estate in your ETF. ğŸ™ƒ

The second step could be to check the dividend distribution policy ğŸ˜œ

When choosing an ETF, you can also ask yourself whether you would like to generate money that you can withdraw and spend? Or you would like your investment to maximize in the future? ğŸ¤·‍â™€ï¸ 

If you invest in a distributing ETF, you will receive dividends or coupons as if you had invested directly in a stock (or a bond). This is good if you need complementary revenue. ğŸ’µ If you invest in an accumulating ETF, the coupons or dividends will be reinvested automatically in your ETF. It’s good if you want to make your investments grow. ğŸ’° To put it simply, reinvested dividends will make babies. ğŸ‘¶

So, it's a good idea to check out the factsheet before investing! âœŒï¸

Outlook on ESG and ETFs ğŸ’«

There are several types of ETFs that may be suitable when you have a sustainable investment approach. ğŸŒˆ But the selection of ESG criteria varies quite a lot, and it is therefore good to know how to differentiate the different approaches used by ETFs. ğŸ¤“

ğŸ‘‰ Exclusion fund 
Exclusion funds are not always very challenging in their ESG approach. ğŸ¤” The main difference between exclusion funds and traditional funds is that these funds exclude controversial sectors such as fossil fuel, alcohol, tobacco, or firearms companies. ğŸš­

ğŸ‘‰ Thematic fund 
These funds are often not very diversified since they target a specific theme, such as access to water, ecological transition, employment and solidarity, emerging economies, health etc. ğŸŒ± So, these funds are concentrated in one industry or sector. Depending on your other investments and your risk profile, it is worth noting the narrow focus on industries and sectors, and figure out if this fits your investment profile. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’»ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’»

To sum up, ETFs are an excellent tool to invest and diversify your portfolio! ğŸ’ª Nonetheless, it is important to check what kind of ETF you are investing in and how it fits your investment profile. 

Remember -  be the movement and makeimpact! â¤ï¸

You may ask yourself: Who are Corporate Knights? ğŸ¤” So let’s, first of all, introduce you to them. âš”ï¸  Corporate Knights is a media and investment research firm that aims to be the voice for clean capitalism. ğŸŒ± Each year Corporate Knights produces a ranking of the 100 most sustainable corporations, providing an index of the world’s greenest companies. ğŸ… The index is recognized for its transparent methodology and the ranking can be used as guidance when looking for sustainable businesses. ğŸ” The businesses in the index have over the years shown to have a good investment return. ğŸ’« 

But let’s get back to what it is all about, the 100 most sustainable corporations of 2022! ğŸ’ª Not to brag about Denmark, but the ranking is characterized by having several Danish companies at the top and Vestas taking the place as number 1. ğŸ¥‡ Go Denmark! ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡°

Who are the top three most sustainable corporations? ğŸ†

Who are this year’s winners? Let’s take a look at the top three companies of Corporate Knights’ 2022 “The Global 100” ranking: 

ğŸ¥‡ Vestas Wind Systems A/S

Vestas is a Danish wind turbine manufacturer and is part of the global energy transition. Vestas mitigates great amounts of carbon emissions by producing and setting up wind turbines. â›”ï¸ Furthermore, Vestas has established a sustainability strategy where they are starting to value sustainability performance higher across the entire value chain. One area where Vestas still has work to do is when it comes to the circularity of their product. At the moment the old turbine blades cannot be recycled, which is of course not very sustainable. ğŸ˜³ 

ğŸ¥ˆ Chr. Hansen Holding A/S

Chr. Hansen is a bioscience company developing natural ingredient solutions for the food, nutritional, pharmaceutical, and agricultural industries. 

Chr. Hansen has been on Corporate Knights’ index for several years but has performed incredibly this year, having moved up from number 24 to second place. ğŸ’ª Chr. Hansen has focused broadly on ESG factors. Concentrating both on clean revenue as well as social factors such as safety and diversity brings them to the top of the ranking. â˜ï¸

ğŸ¥‰ Autodesk Inc 

Autodesk makes software products and services. ğŸ’» Their products and services are used in different sectors from architecture, engineering, and construction to product design, media, and entertainment. Autodesk’s sustainability strategy puts an emphasis on the company’s risks and opportunities based on impact assessments and partnering with customers and having cross-sector collaborations. ğŸ¤ 

How does Corporate Knights determine which companies are sustainable? ğŸ’ğŸ’‍â™‚ï¸

Many actors rank sustainable businesses, but all actors use a variety of parameters to rank the businesses. It is, therefore, a good idea to look at how an index is created and what methodology is used, because then you have a better understanding of what a corporation has accomplished to be ranked high, and see if this is in alignment with your values. â¤ï¸ğŸ’šğŸ’™ 

Corporate Knights analyzes 6,914 corporations with a revenue of above $1 billion when creating the ranking. ğŸ˜±  The data for the ranking consists of indicators based on ESG (environmental, social, and governance) factors. ğŸ¤“ In alignment with Corporate Knights’ self-proclaimed voice of clean capitalism, the ranking weights clean revenue and clean investment very high. ğŸ™ Clean revenue and clean investments can be defined as sales of goods and services or investments that contribute to renewable, low carbon energy, circular economy, or clean production. ğŸŒ± To give a full overview of how the corporations are ranked, clean revenue and clean investments account for 50 points of the score out of 100 points. The last 50 points are then allocated to other environmental indicators as well as social and governance indicators. ğŸŒ±â¤ï¸

We hope we have encouraged you to have a look at some of the other 97 most sustainable corporations ranked by Corporate Knights. ğŸ˜„ğŸ™Œ 

Stay tuned and remember - be the movement, make impact! â¤ï¸

What are London, NYC and Co. doing to master sustainable development?

SDG Goal 11 is all about sustainable cities. Today, about half of the world’s population is living in cities, and this number is projected to grow from 3.5 to 5 billion by 2050. ğŸ˜³ Cities are seen as the powerhouses of economic growth, but they also account for most of the world’s emissions and energy consumption. âš¡ï¸ Not only that, but the rapid urbanization puts pressure on the environment, public health and local water supply. ğŸ’¦ ğŸŒ± Naturally, this raises concerns about how cities can become more inclusive and sustainable. That is why we decided to take a look at what some of the most important cities in the world do to ensure a sustainable future! ğŸ‘ğŸ¼ 

First: New York City - the city that never sleeps. ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ A huge city like New York can work with most of the SDGs in a local context. ğŸŒƒ A key part of New York’s strategy is the belief that local and regional governments play a key role in reaching the SDG targets. ğŸ¤ Following the global adoption of the UN SDGs in 2015, New York set up the Global Vision | Urban Action platform, which was aligned with New York’s development plan called OneNYC. The platform allows local governments to share information and create innovative solutions to challenges using the lens of the SDGs, amongst other things. ğŸ” Another milestone is that in 2018, New York became the first city to report its sustainability progress directly to the United Nations - and it has inspired others to do so, too! ğŸ‰ Pretty amazing, right? ğŸ¤© It definitely seems like New York is committed to sustainability. ğŸ˜ We’ll see what the future holds! ğŸŒ±

If we’re talking about large cities, then the megacity of Tokyo in Japan should not be missing from the list. ğŸ‡¯ğŸ‡µ With a population of around 14 million citizens, Tokyo sees its responsibility to be a global leader in sustainability. ğŸŒ So far, the city has taken steps towards becoming a “smart energy city”, driving forward a low-carbon transportation system, and making its water infrastructure sustainable. ğŸ’¦ Smart cities are a concept aiming to make cities more efficient, greener, and socially inclusive through the use of data and technology. ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’»ğŸ§‘‍ğŸ’» In March 2021, a new long-term sustainability strategy was introduced which is in line with the SDGs. One key aspect of the strategy is “to leave no one behind” which reflects SDG 8: To promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all. âœ¨

Important news is also that Tokyo joined New York in reporting its progress to achieve the SDGs to the UN in 2021. ğŸ“„ That’s news we enjoy hearing! ğŸ˜

Next up: London. ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ While London so far has not committed to voluntarily disclosing its sustainability progress to the UN, it was indeed crowned as the most sustainable city in the 2018 Arcadis Sustainable Cities Index, which measures city sustainability from the perspective of the citizen. ğŸ¥³ London scored high in the economic and social pillars, but, you guessed it… it scored lower on environmental pillars due to air quality and waste management issues. â˜¹ï¸ London has had a Sustainable Development Commission (LSDC) since 2002, and this commission now also uses the SDGs to measure London’s sustainability progress. The LSDC has celebrated many great achievements, but it also acknowledges that London has a lot of work to do, particularly when it comes to inequality. âš¡ï¸ The fact that housing is extremely expensive surely plays a role in why more than a quarter of Londoners live in relative poverty. ğŸ’· ğŸ’” Reducing these inequalities was identified as an important step that could also lead to improvements in other social areas such as public health and homelessness. As the saying goes: self-reflection is the first step to improvement. â˜ğŸ¼

Paris, je t’aime! ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· But do we also love Paris’ progress in sustainable development? Let’s see! Since 2007, Paris has had Climate Action Plans, thanks to which the city’s carbon footprint has decreased by about 20% in the last 15 years. ğŸŒ± By 2050 Paris plans to be carbon neutral - we fully support that ambition! Furthermore, Paris wants to become the greenest city in Europe. ğŸŒ¿ To achieve this, there are initiatives to make urban spaces more eco-friendly, limit congestion, and create more green spaces. ğŸ’š When it comes to the social dimension of sustainability, Paris views its Climate Action Plan also as a means for sustainable economic and social development. ğŸ™Œ 

On a side note: The Olympic and Paralympic Games in 2024 which are going to be hosted in Paris are planned to be the first (of hopefully many) climate-positive. Yay! ğŸ˜ 

Cities are looking for innovative solutions to improve their sustainable development

What all these cities have in common is that they are trying to become greener and grow more inclusively. But how can this be achieved? ğŸ¤” Well, there are a lot of new innovative solutions to improve urban living. Some of them such as vertical farming you might already know from reading our article about the future of food. ğŸ± Several cities are also planning to adopt circular economy approaches based on the principles of sharing, reusing, and restoration. â™»ï¸ And very importantly, they are trying to become smarter and optimize existing resources through the use of artificial intelligence (AI) and other modern technology. ğŸ’» Of course, all these solutions need financing. But just to give you an example, the AI market is expected to grow by more than 40% until 2028, and there are billions of dollars invested in it. ğŸ’µ Maybe you’re interested in investing in AI companies as well? ğŸ’¸ 

Overall, we’re seeing that sustainable development is definitely on the agenda in today’s most important cities. ğŸŒ As it should be. ğŸ˜Œ We hope sustainability is on your agenda, too. Stay tuned and remember - be the movement, make!mpact! â¤ï¸

The United Nations Global Compact or for short UNGC is a voluntary effort at the global level to support MNCs or multi-national companies (the companies that have business in many countries) that are committed to sustainable practices in areas such as the environment, labor rights, or corruption. ğŸ™Œ The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is another global organization that is working in partnership with UNGC in the above direction. Let’s understand why this is so important, what are the violations of UNGC by MNCs and why it is happening in the EU. ğŸ’ª

 

What is this UNGC again? ğŸ¤”

UNGC is a strategic initiative to ensure business houses are conducting their operations with ethics. UNGC has a guideline of 10 principles for companies, to guide them their value system and culture towards sustainability. ğŸŒ± These principles were based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Labor Organization’s Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, and the UN Convention Against Corruption.  

Okay, got it! ğŸ˜ Tell me more about these principles.

UNGC offers companies a unique opportunity to align their practices with a sustainable and inclusive future. Using this program, the investee companies are encouraged to align their strategies and operations with universal principles in the areas of human rights, labor, the environment, and anti-corruption, and take actions that promote societal goals. UNGC and OECD principles work towards corporate social responsibility in a complementary way.

The UNGC principles are broad and consist of 10 following principles under four section:

Human Rights ğŸ‘±‍â™€ï¸ğŸ‘±:

  1.     Principle 1.The business should support the international human rights
  2.     Principle 2: They should not be involved in violations of such rights

Labor ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ”§:

  1.   Principle 3: Business should encourage freedom to association as well as right of collective bargaining
  2.     Principle 4:  should not be involved in any kind of forced labor or bonded labor
  3.     Principle 5: should work towards eliminating child labour
  4.     Principle 6: should not support any discrimination at workplace in any manner

Environment ğŸŒ¿:

  1.     Principle 7: support a precautionary approach to environmental challenges
  2.     Principle 8: take measures to improve environmental responsibility
  3.     Principle 9: promote use of environmental friendly technologies

Anti-corruption ğŸ¦:

  1. Principle 10: work against corruption in all forms including bribery

  

The OECD guidelines are detailed and cover the topics left by UNGC such as taxation. The UNGC works through dialogues, networking, partnerships, learnings, and initiatives among its participants. Because of the importance of UNGC, this was included as one of the disclosure requirements under recently introduced SFDR in the EU.

 

So what's this SFDR now?? ğŸ§

A legislation came into being in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, in short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law to make the financial system sustainable. It consists of disclosure requirements in the form of PAI statements. ğŸ™Œ

 

Are those PAIs of any use to me? 

The PAI indicator of SFDR is another attempt to create a financial system which promotes sustainable business and integrity by stopping the fundings to companies who violate norms of basic human rights or other UNGC norms. ğŸ‘Š If you, as an investor, would like to eliminate this kind of a company from your portfolio since human rights and labor issues are close to your heart, then those PAIs could help you make a decision. PAI indicators will impact the stock selection in a big way and the fund manager will try to create portfolios only with good PAI indicators. ğŸ¥°

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

So, in detail, it pretty much means that companies who seek investment, must disclose their impact on other stakeholders such as employees, society or biodiversity systems, and cannot just work for the shareholder and their profitability.â˜ï¸

Thus, with the new SFDR and UNGC violations as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in ethical and sustainable society, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and where do they stand in comparison to their competitors. ğŸ¤©

 

Who does this apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. âœ‹ Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market , therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. ğŸ‘

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care?

Because UNGC principles are basic principles of equity and has over 13000 corporate participants. This PAI indicator along with others are working towards the UN SDG goals through controlling finance to the investee companies.  Hence, the sustainable funds under SFDR would be easier to identify based on their PAI statements and their ranking on the basis of the metrics used. It will be good for you to diversify your portfolio towards sustainable investment.

articles.a_content:
In recent years financial sector ğŸ¦ involvement in sustainable development ğŸŒ±has increasingly become a central issue instead of a peripheral one. The financial institutions are making efforts at a varied level to make their financing and investment decisions sustainable. What are these players doing in order to make sustainable investing truly meaningful? Why was Sustainable Finance Disclosure regulation introduced in the EU and how can it make the journey easier for the impact investors? What is the Principal Adverse Impact in SFDR? ğŸ¤·

Let’s unravel the mystery behind them!! ğŸ™Œ

 

ğŸ‘‰ Principal Adverse Impact (PAI)

 

PAIs are disclosure statements within the ambit of Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation. SFDR was introduced in the EU in March 2021 to regulate sustainable investing, by requiring financial market participants (like banks, mutual funds, pension funds) to transparently report the negative impact of their financing and advisory decisions on the sustainable factors. â˜ï¸ A principal adverse impact is the result of investment decisions (and advice) that cause negative effects on sustainability factors. By measuring adverse impacts associated with the activities of underlying investee companies, PAI analyzes how sustainability factors are impacted. ğŸ’‍â™‚ï¸

 

ğŸ‘‰ What are the negative impacts? 

Article 4 of the SFDR requires financial market participants (including managers) to publish and maintain information regarding the adverse impacts their investment decision-making process may have on sustainability factors on their websites. So, this obligation to ‘comply or explain’ is at entity level and not on individual funds. Thus, managers will need to aggregate information at funds level to present them at the entity level.

Furthermore, according to Article 7 of the SFDR, the prospectus of each fund must indicate whether the manager fulfills the reporting requirements imposed by Article 4 and whether it considers the principal adverse impacts of investment decisions on sustainability factors when managing its assets.

 

ğŸ‘‰ What type of PAI indicators should managers’ report?

The PAI indicators are categorized into mandatory (18 in total) and optional (46 in total). Their focus will be on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors commonly observed by investors. The disclosure regarding them is at both product and entity level. At the product level entities must disclose how PAIs are integrated into all aspects of a product and at the entity level measurement and disclosure of PAI must be done for the entity.

PAIs could be either climate and environmental ğŸŒ± related indicators or social and employee ğŸ‘©‍ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ’¼ matters. The detailed list is as follows:

 

Climate and environmental indicators:

  1.   GHG emissions (Scope 1, 2, 3 and total)
  2.   Carbon footprint
  3.   GHG intensity of investee companies
  4.   Exposure to company active in the fossil fuel sector
  5.   Share of non-renewable energy consumption and production
  6.   Energy consumption intensity per high impact climate sector
  7.   Activities negatively affecting biodiversity sensitive areas
  8.   Emissions to water
  9.   Hazardous waste ratio

 

PAIs related to social or employee matters:

  1. Violations of UN Global Compact principles and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises
  2. Lack of processes and compliance mechanisms to monitor compliance with UN Global Compact principles and OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises
  3. Unadjusted gender pay gap
  4. Board gender diversity
  5. Exposure to controversial weapons (anti personnel mines, cluster munitions, chemical weapons and biological weapons

 

PAI related to Supranational:

  1.           Investee countries subject to social violations
  2.           GHG Intensity of Investee Countries

PAI related to real estate:

  1.           Exposure to fossil fuels through real estate
  2.           Exposure to energy-inefficient real estate

 

So, what does that all mean for retail investors? ğŸ¤¨

Even though the regulation does not require ranking of PAIs or how good or bad a company is, as soon as reporting will start in January 2023, investors will have these statements about invested companies and the risk they pose to sustainability.” ğŸ‘€

Thus, SFDR and the PAI statements can facilitate easy filtering for the investors in terms of their investment goals. The Act aims at eliminating ğŸ™…‍â™€ï¸ greenwashing by the financial institutions and forcing them to align their financial and investment decisions for sustainability.

 

Who does this apply to? ğŸ§

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. The PAI statements are to be made by managers with an average number of 500 employees or more in the prescribed template. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future.

 

 

Yeah that sounds good… But why should I care? ğŸ¤¨

Because these PAIs will bring transparency and liability in the field of sustainable investing, making comparisons would be easier for you now. âš–ï¸ One no longer has to thoroughly research the funds’ impacts on their own but can instead trust the disclosures in term of their impact statements. ğŸ“„ So it seems that with specific framework for consideration of ESG fragments, investing could be fun and safe.

articles.a_content:
GHG emissions of Greenhouse Gas Emissions is one of the most used terms in the context of climate change or global warming. ğŸŒ What do we mean by GHG or Greenhouse Gas? Why is it necessary to measure and reduce it? What are the efforts of governments and the private sector in this direction? ğŸ¤” Let's understand them one by one. â˜ï¸

The greenhouse gas effect is a natural phenomenon, but due to human activities, the rate of emissions has increased substantially in the last 50 years. ğŸ“ˆ This increase is not good for us or the environment. ğŸ˜° So how do we know how much GHG emissions should there be? And what do we mean by scope 1, 2 and 3? ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

 

Greenhouse Gasses are present naturally in the atmosphere, and they make the Earth's surface warmer as they absorb and emit radiation within the thermal infrared range causing the greenhouse gas effect. Due to human activities such as the burning of fossil fuel, deforestation, and production of electricity,  this effect has increased substantially causing climate change and global warming. ğŸ˜¥ The biggest culprit here is carbon dioxide from burning fuels such as coal, natural gas and oil. ğŸ¥´

 

Carbon dioxide or CO2 has a major role in this emission, i.e. almost 75%, the other GHGs are methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons etc. Internationally GHG protocol does the accounting and reporting of emissions, and these emissions are categorized into three segments:

 

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 1: These are the direct emissions from the assets owned and/or controlled by the company. For example, machines ğŸ­, equipment ğŸ–¨ owned by the company or buses ğŸšŒ operated by the company for employee transportation.

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 2: Indirect emissions from purchased electricity, from the cooling or heating system. ğŸ’¡

ğŸ‘‰ Scope3: This segment is also indirect emission and the most comprehensive one.  This includes all the emissions in the value chain. For example, emissions by vehicles ğŸš˜ used by employees for commuting to work. This emission is more complex than the other two as the investee company will have limited control over the data and reporting of it.

 

What are the main sources of emission? ğŸ§

According to IPCC, the major sectors of these emissions are transportation (27%) ğŸš˜, generation of electricity (25%) ğŸ’¡, industry (24%) ğŸ­, commercial and residential (13%) ğŸ™ and agriculture (11%) ğŸŒ¾.

 

What are the regulations to control and measure these emissions? ğŸ“‘

The United Nations Environmental Program Agency collects and reports data from major industrial sources of GHG emissions. The Paris Agreement, signed between 196 countries in 2015, is a landmark judgment in this direction. Its goal is to limit global warming to well below 2, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius, compared to pre-industrial levels. ğŸ™Œ In order to achieve this target it is necessary to be net-zero by 2050. â˜ï¸ Moreover, recently, legislation came into force in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, in short SFDR. ğŸ¤© This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable ğŸŒ± as it requires institutional investors and financial advisors to report on sustainability risk and principal adverse impact (PAI). These PAI indicators are the impact of social or climate factors. Read more about these PAI in our earlier articles in the series.

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

GHG emissions should be halved by 2030, to keep global warming below 1.5 degrees by 2100! âœŠ However, the global efforts are not visible just yet. ğŸ˜ª  SFDR could be a watershed regulation for channelizing finance for sustainable development. ğŸ¤© Thus, with the new SFDR, we, the investors interested in green investment funds, will know much more about whether these funds are actually green and sustainable, and also how their financials might be influenced by sustainability risks. ğŸ¤¤ GHG emissions are a good way to measure climate-related and reputational risk in your investment. ğŸ˜Œ

 

 

Who does this apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. âœ‹ Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market , therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. ğŸ‘

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤¨ 

The word "green" does not mean that something is sustainable. ğŸ™… Moreover, taking care of just direct emissions is not enough. Indirect emissions also need to be addressed by the companies, as both the direct and indirect greenhouse emissions are contributing to global warming. ğŸ¥µ Hence, with the reporting and labeling, it would be easier for you as an investor to choose a company to invest in within an industry or a sector. ğŸ¤©
