articles.a_content:
GHG Carbon footprint has been introduced as one of the PAI indicators under the recently introduced Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation or SFDR. 

What does it mean? How is it related to sustainability? And why do we need to measure them? ğŸ¤”

The GHG carbon footprint is used to measure total GHG emissions caused by an individual or a company. Carbon dioxide or CO2 has the major role in this emission, i.e. almost 75%, the other GHGs are methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, and perfluorocarbons. To make it simple, every GHG measurement is the equivalent of CO2. Therefore, a company's carbon footprint entails more than just burning fossil fuels. It also has the indirect emissions associated with their services and products.

Internationally GHG protocol does the accounting and reporting of emissions, and these emissions are categorized into three segments:

ğŸ‘‰Scope 1: These are the direct emissions from the assets owned and/or controlled by the company. For example, machines ğŸ­, equipment ğŸ–¨ owned by the company or buses ğŸšŒ operated by the company for employee transportation.

ğŸ‘‰Scope 2: Indirect emissions from purchased electricity, from the cooling or heating system. ğŸ’¡

ğŸ‘‰Scope3: This segment is also indirect emission and the most comprehensive one. This includes all the emissions in the value chain. For example, emissions by vehicles ğŸš˜ used by employees for commuting to work. This emission is more complex than the other two as the investee company will have limited control over the data and reporting of it.

 

Looking into these is important since on the surface, a company that, e.g., offers service to its customers might not appear to have much carbon emissions, but it might actually produce scope 3 emissions which is even more than a company that makes cars. ğŸ§

 

Who measures these emissions for companies? ğŸ¤·

The United Nations Environmental Program Agency collects and reports data from major industrial sources of GHG emissions. The Paris Agreement, signed in 2015 is the most widely followed regulation for reducing them. This agreement was ratified by 196 countries and requires binding commitment from countries to reduce their carbon footprint. Moreover, recently, legislation came into force in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, in short SFDR. ğŸ¤© This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable ğŸŒ± as it requires institutional investors and financial advisors to report on sustainability risk and principal adverse impact (PAI). These PAI indicators are the impact of social or climate factors. Read more about these PAI in our earlier articles in the series. ğŸ™Œ

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

So, in detail, it pretty much means that companies that are preaching sustainability, must disclose their sustainability risks and, from 2022, their principal adverse impacts. ğŸ‘Š Sustainability risks refer here to the risks that sustainability factors have on a fund's financial return. Principal adverse impacts, on the other hand, refer to the impacts that the fund has on, as the SFDR states, "environmental, social and employee matters, respect for human rights, antiâ€corruption and antiâ€bribery matters." ğŸ‘€

Thus, with the new SFDR, we, the investors interested in sustainable funds, will know much more about whether these funds are green and sustainable, and also how their financials might be influenced by carbon footprint. ğŸ¤¤

 

Who does this apply to?

We just need to scroll through the news on our phones to see the effect of greenhouse gasses (GHGs) and the consequent climate change. ğŸ˜° This increase in the GHGs is not good for us or for the environment. But it’s not just the total amount of emissions that matters. The intensity of this emission is equally crucial to make a comparison between different entities, both at individual, societal and global levels. Let’s understand what emissions and emissions intensity are, and the importance of measuring them. â˜ï¸

 

What are carbon emissions? ğŸ¤”

Carbon emissions, or the GHG emissions, are the Greenhouse Gasses emitted by various human activities. These gasses like CO2, Methane, Chlorofluorocarbons etc. cause global warming and climate change. ğŸ¥µ Internationally GHG protocol does the accounting and reporting of emissions, and these emissions are categorized into three segments: 

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 1: These are the direct emissions from the assets owned and/or controlled by the company. For example, machines and equipment ğŸ— owned by the company or buses ğŸšŒ operated by the company for employee transportation.

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 2: Indirect emissions from purchased electricity, the cooling or heating system. ğŸ’¡

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 3: This segment  also consists of indirect emissions and is the most comprehensive one. It  includes all the emissions in the value chain. For example, emissions by vehicles used by employees for commuting to work. ğŸš™ This emission is more complex than the other two as the investee company will have limited control over the data and reporting of it.

 

GHG intensity and its measurement ğŸ“ˆ

GHG intensity is defined  as the volume of carbon emissions per million dollars of revenue (carbon efficiency of a portfolio, expressed in tons CO2e/ $M revenue). Simply saying, it is the total emissions divided by total units of production or total economic activity.

Total GHG intensity of electricity generation is calculated as the ratio of CO2 equivalent emissions from all sources of electricity production (including nuclear power plants, wind farms, and solar farms) to total electricity production. A total of energy consumption in production overhead and additional emission in the production process to calculate  total GHGs released in energy consumption.

GHG Intensity means the total greenhouse gas emissions of the parent company and its subsidiaries measured in Metric Tons of CO2e, per Million Dollars in revenue. The metric tons of CO2e includes Scope 1 (direct) and Sope 2 (energy indirect, market-based) emissions according to the World Resources Institute (WRI) and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) Greenhouse Gas Protocols.

 

Why is this indicator important? ğŸ§

Carbon dioxide or CO2 has a major role in the total GHG emission, i.e., almost 75%. The other GHGs are methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons etc. Though naturally present in the air, Greenhouse Gasses make the earth surface warmer causing multiple ripple effects on climate, biodiversity and our health. ğŸ˜£ Due to human activities such as the burning of fossil fuels, deforestation, and production of electricity, this effect has increased substantially causing climate change and global warming. 

 

How could the GHG intensity be reduced? ğŸ“‰

Improved energy efficiency, conservation, and the use of lower-carbon energy sources are the most cost-effective ways to decrease GHG intensity. â˜ï¸ International climate policy is regulated by the United Nations, and through a series of climate summits, also known as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate change, measures were taken to reduce corporate emission intensity. The main accounting tool used till now is the Greenhouse Gas Protocol, used as a standard for quantifying and reporting organizational level carbon footprint. The United Nations Environmental Program Agency collects and reports data from major industrial sources of GHG emissions.

Recently, legislation came into force in the EU in March 2021, under the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable as it requires institutional investors and financial advisors to report on sustainability risk and principal adverse impact (PAI). ğŸ‘ These PAIs are the impact of social or climate factors. You can read more about these PAIs in our earlier articles in the series. ğŸ‘ˆ 

 

Okay, but how would SFDR help with GHGs? ğŸ¤¨

SFDR has made it mandatory for financial market participants to disclose the GHG intensity in the PAI template. So, now with a detailed explanation of emissions (scope-wise) as well as emission intensity, it would be easier to make an assessment of companies in terms of whether they are actually doing the emissions or just a part of their value chain. 

Thus, with the new SFDR, we, the investors interested in green investment funds, will know much more about whether these funds are actually green and sustainable, and also how their financials might be influenced by sustainability risks. ğŸ¤¤ GHG emissions are a good way to measure climate-related and reputational risk in your investment.

 

Who does this apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprises the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future.

 

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤·ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

Because it is a material risk to the investment. When selecting companies for your portfolio, sustainability risk plays a similar role as market risk. Just accounting for direct emissions is not enough, indirect emissions need to be taken care of by the companies, as both the direct and indirect greenhouse emissions are contributing to global warming. â˜ï¸ Hence, with the reporting and labeling of these companies, it would be easier for you as an investor to choose within an industry or a sector. ğŸ‘

You must have heard a lot about companies switching towards cleaner modes of energy and calls to stop using fossil fuels to meet our energy needs.ğŸ‘‚ What are these fossil fuels, and why are they considered bad for the environment? What is the urgency to switch to renewable sources of energy? Let's dig deeper and know more. ğŸ‘‡

 

Fossil fuels are the non-renewable source of energy which run our homes, industries, and the economy. ğŸ­ Coal, natural gas, and oil constitute this fossil fuel, which are carbon-based and considered a major source of Greenhouse Gas emissions. One thing to know about them is that they are not infinite, which means they will be exhausted with continuous utilization. ğŸ“‰ Moreover, their usage is causing damage to the ecological system in multiple aspects. ğŸ˜©

 

 

What's the fuss about Fossil fuels? ğŸ¤”

First of all, burning fossil fuels is polluting the environment. ğŸŒ± Moreover, exposure to the companies active in the fossil fuel sector poses both sustainability risk as well as market risk for you as an investor. ğŸ˜ So, if you invest in companies active in this sector or in companies that have exposure to those companies, you could face a risk to your portfolio. ğŸ¥´ Fossil fuels are responsible for two thirds of emissions in the last twenty years. ğŸ˜± And it is worth noting that in the EU almost 70% of the energy comes from fossil fuel (petroleum products- 35%, natural gas-24%, solid fossil fuel-12%). ğŸ˜¤ Most of this fossil fuel in Europe comes from Russia. ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º With the Russian-Ukraine war the urgency for reducing this exposure is doubled.â—ï¸

  

Why is fossil fuel bad?ğŸ‘

Fossil fuels cause negative externality for the community and the environment. A few examples of these externalities are- air and water pollution, oil spills, health problems, rise in the sea level, severe flooding etc. And these impacts create a chain of further consequences which endanger the sustainability of the planet itself. ğŸ˜¥ Take, for instance, a rise in the sea level could submerge areas and even countries lying closer to sea level, endangering assets of trillion dollars.

 

It’s simple, isn’t it?. Just don't burn fossil fuels. ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

 

Well, it's not that simple. ğŸ˜… The Paris agreement of the United Nations Framework for Climate Change (UNFCCC) aims for achieving decarbonization by phasing out fossil fuel by mid century. However, according to the 2021 Production gap report of the United Nations Environment programme, the achievements in this regard are not satisfactory. ğŸ˜• Hence, SFDR is part of the European Union’s sustainable development plan to phase out non-renewable sources from the energy mix. SFDR requires financial market participants to make disclosure regarding their exposure in this segment through Principal adverse impact statements. â˜ï¸ 

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

So, in detail, it pretty much means that companies who want the shades-of-green labels must disclose their sustainability risks and, from 2022, their principal adverse impacts. ğŸ‘Š Sustainability risks refer to the risks that sustainability factors have on a fund's financial return. Principal Adverse Impacts, on the other hand, refer to the impacts that the fund has on, as the SFDR states, "environmental, social and employee matters, respect for human rights, antiâ€corruption and antiâ€bribery matters." ğŸ‘€

Thus, with the new SFDR, we, the investors interested in clean energy funds, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working for renewable energy or not, and also how their financials might be influenced by sustainability risks. ğŸ¤¤

 

 

ğŸ‘‰Who does this apply to?

 Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. âœ‹ Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market , therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. ğŸ‘

 

I guess that's all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤¨

Because with companies being open about their actions, you can choose the ones that are behaving responsibly to invest in, and so, reduce the negative impact of business on the planet. ğŸŒ Of course, you can use solar panels in your home to generate electricity, but by using your investment options wisely, you could create a chain of impacts for the sustainable ocean, marine life, human health and many more. ğŸ’š

Have you thought about the percentage of non-renewable sources of energy consumption and production to renewable sources in the companies you are investing in? What are renewable energy sources and why are they called alternative sources of energy? And why does Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation talk about them as one of the Principal Adverse Impacts? ğŸ¤”

Let’s start the ride to understanding these concepts and their importance in your impact investing journey. ğŸš€

Fossil fuels (non-renewable sources of energy) are responsible for two-thirds of emissions in the last twenty years. In the European Union also, almost 70% of the energy comes from fossil fuel (petroleum products- 35%, natural gas- 24%, solid fossil fuel- 12%). Moreover, non-renewable sources like coal, natural gas, oil and nuclear energy cannot replenish themselves, hence their consumption and production are limited in supply. ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ Unfortunately, we are still dependent on these energy sources in our daily lives. ğŸ˜• Have you thought about how much percentage of non-renewable energy is in the consumption and production of your investee companies? Because the higher the percentage of renewable sources in their energy mix, the more sustainable these companies are! ğŸ’š

 

ğŸ‘‰ What does SFDR say about renewable sources?

Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation talks about consumption and production of non-renewable sources of energy as one of the disclosure requirements from the investee company. This Act aims at bringing transparency and standardization in the field of sustainable investing. The Act has 18 Principal Adverse Impacts (disclosure statements) relating to companies, supranational or real estate sectors on environmental & social matters.

The metric uses the share of non-renewable energy consumption and non-renewable energy production of investee companies from non-renewable energy sources compared to renewable energy sources expressed as a percentage. Reducing this percentage is crucial to meet the Paris Agreement goals of a carbon neutral planet by 2050. â˜ï¸

 

Why is renewable energy good for the planet? ğŸŒ

Renewable energy sources are clean and sustainable sources of energy, e.g., solar, wind, hydropower, and solid biofuels. Moreover, they have the potential to replace fossil fuel in three main sectors such as cooling & heating, electricity, and transportation. They are both economical and sustainable in the long run. ğŸ‘ For instance, the economic cost of solar energy is foreseeable and could be planned. On the other hand, the cost of natural gas is not only affected by economic factors but also geo-political factors (as seen in war situations). ğŸ˜” So, alternative energy is sustainable from a financial and non-financial (Environmental, Social, Governance) view point. SFDR aims at minimizing greenwashing and offering a transparent view into sustainability investments for the end users. ğŸ˜Œ

 

That’s great! Tell me more about this ğŸ¤©

Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation is one of three pillars of the European Union Action Plan on Sustainable Finance (the other two being EU taxonomy and Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive).

SFDR works on a double materiality basis. A company must work on not only the financial aspect or financial materiality but also the impact materiality (the E, S and G aspects). The Act covers the financial materiality in terms of sustainability risks, which are the sustainability issues (climate change, gender disparity) that can have a negative impact on the economic returns of an investment. ğŸ“‰ Sustainability risks refer to the risks that sustainability factors have on a fund’s financial return. Principal Adverse Impacts, on the other hand, cover the impact materiality. They are the negative impacts that the fund has on “environmental, social and employee matters, respect for human rights, antiâ€corruption and antiâ€bribery matters.” ğŸ‘€

Thus, with the new legislative tool in the form of SFDR, end users can be sure of getting reliable ESG information for investing their capital toward Sustainable Development Goals. ğŸ‘

Who does this apply to?

A European Union directive, the SFDR applies directly to participants of the financial markets and advisors within the EU. It does, however, not exclude institutions located outside of the Union from its impact. ğŸ˜± Anyone marketing their product within the EU must follow the rules laid out by the directive, whether they are European or not. ğŸ˜® We can also expect to see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts as the EU is the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China).

 

This sounds amazing! But why should I care? ğŸ¤¨

Because of the increased focus on reducing the percentage of nonrenewable energy from the energy mix, more investment and research would be directed toward the renewable sector. Along with PAI # 5 ‘non-renewable energy consumption and production’, the investee company will be making detailed disclosure about their exposure to non-renewable energy irrespective of the industry they are in. This Regulation will bridge the information asymmetry between capital providers (investors) and capital seekers (financial market participants).

Are we, human beings, the sole inhabitants of this planet?

Of course we’re not, duh. ğŸ™„ Although let’s be honest, we’re sometimes acting like we are. ğŸ˜… In reality, we are surrounded by other living beings and a complex intertwined biosystem. We, as human beings, have the largest impact on biodiversity, which can be both positive and negative. ğŸ‘‰So… Is the government actually doing anything in this matter?

The PAI indicator of ‘activities negatively affecting biodiversity sensitive areas’ in SFDR is another attempt to maintain biological diversity. ğŸŒ¿ Every business entity needs capital or money to run but the question is how they earn it. Thus, with the new SFDR and biodiversity negative impact as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in environment, climate change and biodiversity, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and where do they stand compared to competitors. ğŸ‘

Because life on another planet is not possible!!! âŒ

We have to reduce our carbon footprint ( or simply the sustained usage of resources). The companies cannot keep on extracting resources infinitely and causing biodiversity loss to sensitive areas which are biodiversity hotspots.ğŸ˜© As an investor it is easier for you to use these disclosures by investee companies as per SFDR and PAI indicators, and rank them on the basis of their alignment with different SDG goals. ğŸ’ª

Waste is generated due to many human activities. In fact, in a recent tweet by Eurostat, a whopping 5.2 tonnes of waste was generated by EU inhabitants in 2018. ğŸ˜± So, what is being done at the individual level and at the society level? What steps is the government taking to recycle and reduce this waste? And what do we call a hazardous waste?

Let’s find out together! ğŸ’ª

Waste is any substance or object which the holder discards, intends or is required to discard. It potentially represents an enormous loss of resources in the form of both materials and energy. In simple words, waste is anything which we dispose of after use. ğŸš® In addition, the management and disposal of waste can have serious environmental impacts. ğŸ˜° For example, landfill takes up land space and may cause soil, air and water pollution, while incineration may result in emissions of air pollutants. 

Examples of waste could be anything from clothesğŸ‘š to daily waste ğŸ—‘ï¸, to electronic items ğŸ“±. Waste is treated differently according to their types in order to reduce their impact on the environment. In the short term, efforts are made to recycle it but in the long term, the focus should be on reducing it, also known as the concept of circular economy. â™»ï¸

 

ğŸ‘‰What is hazardous waste?

Hazardous waste is more dangerous to human health and environment if it is not separated and disposed of properly. It could be in gaseous, liquid or solid state. They could have in general one or more of the traits or characteristics: reactivity, toxicity, corrosivity or ignitability. Few examples are: batteries, petrol and kerosene, paints, pesticides and garden based chemicals. In the EU, in 2018, around 4.4% of the waste generated was hazardous. In general, waste is disposed of through landfill, deposited into land or released into water bodies, which as you can imagine, is not great. ğŸ˜ª

Okay, so how do we deal with this hazardous waste? ğŸ¤¨

The United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) is working towards reducing harmful and hazardous waste by providing support through scientific assessment and raising awareness about the issue. The Basel convention signed in 1992 is one of the major global efforts to control transboundary movement of hazardous waste and their disposal. Hence, basically the polluter pays principle applies here too. ğŸ’° Recently, a new legislation has been introduced in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, in short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable. This has included hazardous waste ratio as a PAI or Principal Adverse Impact. These PAIs are impacts of financing decisions on sustainable factors.

 

What is this PAI, is this related to pie??

Well, it gets kind of technical here, but we’ve got you! We’ll list them for easier understanding:

 

So, what is the logic behind these PAI indicators? ğŸ¤·

Despite years of efforts, hazardous waste remains a concern, and the amount is increasing substantially over the years. ğŸ“ˆ The PAI indicator of hazardous waste ratio in SFDR is another attempt to eliminate this gap by stopping the fundings to companies who do not follow the guidelines to handle hazardous waste disparity in one or the other form. These PAI indicators will impact the stock selection in a big way and the fund manager will try to create portfolios with good PAI indicators. This ratio is related to SDG number 3 (good health and well-being), 6 (clean water and sanitation), 11 (sustainable cities and communities),13 (climate action),14 (life below water) and 15 (life on land).

 

Great… Now explain it to me in normal English. ğŸ¤¨

So, it simply means that hazardous waste cannot be thrown like we threw a can ğŸ¥«in the dustbin. ğŸ—‘ The companies who generate this waste in bulk cannot abstain themselves by throwing this waste in land and water, and polluting them for further use. The cost of disposing of this waste has to be borne by the entity creating this waste.

Thus, with the new SFDR and hazardous waste ratio as one of the PAI indicators, the investors interested in the above SDG goals will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and where do they stand in comparison to their competitors.

So now, we, the investors interested in green investment funds, will know much more about whether these funds are actually green and sustainable, and also how their financials might be influenced by sustainability risks. ğŸ¤¤

 

 

Who does this SFDR apply to? ğŸ‘‡

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future.

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care?

Because all these PAI indicators are working towards various SDGs through controlling finance to the investee companies.  Hence, the sustainable funds under SFDR would be easier to identify based on their PAI statements and their ranking on the basis of the metrics used. It will be good for you to diversify your portfolio towards sustainable investment. ğŸ’š

The United Nations Global Compact or for short UNGC is a voluntary effort at the global level to support MNCs or multi-national companies (the companies that have business in many countries) that are committed to sustainable practices in areas such as the environment, labor rights, or corruption. ğŸ™Œ Let’s find out why this is so important, how UNGC monitors MNCs and why it is in news in the EU. ğŸ’ª

 

 

ğŸ‘‰ UNGC monitoring- multinational:

UNGC has a guideline of 10 principles for companies operating in multiple countries, to motivate them to include sustainability in their value system and culture. These principles were based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Labor Organization’s Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, and the UN Convention Against Corruption. UNGC is a strategic initiative to ensure business houses are doing business with ethics.

 

Great!! Tell me more about these principles ğŸ˜„

UNGC offers companies a unique opportunity to align their practices with a sustainable and inclusive future. Using this program, the investee companies are encouraged to align their strategies and operations with universal principles in the areas of human rights, labor, the environment, and anti-corruption, and take actions that promote societal goals. ğŸ¯ UNGC and OECD (Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) principles work towards corporate social responsibility in a complementary way and these are world’s largest initiatives in this direction. ğŸ‘†

The UNGC principles are broad and have the following 10 principles under four sections:

Human Rights ğŸ‘±‍â™€ï¸ğŸ‘±:

  1.     Principle 1.The business should support the international human rights
  2.     Principle 2: They should not be involved in violations of such rights

Labor ğŸ‘¨‍ğŸ”§:

  1.   Principle 3: Business should encourage freedom to association as well as right of collective bargaining
  2.     Principle 4:  should not be involved in any kind of forced labor or bonded labor
  3.     Principle 5: should work towards eliminating child labour
  4.     Principle 6: should not support any discrimination at workplace in any manner

Environment ğŸŒ¿:

  1.     Principle 7: support a precautionary approach to environmental challenges
  2.     Principle 8: take measures to improve environmental responsibility
  3.     Principle 9: promote use of environmental friendly technologies

Anti-corruption ğŸ¦:

  1. Principle 10: work against corruption in all forms including bribery

 

The OECD guidelines are detailed and cover the topics left by UNGC such as taxation. The UNGC works through dialogues, networking, partnerships, learnings, and initiatives among its participants. Because of the importance of UNGC, UNGC monitoring of the multinationals was included as one of the disclosure requirements under the recently introduced SFDR in the EU.

 

So what's this SFDR now?? ğŸ§

A legislation came into being in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, in short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law to make the financial system sustainable. It consists of disclosure requirements in the form of PAI statements. ğŸ™Œ

 

What is this PAI, is this related to pie?? ğŸ§

Well, it gets kind of technical here, but let’s simplify it.

 

The logic behind these PAI indicators:

The PAI indicator of SFDR is another attempt to create a financial system which promotes sustainable business and integrity by stopping the funding to companies who violate norms of basic human rights or other UNGC norms. âœ‹ Every business entity needs capital or money to run, but if you as an investor would like to eliminate this company from your portfolio as human rights and labor issues are close to your heart, then you could be happy. These PAI indicators will impact the stock selection in a big way and the fund manager will try to create portfolios with only good PAI indicators.

 

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

Big companies or multinationals need to have a system of processes and compliance mechanisms to monitor compliance with UN Global Compact principles and OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. They need to show their efforts towards working for all the stakeholders’ interests and not just focus on shareholders' profitability

 

Thus, with the new SFDR and UNGC violations as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in an ethical and sustainable society, will know much more about whether these funds are working towards this goal and where they stand in comparison to their competitors. 

 

Who does this apply to? 

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. 



I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care?

Because UNGC principles are basic principles of equity and have over 13000 corporate participants. This PAI indicator along with others is working towards the UN SDG goals through controlling finance to the investee companies. Hence, the sustainable funds under SFDR would be easier to identify based on their PAI statements and their ranking based on the metrics used. It will be good for you to diversify your portfolio toward sustainable investment. ğŸ’š

‘Equal pay for equal work’ is the basic principle which regulates the wage structure. This means that both men and women should get equal pay for equal work in a work situation in the absence of any other justifiable reason.ğŸ‘ However in reality, differences exist at ground level in almost all spheres be it a family, a business entity or in society in general.ğŸ˜ When this difference in pay occurs just because a person is a male or a female, it leads to gender pay-gap.

 

So, what is the gender pay-out gap and why is it important?

Is this gap the same in every country or is the situation better in the EU?

Is there any regulation to take care of it?!

We are here to answer all of those questions and understand the meaning and importance of this concept. ğŸ¤“

 

Gender Pay Gap

Gender doesn’t just mean being a male or a female from a biological point of view.ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ™… It refers to the social identity which is attached to a man or a woman. So, when in a work set-up, males are being offered higher salary as compared to females not due to any technical differences, but rather on the basis of gender identity, then a gender pay gap is created.ğŸ˜ª

There are many ways in which this gap can exist. Surprisingly, the gender pay gap exists even in the so-called developed countries.ğŸ˜® According to data from the International Labor Organisation (an International body regulating labor laws throughout the world), this difference is e.g., as high as 45% in the African country of Sierra Leone or almost negligible in Panama.ğŸ˜¢ Even in Europe, a persisting gap of 14.1% has been seen despite decades of efforts from the government's side.ğŸ¤¯

 

Why is it important to bridge this gender pay gap? ğŸ¤”

It has been proven by various reports and indices that gender equality in all forms is essential for the development of a nation.ğŸ“ˆ If females don’t get  equal pay for their work as men, it will be reflected in their social status and lead to their social exclusion.ğŸ™… That is why closing this gap would positively impact the world GDP (Gross Domestic Product).ğŸ¤ğŸ»

 

 

Soooo... Is the government doing anything about this? ğŸ§

Well, first of all, there has been convention number 100 from ILO for regulating equal pay across all genders. Also, in Europe, in order to implement  the principle of “equal pay for equal work”, the European Commission came up with “the EU action Plan 2017-19”, which was a plan to cover different aspects of the gender gap. Lastly, more recently, legislation has been introduced in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation- in short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable.ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸ğŸ¤“

 

What is this PAI, is this related to pie?? ğŸ¤¨

Despite years of efforts, gender pay disparity exists in most of the companies, though it has reduced considerably. The PAI indicator of unadjusted gender payout in SFDR is another attempt to eliminate this gap by stopping the fundings to companies who still have gender pay disparity in one or the other form.ğŸ‘ Every business entity needs capital or money to run, but if you as an investor would like to eliminate this company from your portfolio as gender equality is close to your heart, then you could be happy. ğŸ˜ These PAI indicators will impact the stock selection in a big way and the fund manager will try to create portfolios with good PAI indicators. Easy, right? ğŸ˜…

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

It pretty much means that companies who seek investment must make their impact on other stakeholders (e.g., employees, society or biodiversity system) transparent, and cannot just work to make profit. ğŸ™Œ So, with the new SFDR and gender pay-gap as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in gender parity, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and how they compare to their competitors. ğŸ‘Œ

 

 

Okay, so who does this apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, doesn’t mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the EU. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ¤­ The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), is an attractive market. This is why it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. ğŸ¤

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤·ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

 

Because gender pay-gap is a key indicator of gender inequality. So, a company cannot preach for the latter if it does not practice the former. ğŸ¤¨ Female participation at the workplace does not just end when they are employed, but rather more important is the position they are at and how much they earnâ€¼ï¸So as an investor it is easier for you to bring equality in society by choosing the right companies for your portfolio. âœŒï¸

Does it make a difference whether a woman is working as a Secretary or as CEO of a company? ğŸ‘€

Business houses as a part of society could play a significant role in increasing gender equality. The controversial weapons or arms are the weapons other than mass destruction or nuclear weapons. In the background of the Russian-Ukrainian war, the damages caused by these weapons have again become a matter of public debate. ğŸ“£ So what are these conventional weapons? How are they a threat to a sustainable society? And why were controversial weapons used as one of the disclosure requirements for the financial services sector in the recently introduced SFDR (Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation)?

 

Let’s find out ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸ğŸ‘‡

 

 

ğŸ‘‰ What are controversial weapons?

 

As the name suggests, these weapons are controversial in their usage. Every country has a right to safeguard its boundaries and they use military power and weapons to do so. However, many of these weapons cause damage that lasts longer than the conflict itself. ğŸ˜“ So what makes a weapon or an arm controversial? These weapons cause damage at a very large scale to everyone who is present without differentiating between who is a criminal, culprit or a civilian. â˜ ï¸ Moreover, their usage is ‘controlled’ and not ‘banned’ by different countries.



ğŸ‘‰ Why is it necessary to control these weapons?

 

These weapons could be chemical, cluster munitions, chemical, biological weapons, and  anti-personnel mines. There are many international agreements among countries to use these weapons safely. The production and use of these weapons are banned by treaties. However, countries still use these weapons whenever a situation of national interest arises. So, it becomes necessary to regulate the companies who are manufacturing and providing these weapons. â˜ï¸ As a responsible investor, the exposure of investee companies in these controversial weapons that include nuclear weapons, is a necessary indicator of your contribution to creating a peaceful society. â˜®ï¸




ğŸ‘‰ What measures are being taken at (inter)national level?

 

A number of international conventions exist to control production, distribution, use and transfer of these arms, for example, Geneva protocol, Treaty on the Non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, Biological Weapon Convention, and Oslo convention.  These treaties have their applicability at the global level. ğŸŒ However we need to focus on controlling the money which is going to finance production of these weapons. To control financing of controversial weapons, one of the Principal Adverse Impact statements in the newly introduced Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation(SFDR) explicitly mentions them. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making it compulsory for the financial system to include ESG aspects in their decision-making. ğŸ™Œ



Controlling investment in controversial weapons

 

Despite years of efforts, controversial weapons remain a threat to society. ğŸ˜° The large number of civilian deaths in Ukraine recently is a reminder to take swift action in this regard. The PAI indicator of ‘exposure to controversial weapons in investee companies’ in SFDR is another attempt to stop the fundings to companies that have any sort of exposure to conventional or nuclear weapons, which could result in mass casualty. ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ Every business entity needs capital or money to run, but if you as an investor would like to eliminate those companies from your portfolio, then referring to these PAI indicators will be able to impact your stock selection in a big way. ğŸ˜

 

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

 

So, SFDR  puts pressure on the financial services sector to incorporate sustainability risk into their financing and investing decisions. They need to disclose the impact of their decisions on sustainability factors. For example, impact on social parameters by the investee companies having exposure in the manufacturing and selling of anti-personnel mines, cluster munitions and biological weapons. Thus, with the new SFDR and controversial weapons as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in eliminating these companies, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and where do they stand in comparison to their competitors. ğŸ¤©



Who does this apply to? 

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. 



I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care?


Because the policy level regulations till now have proven to be insufficient, so as a responsible investor you can work towards excluding companies that have exposure to controversial weapons from your portfolio. ğŸ‘ SFDR and the PAI statements could help you in making these choices. ğŸ¤—

articles.a_content:
Can focusing on reducing emissions lead to sustainable countries? ğŸŒ± Or we need to focus on GHG intensity too. What is the emissions intensity and why is it crucial to measure GHG intensity of investee countries your portfolio is exposed to? Let’s understand the concept of GHG intensity for the investee countries. ğŸ’ª

What are GHG emissions? ğŸ¤”

GHG emissions or carbon emissions are gasses such as Carbon dioxide or CO2, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons which have profound impact on the earth’s temperature, leading to climate change. ğŸ¥µ GHG protocol does the accounting and reporting of emissions, and these emissions are categorized into three segments:

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 1: These are the direct emissions from the assets owned and/or controlled by the company. For example, machines or equipment ğŸ— owned by the company, buses ğŸšŒ operated by the company for employee transportation.

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 2: Indirect emissions from purchased electricity, from the cooling or heating system.

ğŸ’¡

ğŸ‘‰ Scope 3: This segment is also indirect emission and the most comprehensive one.  This includes all the emissions in the value chain. For example, emissions by vehicles ğŸš™ used by employees for commuting to work. This emission is more complex than the other two as the investee company will have limited control over the data and reporting of it.

 

GHG intensity and its measurement ğŸ“ˆ

GHG intensity is the emission rate of greenhouse gasses or the ratio of a particular pollutant to a specific activity or manufacturing process; for instance, the grams of carbon dioxide released per megajoule of energy produced, or the ratio of greenhouse gas emissions to gross domestic product (GDP). Technically, GHG intensity is defined  as the volume of carbon emissions per million dollars of revenue (carbon efficiency of a portfolio, expressed in tons CO2e/ $M revenue). While measuring GHG intensity for an investee country, it is the total emissions divided by total units of production or total economic activity.

 

So, can we measure it…? How? ğŸ˜®

It seems we can!! ğŸ™Œ For example, GHG intensity of total electricity generation is taken as the ratio of CO2 equivalent emissions from all electricity production (both from main activity producers and auto-producers) to total electricity generation, including electricity from nuclear plants and renewable sources. Similarly, for arriving at the total GHGs released in energy consumption for production, an aggregate of GHGs released in energy consumption for overhead, GHGs released by transport used for business travel and additional GHGs released from the production process is taken into account.

 

 

Take for instance, if the investee company makes a car, then GHG released from the factory, in the supply chain and also by the employees personal transportation to the company is considered to calculate the GHG intensity.

When we measure the emission intensity, we include both Scope 1 (direct) and Scope 2 (energy indirect, market-based) emissions in the the metric tons of CO2e (according to the World Resources Institute (WRI) and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) Greenhouse Gas Protocols).

 

Why is this indicator important? â˜ï¸

Because this indicator is the best indicator of the carbon footprint ğŸ‘£ and emission level of a country. Countries, such as Sweden, France, Luxemburg with higher usage of renewable power in their energy mix are having lower GHG intensity. ğŸ“‰ Whereas, countries such as Poland, Cyprus, Estonia and Greece had the highest electricity generation carbon intensity in the EU in 2020. ğŸ“ˆ

 

How could the GHG intensity be reduced? ğŸ‘‡

Improved energy efficiency, conservation, and the use of lower-carbon energy sources are the most cost-effective ways to decrease GHG intensity. ğŸ™Œ International climate policy is regulated by the United Nations and through a series of climate summits, also known as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate change, measures were taken to reduce corporate emission intensity. âœŠ The main accounting tool used till now is the Greenhouse Gas Protocol, used as a standard for quantifying and reporting organizational level carbon footprint. The United Nations Environmental Program Agency collects and reports data from major industrial sources of GHG emissions.

Recently, legislation came into force in the EU in March 2021, under the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable as it requires institutional investors and financial advisors to report on sustainability risk and principal adverse impact (PAI). These PAIs are the impact of social or climate factors. Read more about PAIs in our earlier articles in the series. ğŸ¤“

 

Okay, but how would SFDR work for this? ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

SFDR has made it mandatory for financial market participants to disclose the GHG intensity in the PAI template. So, now with a detailed explanation of emissions (scope-wise) as well as emission intensity, it would be easier to make an assessment of companies in terms of whether they are actually releasing the emissions or just a part of their value chain. 

Thus, with the new SFDR, we, the investors interested in green investment funds, will know much more about whether these funds are actually green and sustainable, and also how their financials might be influenced by sustainability risks. ğŸ¤¤ GHG emissions are a good way to measure climate-related and reputational risk in your investment. ğŸ’

 

 

 

So who does this apply to? ğŸ‘€

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprises the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future.

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? 

Because it is a material risk to the investment. â˜ï¸ When selecting companies for your portfolio, sustainability risk plays a similar role as market risk. Accounting only for direct emissions is not enough. Indirect emissions need to be taken care of by the companies, as both the direct and indirect greenhouse emissions are contributing to global warming. ğŸ¥µ Hence, with the reporting and labeling of these companies, it would be easier for you as an investor to choose within an industry or a sector. ğŸ˜Œ

articles.a_content:
Human rights are one of the crucial aspects of development. But still, we come across news of human rights or social violations-in both developed and developing countries. Are there international laws to prevent these social violations by countries? And if yes, why are they not being followed? ğŸ¤¨ Let’s understand why some social factors are more important in ranking a country. ğŸ‘‡

ğŸ‘‰ What are social violations?

When the fundamental rights to life are not guaranteed by the state, it amounts to social violation. The S (social part) of the ESG investing or sustainable investing is about considering the social factors e.g., human rights, workers minimum wage or bribery as a material risk in the investment decision making. These social factors have a material impact on the investment opportunity because different rating agencies rank a country not just on economic criteria but social metrics too. For example, recently Fitch downgraded the sovereign rating of Russia from ‘B’ to ‘C’, which simply means the country has a higher default risk. And the reason given by the rating agency is that Russia has an ESG Relevance Score (RS) of '5'(poor) for both Political Stability and Rights and for the Rule of Law, Institutional and Regulatory Quality and Control of Corruption. ğŸ‘ This is also in line with the World Bank Governance Indicators measuring dimensions of governance. Hence, despite having a good Balance Sheet assessment, a country can still have a low rating (due to social and governance factors).

 

So, how to measure social violations by investee countries? ğŸ¤”

The social violations could be measured by the number of investee countries subject to social violations (absolute number and relative number divided by all investee countries) as referred to in international treaties and convention, United Nations, principles, and where applicable national law.

For example, how would you rank a country in your investment options, if the country performs poorly in transparency index (to measure corruption) or Gini-coefficient (to measure economic inequality) or human development index? Sooner or later, the poor performance in the social parameters will be reflected in the investment scenario too! ğŸ˜±

But why is it in the news in the ESG investing space now?

Because the EU Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR) talks about the social violations by the investee countries as one of the PAI statements. In the absence of any mandatory reporting for the financial market participants for their investment in sovereign countries, it was quite challenging to find sustainable options. ğŸ˜°

Earlier, principles were laid down by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Labor Organization’s Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, and the UN Convention Against Corruption for the countries. However, these guidelines didn’t have any legal mandate plus a lack of clarity in defining social violations by countries. ğŸ˜’

So, after SFDR, double materiality should be a focus for you as an investor. Both financial materiality and impact materiality should be taken into account by the institutional investor. â˜ï¸

 

Who does SFDR apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future.

 

Great!! Tell me more! ğŸ˜

After the pandemic, a significant number of institutional investors are looking at the poor performance of the countries in social factors. According to the EY Global Institutional Investor Survey, ‘74% of institutional investors now are more likely to “divest” based on poor environmental, social and governance (ESG) performance, than before the COVID-19 pandemic’.

Similar to risk specific to companies, there are country risks involved in investing in a supranational company. Moody’s, Standard & Poor and other large rating agencies give ratings to this country, however most of these ratings consider the country’s economic and financial fundamentals. Hence, the sovereign ratings may not give a complete picture while investing in a country.

Diversity, equity and inclusion initiates are the crucial parameters to check sustainability level of an investee country. ğŸ™Œ

ğŸ‘‰ Why does monitoring investments in investee countries matter?

Because they are the source of long-term finance for the investee countries' development. And also, ESG factors are material to investment decision making not just for the impact investors, but for the quality of life of the people from the concerned country.

Thus, with the new SFDR and social violations by the investee country as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in ethical and sustainable society, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and where do they stand in comparison to their competitors.

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

Because transparency is the new human right, disclosure about the adverse social violations is key to curb greenwashing. ğŸ‘ The institutional efforts must intensify their efforts to make an impact in the society in terms of quality of life.

These PAI indicators along with others are working towards the UN SDG goals through controlling finance to the investee companies.  Hence, the sustainable funds under SFDR would be easier to identify based on their PAI statements and their ranking based on the metrics used. It will be good for you to diversify your portfolio towards sustainable investment. ğŸ‘Œ

‘Equal pay for equal work’ is the basic principle which regulates the wage structure. This means that both men and women should get equal pay for equal work in a work situation in the absence of any other justifiable reason.ğŸ‘ However in reality, differences exist at ground level in almost all spheres be it a family, a business entity or in society in general.ğŸ˜ When this difference in pay occurs just because a person is a male or a female, it leads to gender pay-gap.

 

So, what is the gender pay-out gap and why is it important?

Is this gap the same in every country or is the situation better in the EU?

Is there any regulation to take care of it?!

We are here to answer all of those questions and understand the meaning and importance of this concept. ğŸ¤“

 

Gender Pay Gap

Gender doesn’t just mean being a male or a female from a biological point of view.ğŸ™…‍â™‚ï¸ğŸ™… It refers to the social identity which is attached to a man or a woman. So, when in a work set-up, males are being offered higher salary as compared to females not due to any technical differences, but rather on the basis of gender identity, then a gender pay gap is created.ğŸ˜ª

There are many ways in which this gap can exist. Surprisingly, the gender pay gap exists even in the so-called developed countries.ğŸ˜® According to data from the International Labor Organisation (an International body regulating labor laws throughout the world), this difference is e.g., as high as 45% in the African country of Sierra Leone or almost negligible in Panama.ğŸ˜¢ Even in Europe, a persisting gap of 14.1% has been seen despite decades of efforts from the government's side.ğŸ¤¯

 

Why is it important to bridge this gender pay gap? ğŸ¤”

It has been proven by various reports and indices that gender equality in all forms is essential for the development of a nation.ğŸ“ˆ If females don’t get  equal pay for their work as men, it will be reflected in their social status and lead to their social exclusion.ğŸ™… That is why closing this gap would positively impact the world GDP (Gross Domestic Product).ğŸ¤ğŸ»

 

 

Soooo... Is the government doing anything about this? ğŸ§

Well, first of all, there has been convention number 100 from ILO for regulating equal pay across all genders. Also, in Europe, in order to implement  the principle of “equal pay for equal work”, the European Commission came up with “the EU action Plan 2017-19”, which was a plan to cover different aspects of the gender gap. Lastly, more recently, legislation has been introduced in the EU in March 2021, with the name Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation- in short SFDR. This regulation is a comprehensive piece of law for making the financial system sustainable.ğŸ’‍â™€ï¸ğŸ¤“

 

What is this PAI, is this related to pie?? ğŸ¤¨

Despite years of efforts, gender pay disparity exists in most of the companies, though it has reduced considerably. The PAI indicator of unadjusted gender payout in SFDR is another attempt to eliminate this gap by stopping the fundings to companies who still have gender pay disparity in one or the other form.ğŸ‘ Every business entity needs capital or money to run, but if you as an investor would like to eliminate this company from your portfolio as gender equality is close to your heart, then you could be happy. ğŸ˜ These PAI indicators will impact the stock selection in a big way and the fund manager will try to create portfolios with good PAI indicators. Easy, right? ğŸ˜…

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

It pretty much means that companies who seek investment must make their impact on other stakeholders (e.g., employees, society or biodiversity system) transparent, and cannot just work to make profit. ğŸ™Œ So, with the new SFDR and gender pay-gap as one of the PAI indicators, we, the investors interested in gender parity, will know much more about whether these funds are actually working towards this goal and how they compare to their competitors. ğŸ‘Œ

 

 

Okay, so who does this apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, doesn’t mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the EU. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ¤­ The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), is an attractive market. This is why it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future. ğŸ¤

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤·ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

 

Because gender pay-gap is a key indicator of gender inequality. So, a company cannot preach for the latter if it does not practice the former. ğŸ¤¨ Female participation at the workplace does not just end when they are employed, but rather more important is the position they are at and how much they earnâ€¼ï¸So as an investor it is easier for you to bring equality in society by choosing the right companies for your portfolio. âœŒï¸

articles.a_title: Exposure to fossil fuel through real estate (SFDR, PAI #17) ğŸ™

articles.a_content:
The real estate sector is one of the highest Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emitting sectors, contributing to almost 40% of the annual global GHG emissions and consuming approximately one-third of global energy. ğŸ˜± What makes this sector so energy intensive? How much of this consumption comes from fossil fuel? Why is it necessary to promote energy efficiency in commercial and residential buildings?

 

Energy inefficient real estate sector

Our homesğŸ , industries ğŸ­, and economy ğŸ¦ are mostly powered by fossil fuels, which are not renewable. Carbon-based fossil fuels, such as coal, natural gas, and oil, contribute to global warming as they emit polluting gasses. Moreover, because of their non-infinite nature, we will eventually run out of them, and their continuous use is damaging the ecosystem on multiple levels. ğŸ˜° Hence, sustainability risk is a major cause of concern in the real estate sector because of its carbon footprint. ğŸ‘£ Thus, we need funding for energy-efficient infrastructure. It is because of this reason, that the new regulation Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation or SFDR has been introduced as an unified framework in the EU to incorporate sustainability risk and negative impact of financial market participants. To measure this negative impact, SFDR has a set of 18 mandatory statements called PAI or Principle Adverse Impact. The energy-inefficient real estate sector is one of the mandatory PAIs.

 

ğŸ‘‰ But why does the finance sector and investors need this disclosure?

Many efforts have been made at the international level like the Kyoto protocol, United Nations Framework for Climate change, and the iconic Paris agreement which all work toward the same goal- a sustainable planet. ğŸŒâ™»ï¸ However, the real estate sector is still way behind its goal of being carbon neutral by 2050.

For impactors who are investing for the long term, energy-efficient real estate could offer great investment opportunities as these investments can boost portfolio return in the most cost-effective and low-risk manner. ğŸ™Œ So, the role of the finance sector in contributing to a low-carbon economy and decarbonisation cannot be denied. SFDR and the impact statements (PAIs) could act as a catalyst for the decarbonisation of real estate and the economy in general.

 

Amazing!! Can you tell me more about energy-efficient buildings? ğŸ˜

The buildings that have Green Building Standards and could be considered energy efficient, use LED lighting and energy-efficient appliances. ğŸ‘ Various parameters like the size of the structure, building design, insulation, and landscaping could be used as a yardstick for the measurement of energy intensity and efficiency. Moreover, these features reduceğŸ‘‡ the cost of heating, cooling as well as electricity (the majority of which is still contributed by fossil fuels) ğŸ¤©.

Being energy efficient doesn’t just mean causing less emission. Rather, it has a holistic approach to best sustainable practices. The UN Sustainable Development Goal  7 and 11 talk about affordable and clean energy and sustainable cities. â™»ï¸ It has two codes, namely, renewable energy and energy efficiency.  So if you believe in these SDGs, you can align with PAIs too. 

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

Greening the real estate sector would lead to improved quality of life and the planet. ğŸŒ Accountability of investee companies in terms of disclosure in energy inefficient real estate can help in strengthening trust among different stakeholders, especially the investors. Moreover, the short-term cost of implementing these changes like installing solar panels is always lesser compared to long-term mitigating costs. By encouraging renewable energy in real estate investment, you could make a positive impact on the environment as well as on your portfolio. ğŸ‘Œ

As an indirect investor in this market (via investment in real estate companies), you could use SFDR and PAI as the guiding roadmap. ğŸ—ºï¸ However, real estate asset managers will need the appropriate resources and expertise to be able to measure these indicators and comply with the regulation. This makes the sustainable investing market more complex. So, we are here to simplify this regulation for you and make interpretation easy and meaningful.

 

Who does this apply to?

Being an EU directive, the SFDR directly applies to the financial market participants and advisors inside the European Union. This, however, does not mean that it has no impact on institutions based outside of the union. ğŸ˜± Any investment manager, European or not, who wishes to market their product to potential clients within the EU must follow the rules set out by the directive. ğŸ˜® The EU comprising the third-largest economy in the world (behind the US and China), it is an attractive market – therefore, it is very plausible that we’ll also see many overseas companies disclose their sustainability risks and impacts in the near future.

 

Yeah, but why do I need to care about this? ğŸ¤·

Because you are a responsible investor. ğŸ¤“ You could be a value driver by making a positive impact through your investment. ğŸ‘ Moreover, from a risk and return point of view, the investee companies with exposure in energy inefficient real estate are more prone to physical (e.g., flooding) and transitional risk (change in regulation). Energy efficiency means taking all the E(environment), S(Social) and G(Governance) aspects and risks into consideration, and making these structures resilient to physical and transient risk. So, it is always prudent to evaluate your portfolio and see the ranking of investee companies.

SFDR will encourage the investee companies who are borrowing money in the capital market to improve their sustainability performance by aligning with predetermined disclosure templates. So, you can use these templates to make an investment which has ESF objectives. ğŸ’ª

articles.a_content:
Sustainability has become such a buzz word now that many certifications tend to label  products and services claiming to be sustainable or eco-friendly. ğŸ˜© But what about the companies who make these products? How do we know if these companies are really making efforts for the environment, society and sustainability or just for the benefits of greenwashing? ğŸ¤¨ Let’s find out!

ğŸ‘‰ What is a B-Corp?

B-Corp is similar to an organic certificate for food products in Europe or fair-trade certificate for producers in the developing countries, only it is a label for the business entities. It is a certification issued by B-Lab, a voluntary non-profit making organization, for companies who are making profit. B-lab is based in the USA, Canada, Europe, Australia, and New Zealand.

 

Who is given this certificate? ğŸ¤”

Companies are given a B-Corp certificate depending on whether they are meeting the conditions below ğŸ‘‡

âœ… Accountability: The board of directors or the management must consider the impact of the company on all the shareholders or the owners whose money is invested in the company.

âœ… Transparency: The Certified B-corporations are required to make and publish report about their economic and social performance and of course this will be assessed by a third party.

âœ… Performance: The companies need to perform well in the B-lab assessment criteria. That means they need to secure 80 or above in the impact assessment score and also pass the risk review.

 

Great, then is it easy to get this certificate?

Well, it is not that easy to get a certificate by B-lab. ğŸ˜… The applicant must score a minimum score of 80 in the 200-score scale and have to meet the highest criteria of ensuring social and environmental performance. Till now only 5500 corporations worldwide are certified with B-Corp certifications in around 84 countries in 177 different industries.

So, how can a company get this certificate in two days? ğŸ¤“

Whoah, hold your horses!! It is not an online certificate a company can get instantly. ğŸ˜® The time and process will depend on the structure of the company. It is easier and less time-consuming for a smaller company as compared to a large one. This is because the evaluation process for a large company would involve a large set of data and systems which will be checked.

The company or corporation needs to do a few things before it can call itself a B-corporation:

ğŸ‘‰ Do the B impact assessment for itself.

ğŸ‘‰ Improve on how the company is governed by using the legal requirement tool.

ğŸ‘‰ Fill the Disclosure Questionnaire.

ğŸ‘‰ Go through the Evaluation and Verification phase, where B Lab global evaluate the structure of the company, involvement in any controversial industries and submit supporting documents for the answers.

ğŸ‘‰ After verification, congrats! You can claim to be a B-corporation.

ğŸ‘‰ This certificate must be renewed every three years.

ğŸ‘‰ The B-Corp organizations have an impact business model.

 

Lmao ok, nerds. What does that all mean in normal English? ğŸ¤¨

So, in simple words when a company takes resources from the society or environment to make a product, accountability and transparency with regard to their impact is required. â˜ï¸ This certificate is an evaluation of a company in five ğŸ– different categories, i.e., community, environment, customers, workers, governance. This certificate increases the brand and market value of a company, even though this certificate does not have a legal validity or status.

Thus, with the B-Corp label, it would be easier for you as an impactor to filter the companies as per your choice of impact.

 

 

Who can apply for it? ğŸ§

Any business entity small or big, proprietorship, partnership, or a company can apply for it. There are different assessment criteria to give them certifications though. The business set up who wants to work not just for profit but also to make an impact in the community, in the society, they can apply for this certificate.

 

I guess that’s all kind of nice… But why should I care? ğŸ¤·‍â™‚ï¸

Because it is easier for retail investors to join a global community of changemakers who are making an impact in sustainable communities and the environment. These labels can be checked by the investor for choosing a financial product in the similar way a fair trade certificate is checked for buying a consumer product. ğŸ™Œ These labels are indicators of highest-level transparency, accountability, and impact of companies on social and environmental factors. So, it’s easy for you as an investor, just search for the above symbol and relax. Someone else has done the background check for the companies.
